content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Pros: Trains! Rewarding and addicting gameplay, beautiful visuals, lots of world options. Can build while paused. Post-release updates.Cons: The vehicle choices are very front-loaded, by the year 2000 there's only a few train engines and railcars that are at all useful and only one road vehicle each for passenger and cargo. I expect this to improve with mods or DLCs but I don't see Steam Workshop support coming soon so modding will still require some technical knowledge and tinkering in the game files for the foreseeable future.While the graphics are great, I get better performance in much more detailed games, which leads me to believe that there's still plenty of optimization to be done. I've been playing it mainly on Linux but I remember it suffering unnecessarily on Windows as well. It also stutters occasionally on Linux.The interface is clunky, sometimes buggy, and lacks inspiration, though some recent updates have improved the first two complaints somewhat. However, I expect to see GUI improvement mods become very popular.There's not much variance in the geography, it's basically a green grass field deformed by a randomized heightmap. I'd like to see more variance in biomes and maybe seasons if possible. I expect this to appear in mods or DLCs, though I'd prefer to have seen it in the base game or at least a free update.Based on recent communications, the devs seem to be relying on the modding community to do a lot of their work for them. I hope they keep in mind that a modding community isn't going to flourish without a great game to build on. This has all the makings of a great game, but it's still got some things to iron out. I hope they keep their priorities in line.TL;DR: It's fun now, but a cautious buyer might want to hold off and see how the game develops, because it still needs quite a bit of work.

												Very great looking game and I enjoy it a lot. Played a lot of Tansport Tycoon, Sid Meyers Railroads, Locomotion and so on and I think if you can take the approatch that you don't try to compare it too much with OTTD or Locomotion you will be able to enjoy it more. It takes a more realistic approach on route planning and so forth and if you accept those things and play by those rules you will get a lot more out of it. Also one big part is all the great mods available, without them it would not be as good, head over to http://www.train-fever.net/filebase/index.php/TermsOfUse/?redirect=%2Ffilebase%2Findex.php%2FFilebase%2F7-Mod-Packs%2F&s=4565470c579b5e167de31365c1b58d6f573c5d16 if you are interested in those.If you are new to the game I urge you to read as much as possible about player feedback in the forums, there are a lot of good solutions and tips and tricks to make i easier and more fun to play. There is also great player made tutorials which explains game mechanics, how to set up lines, how to use signals correctly in the game and other stuff, check them out!Game still have some flaws but I think the devs are doing a good job by constantly pushing out updates and listening to de the community, especially considering how small studio it is.For me it was defenatly worth the money, maybe not in the beginning but after all updates as of today 14.11.2014 it is.+ Great looking+ The available mods, absolutely amazing job by all modders!+ So far constant updates to fix issues and address player requests+ Waypoints intoduced in latest update- Some limitations in track building, for example rail crossings, unable to upgrade stations without demolishing- Traffic jam problems later in game (have been addressed in latest update but some players still report about clogged up traffic)- Time consuming to renew vehicles, however you can send whole line to depo to be sold on arrival which makes it a bit easier- Performance issues later, minimum requirements wont get you far...- Sometimes might be really hard to get good working cargo lines, especially if you would like to transport longer ways, be sure to check out out how cargo is being transported, helps out a lot (bottom right corner with 3 sheets)Sorry if there is some misspelling, english is not my native language.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												First of all, I'm not really an expert on the game yet. I loved Railroad Tycoon so I was really exicted when I saw this in the Steam-Lottery and even won the game. In short: I can't say I wasted my money (partly due to me not spending any money).The game is easy to get into, given you know how these kinds of games play out. If you ever played Railroad Tycoon or Sid Meier's: Railroads you'll know what to do from the start. All the others currently have to rely on Steam guides or trial-and-error to get the basics down. Given the lack of interesting industries (without mods) it's not a difficult game, though I don't think it is supposed to be since most of the fun comes from watching your little trains make their rounds and queue up at busy stations. It's a great game for everyone who ever wanted some miniature model trains but either doesn't have the space, the money, or loving parents who'd buy it for them during their childhood. During my playtime I didn't encounter a single bug.As it is right now, the game's performance isn't all that great. I often get lags and freezes at the end of an ingame month and a general decrease in FPS as the game progresses, it always stays at a playable rate (lowest I got was 26 FPS). I think that might be fixed in the future though! There also seem to be a lot of updates, so I'd bet my money on that. The game also offers a modding community, which sadly isn't that big. This can and, hopefully, will change as well in the future though.Overall I see a lot of potential in this game, but I wouldn't spend the full price buying it. Pro:Nice if you like watching trains do their roundsDecent graphicsMod supportActive devsCon:PerformanceLong-term motivation (lack of industries)

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												This game is one of the very good "tycoon's" But i must admit that there are some issues with the game still , that really for me took a lot away from it. Basicly what im most cross about, is the fact that as an example the later road vehicles has a listed speed of 100 km/h, BUT even with the best roads of the time of the vehicle you cant drive more then 70... thats just not very user friendly. Stuff like that is in the game in many places still. That being said i thoroughly enjoyed myself, more so then with any other tycoon since railroad tycoon 2. But one other very serious issue in the game to my mind, the AI behind the movement of passenger travel. If i make a train "with no stops" to a city 6 minutes away, and the wait time then becomes 12 minutes, i can get the same passenger transfer with trams, but with only 30 secs wait time and 12 minutes transfer time. That will mean that the passenger will take the tram almost every time. Thats not very logical in my opinion. The real issue with this, is the fact that you can more passengers with the trams for less money, both in terms of /year, and initial investment. Thus trains are not viable economicly in the game unless you play on the biggest map, which even a intel i5-3570 cant handle reliably, if you try to setup lines for all cities. (and only if you use a lot of trains on that perticular line). One of the main ways to remedy would be if the developers fixed passenger embarkment onto trains. It makes no sense that a passenger in 1850 takes as long to enter a train as he does in 2020. Not does it make sense that they seemingly only uses one entrypoint, instead of one per traincar. ex, if you have a train with 15 cars, with 20 passengers capacity each, it simply should take the same time to get onto said train as the same train with 1 car, with space for 20 passengers. At least very close to that. One thing id like to see in the future, is something like "station upkeep" being a togglebar, that could help on station turnaround times/passenger embarkment. And something like dining cars and the like. But again i cannot stress enough, it really is a good game, with a lot of potential.

												This is a very nice Transport business simulator.The developers clearly have an eye for details.It is a challenging game. Most of the complaints you see about how hard the game is, are simply part of the challenge of the game. It shouldn't be too easy to get your company profitable. content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												As a huge fan of TT, RT series, Simurtans and OpenTTD I was thrilled to see a new player in the genre built on a 3D engine.It doesn't have planes and boats and the whole simulation is quite different from the earlier mentioned games, it is by far more realistic.You have buses, trucks trams and trains and start in 1850 with a loan and along the time axis, new vehicles will be available. Go from Steam trains to TGV (named FGV due to license rights).It's a great challenge to plan the infra structure to transport passengers and goods. You can't build 90 degree curves or 45 degree slopes, just as in reality. You need to be a bit patient in the beginning before you have learned to rethink all you know about these kind of games. When you have mastered it, there are a ton of mods to download, everything from UI & Hud skinning, vehicles and new factory chains.If you like Sandbox games, this can be turn into sandbox mode by downloading two mods; Cost mod and Timeless mod.The game development is mainly community driven with a very dedicated team of developers at Urban Games. Updates and new features are released quite often.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Train Fever in the mold of Railroad Tycoon and Transport Tycoon. The goal of the game is to build a vast and profitable transport network using road and railroad. The game allows you to transport both resources and passengers. It is a decent game in the genre.What the game does right is the basic economy with town growth and resource supply and demand. It has neat animations to show how the different resources and people are transported when not transported on your network, making it so that not everyone is solely dependant on your transportation even if that helps. The town grows at a good speed throughout the game making your transportation efforts visible on the map.The build tool is a bit quirky but does what it is supposed to do and you mostly get used to it after a while. The UI in general is a bit quirky with popup windows popping up anywhere on the screen.The main drawback of the game is the limited amount of resources (just 5). It is also often hard to know what industries will yield a lot of resources and thus be profitable to transport and if you built a long railroad line just to transport the resources of an industry that happened to not be producing anything, then you wasted a lot of money. The economy could in general do with a lot more information and charts so that it is easy to understand what might be profitable.

number of helpful: 18 of 23 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												This is one of those games that is never going to escape it's troubled beginnings. There have been some pretty major bugs that have plagued the development of this game and the fledgling developer has done a respectable job at addressing these. At it's core, this is a deep game with a super-steep learning curve and some frustrating interface/gameplay issues. So why is this getting a thumbs up from me? Because despite this, there is still a game that has absorbed me and has given me 80 hours of gameplay.It's totally sandbox; you're on your own and just poking around with the game doing whatever you want with little other than profit and loss to guide you. But sometimes that's what you want, to just fiddle around and not have some corny derivitive quest thrown at you, or feel as though the goals set by the game are railroading you (pun intended) into playing a type of way you don't want to play.Big tip: always start with bus routes, get several towns running, then you can start playing around with trams or connecting up compatible industries, expanding until you have enough to start laying track. It's about feeling when you're ready to expand into the next big step, being cautious and backing off if something isn't working.But, this game would benefit from so much that would take the guesswork out of all this. The developers have obviously tried to go for a more intuitive feel to how you play a transport game, moving away from things like catchment zones when placing stops and the like, which should translate as more realistic: people in real life will travel as far as they need to for public transport, it isn't a binary 'I'm 100 metres away, I'm good to go. I'm 101 metres away, I'm not going that far,' but this does mean that you have no real sense for how far apart stops should be, whether you're bogging your system down with too many stops or missing out chunks of possible passengers because it's quicker to walk. But, in the end, as long as you're making money, who really cares about digital people having to walk a mile to work?The simulation is broad and develops impressively over time, but again has some issues. Watching towns grow and develop over time is fascinating, although growth tends to often be counter-intuitive, with roads appearing almost randomly. Although you can place roads and have some control over the development of settlements, the lack of accompanying features and relatively minimal feedback into the transport part of the game, besides the ability to add a shortcut to complete a route or upgrade roads to improve speed, means there isn't much reward for getting into this too much.All in all, the game is playable, albeit with its own little eccentricities. The game is more of a relaxing pass-the-time style than quest-driven adventure through the decades. But, as I've said, it works of you like that kind of game.The developers are starting fresh with a new game rather than patching and updating this one, which tells me several things. Firstly, they've learnt a lot from this game and have listened to feedback and know that to try and put in all the stuff people want and correct the mistakes that the game has grown up with would be huge and likely game-breaking. But, it also tells me that they are still passionate about this game: they could have done what some many other developers have done, gotten as far as they could with their first attempt and then gone in a different direction. But they haven't. They are building on what they've learnt and starting fresh and in the world of game development, taking years to develop your first game, which is good but bogged down with virtually insurmountable problems, is the easy way to bankruptcy. So, I'm still happy I paid for this game, supported whoever is behind Urban Games, and I'll be there to support their passion for making the right game that they've always imagined when Transport Fever is released.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												As for the question: "Should I buy it?", the answer is "Not anymore, because it just got a much better sequel."Don't get me wrong, in the last two years the game got a lot of support and a massive free DLC, but it still hasn't fixed its most glaring flaws.1. The interface is atrocious all the time, and counter-intuitive most of the time. Several useful options are buried deep in the awkward multi-tabbed menus, and some are absent entirely, like adding more platforms to an already-built station.2. Gameplay is simplistic by design, and worse yet, it's badly explained. Besides supplying factories with raw materials, you're never explicitly told what effect your transportation efforts have on the cities and why. 3. Game balance is odd. Early game is usually a breeze, particularly if you focus on the obvious choice of passenger transport, but if you slip in late game, you're done even if you quickly go for damage control.With the release of the sequel I mentioned, called "Transport Fever" and priced similarly to this game, I strongly advise you to give this one a pass.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												I bought this game for trains. Unfortunately, there is a lot more to it than that. I have (currently) spent fifteen hours micro-managing trams, busses and eventually trains. Just when I am getting to have some fun with the trains, all of the busses in one of the towns become end of life and need replacing. There goes an hour sorting that out, back to the trains. Half an hour later, you guessed it, replace more busses. At the moment I am concentrating on moving people around and haven’t even looked at the raw materials and goods aspect of the game. I just want to play with trains and have to mess about with the other stuff to get the required money.Setting up the busses and trams is fairly straightforward, or so I thought. Apparently there is a twenty minute rule, if a journey takes longer than twenty minutes then the route will not be used, the passenger disappears or the goods never move. This compounds the micro-management by increasing the number of routes required in order to keep them short enough to not fall foul of the rule.Building a train line can be a bit of hard work, especially for your hard drive. The golden rule is if the land you are looking to build on deviates from flat by a jot, SAVE. There is little to assist in surveying and planning a route, mistakes are costly as there is no undo button. You either revert to a previous save or pay to demolish your mistake. Save files for the “large” game are over 70MB.  Placing track is far from intuitive.Things I would like to see; instead of telling me something is too old and needs replacing give me the option to replace it there and then, three digit vehicle numbers with leading zeros, better surveying tools, warnings when a route is too long, AN UNDO BUTTON.Am I having fun? Just about. Do I recommend this game? Just about. If you like Transport Tycoon type games I think you will enjoy this. If you just want to play trains maybe suffering the learning curve of the Trainz Surveyor maybe more suited.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												A spiritual successor to Transport Tycoon, this game will be very easy to pick up for any fans of the original. It has a very similar feel, though it incorporates some of the better aspects of games such as Cities in Motion and Railroad Tycoon - this includes from Railroad Tycoon the automatic goods transportation at a slow, but nevertheless present rate, meaning they aren't entirely reliant on your company to transport things - as well as the detailed city sector, supply and demand and "line" system from Cities in Motion.This means, for example, at a passenger station for trains, you might want to bring in more people from around town via buses and trams that otherwise would not be at the station, and then unlike transport tycoon, it doesn't have a system where "everything at the station boards the first train arriving and then travels to the first stop that train goes to and all unloads". Rather, the game individually simulates everyone in cities, meaning they could have a job in another town, or want to go shop, or leisure purposes - whatever. As a result, they have a specific "line" they want to board, and a specific stop they want to get off at should the line have more than 1 stop. You won't have situations where everyone boards whatever train and travels to wherever as a result, and you will find that new lines that expand to new cities will result in any lines it connects to seeing a boost in passenger usage as some will get off the train and immedietly wait for another line to get to their destination - hence, more money as they pay twice to get there.This also presents a challenge as time goes on, because starting in the early 1900s, people begin to get cars to drive about. This means fewer people will want to use mass transit systems you've set up, and you'll have to make your systems faster and more efficient to make it preferable to driving as cars become more widespread. It also presents traffic issues for your buses, trucks, and trams, as they now have to deal with traffic on the road which more often than not is slower than they are.These concepts do not apply only to passengers, however. Cargo runs on a similar system - you can't just hook up, say, any coal mine to any steel mill and expect instant cargo. Raw material producing plants have a specific location they want their goods transported to, possibly more than one depending on the size of the industry. Then, that cargo place where the raw materials are delivered has a specific place IT wants to go - usually. I've found that goods are a bit more lenient in this sense, and will allow you to go a bit further away to a neighboring city or something. This also presents a difficult issue because one of the easiest ways to set yourself up for the remainder of the game and never worry about bankrupcy in transport tycoon was to immedietly make a massive freight line that covered a large distance, giving you a lot of money for the distance and speed delivered with every train. You cannot do that in this game. That makes freight LESS profitable than passengers, and means you have to rely on the heavily variating levels of passengers on trains to provide the most money. Even then, trains get progressively more and more expensive to maintain - they are FAR more expensive to keep running than they were in transport tycoon, especially in later stages. To make it more difficult, every item in the game comes in much shorter supply than it would have been in transport tycoon - you won't find hundreds of passengers or freight lining up at a station within a couple years of service. In fact, you won't find hundreds of items lining up for likely a hundred years or more, if ever.I have to mention the music of course. It's quite catchy. Comparitavely with the other 2 transport tycoon games, it's actually quite good and does a good job of being background music that isn't too flashy or disturbing to the gameplay while at the same time, not too drab to feel boring or something - and it's coupled with a FANTASTIC tribute song to the original transport tycoon theme.Now, the downsides. The game is currently littered with things that plainly are bugs or things that I'm not sure if they ARE bugs. An example of a bug is passengers and cargo will disappear off things they are being transported on during longer trips, or that while you can make a railroad cross over a road, you cannot make a road cross a rail...which is frustrating. An example of something that COULD be a bug is the lack of ability to make twin crossover tracks, or any crossover tracks at all. 2 tracks can NEVER cross each other for any purpose, which means to do something as basic as a crossover between 2 rails, you have to do 2 sets of alternating switches next to each other, which causes pathfinding issues likely as another bug, and to have rails cross for a different route or something, you need to have one route switch onto the other, then back off again. It could be a bug, but if not, I find it very irritating regardless.Another curious thing wrong with the game is it's lack of basic options such as keyboard rebinding, switching units from metric to imperial, or zoom/snap to an object you have selected (making you have to find it yourself using the PIP screen). It also lacks multiplayer or any form of AI opponents - I myself am more a fan of multiplayer in these games than AI, but I know there are people who wish for them or just both in general. The "expansive 256 km squared" maps really aren't that expansive - on large, the maps are 4-6 cities in length...being only 16x16 km in size for the large map. This could explain the lack of multiplayer or AI, because the map would fill up FAR too quickly with other companies.Overall, I love this game. I have always wanted to see what a transport tycoon game might look like in 3D, and what do you know - here it is. They got the scale and realism right, making it great to look at, and for a team of 3 people I am VERY impressed with their graphics engine they created. This is a difficult game making it hard to recommend to anyone who hasn't played a transportation sim before, but considering the majority of the world has played one, I would HIGHLY recommend it to you fans out there. Enjoy the game!

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Nearly everything I've experienced with this game has been positive.I first saw this advertised on the Frontpage, as a pre-order. With only 11 hours to go, I went ahead and bought it after watching the trailer and looking at the screenshots - it definetley looked like something I'd enjoy.Loading the game took a little longer than I was comfortable with, and the menu music felt really dated and out-of-place. That was very quickly rectified by a short stop to the Options menu. Unfortunately, this game seems to suffer with load times - loading any save game (which are >= 250MB each...) takes around three minutes; after loading in, there's some slight lag while the game builds up the environment.Gameplay was surprisingly enjoyable. You have control of buses, trams and railways and need to connect up two or more towns and build a successful business. It can be hard at first, but once you've swept past the learning curve it all falls into place. Furthermore, the random terrain generation (seeds) makes each replay a unique experience in its own right.It does have some other shortcomings, though. Terrain is annoying; if you make a mistake, you can't rectify it with the terrain tools if it's too close to a structure or river. I was left with two sheer cliffs after demolishing my railway bridge - I could not remove them.Overall, I'd rate this game a hearty 8.5/10 - it's still got potential, but enough content to keep me interested until the next patches/DLC.

												I really like this game, first time I played 20 hours. Then 1/2 yr later started again and watched some tutorials tips and tricks and reading some guides > really enjoyed the next 100 hours. my beginner tips:- start with flat small map, you will start new map(games) often as learning- start on easy  (it brings enough money to allow for mistakes)- building a long road /railway in 1 piece is expensive, build it in shorter parts.- key M and N raise / lower the middle part of the road while building- trains bring good money until about 1980 - then you need cities > 600 people to get enough money, otherwise bus lines are more effective.- Buildling larger cities is something which requieres many connections to other cities and supply of enough goods, not so easy to do (as beginner) but fun to learn.- nice mixture of planning, constructing, buying and replacing vehicles, checking constantly for efficeny of transport lines, constant looking into expanding and improving, zooming in and follow a vehicle and enjoy the ride Looking forward to TransportFever end of 2016.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												It's a good tycoon game about transportation, mostly trains. You also have trucks, trams, buses and trucks, but those are mostly used to set up local networks that enables wider access to your trains,Train simulation is pretty complex, with lots of factors coming into play: Track curvature, slope steepness, engine power output, tractive power, and weight of the wagons, so a lot of the gameplay is about designing efficient tracks, that allow your trains to navigate through the (fully 3d) terrain in the most efficient way possible; then populating the trains with suitable engines and wagons.Here I should add that this is unfortunately also the game's weakest point (although it's not such a big deal): laying tracks and modifying terrain is often very quirky. It often takes several tries (and a lot of bulldozing, which also costs you in-game money) to get a track, or junctions, just the way you like it. Crossing rivers and roads is even more complicated, which put me off a bit. All in all, however, while I do think they could have polished this aspect some more, I understand that the complexity of laying tracks is part of the charm of the game, and that how good you are at balancing between length, steepness, curvature and train power will determine how efficient your network will be.The economic simulation is surprisingly complex, and engaging. Towns will react to your lines by increasing in size and height (sometimes massively). Despite its complexity, it's easy to pick up after reading a couple guidelines given to you at the beginning of the game. I don't think you'd have any trouble with it if you ever played TTD before.Graphically it is stellar, and once I got my game going, I often found myself just watching how my trains navigate the network I laid out.Finally, I'll also add that I've owned this game for a few months before reviewing it, and that the devs have adressed many of the issues that the game used to have, and delivered a lot more content with the free USA DLC. In short, if you like trains and tycoon games, this is a good buy.

number of helpful: 18 of 25 people (72%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												I am a fan of Railroad Tycoon Simulator and decided to try this one to see what do I get.The pros: the bus system is a great plus to the train builder which allows you the perfect support for your trains to reach anywhere (no need to set a station next to a hub of farms just to get their cargo for example). The graphics are clearly great in details and the map builder engine allows each map to be always different.The cons: - The user interface is TERRIBLE, sometimes I feel I am in some sort of tool like Photoshop with lots of mini Windows instead than having a clear UI designed and themed as a game. - The graphics are good, but on auto-generating it you can feel it's not that beautiful. I prefer to play real life maps like England or France and feel like the tycoons of its day building the railroad and connecting historical cities.- The options to set up the trains are very limited, even the buses, you can play a few hours but there isn't much to it, not much strategy or required set up to adapt to changes as there aren't that many changes or doesn't seem to.- The building tracks engine is terrible. It generates unnecessary climbs or tunnels and requires to invest massive fortunes just to connect to pieces that aren't that unlevelled and in other games are much easier to connect. Ok I know RailroadTyccon is quite unrealistic with certain train tracks but in the end you can connect the pieces without so much hassle and play, which is the point after all, having fun, not realism.- Didn't play enough as to know this, but doesn't seem to allow me to build factories or any other sort of business like hotels or pubs which usually increases the game possibilities as you are running a company and not necessarily want to stick to trains only, giving you full control of goods transport and production. Though in compensation you have the buses and roads.I still haven't played it that much as to completely value it and I'm certain there is more to it than what I've seen, will update this review if I see more pros or I change my mind on certain cons, but so far this is what I saw.Personally, having Railroad Tycoon 2 and 3, any of those is more fun from minute 1 and makes me evade from this world consuming hours of my life without realizing, which probes how good they are as games, this game instead made me check the clock several times as I was getting bored and stressed. Can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												After seeing all the negative reviews I thought I'd put in my two cents.  First, I think this game is awesome.  So naturally my review is biased, but so is everyone else's.  In order to follow the established trend here is my bullet point list of good and bad traits.Good:-modern graphics engine-realistic train physics:     -speed is adjusted based on angle of curve, incline/decline, weight, and power to name a few of the ones I've noticed     -tracks must follow the same rules as real world train tracks (eg.  no steep hills, no sharp turns, 90 degree road crossings)     -train signals are realistic and easy to manage-play your way (eg. city management, train empire, trading mogul)-easy to use menu and interface-dragable windows with real time feedback on anything and everything-your actions affect the size of your cities in real time-procedually generated so always something new-did I mention how fun it is?Bad:-no manual / poor tutorial-repetative-steep learning curve (bad?)Here's where I defend my review and tell you why all the negative reviews are wrong.  First, the complaint I read the most is that there are too many rules regarding track building.  That is the "simulation" part of the game, trains have a very low tollerance for sharp curves, steep hills, and road crossings.  Get over it!  The other main complaing is the lack of manual, well here you go:Train Fever Interactive Gude:  (Link Removed...just search train fever website forums for great interacive guide)Your welcome!The most useful advice I learned is that the maximum travel time for people or goods is 20 mins, and the npc's will pick the quickest route regardless of cost.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												This is a hard game to recomend but I am going to anyways. This game (at the time of my writing this) has many problems. But I think what the game does do well makes up for its problems. It might help if you go into the game with little to no expectations so that you are less dismayed by its faults. I will list some of the biggest problems I have with the game and then some of the main things I think make the game worth playing.Problems:1. Replacing older vehicles is a real chore. The need to keep up frequency on your lines really compounds this problem. Also there is no way to disable the annoying messages that fill the bottom of the screen notifying of a vehicle that has reached its life span.2. I find the balancing of the stats on the vehicles along with when they come out and are made obsolete to be very poorly done. As one example the running costs of a locomotive is easily 10-20 times that of a road vehicle making the construction of train lines very risky if you don't know just the right circumstances to make a profitable line. And even if you can manage a profitable train line you are almost guarenteed to be able to make a much more profitable bus/tram or truck line in place of the train.3. Collision issues while doing road and rail construction is very inflexible. It seems the majority of construction atempts are going to give you a collision message meaning it won't allow it. Often times you either have to make significant compromises to your plans, forget your plans altogether, or invest a lot of money and work into making it work. Such as spending millions of dollars bulldozing buildings along a road just so you can upgrade the road or connect another road to the road, even if there was a large open spot where no buildings were in the way.Good things:1. The sounds and visuals of the game are very appealing in my opinion. I spend much of my time just following vehicles around or watching people go whereever they are going. I think the next closest game of this type would be Cities in Motion but sunnier.2. The randomly generated maps and cities are very impressive. Granted there isn't a lot of variety in the generation catogories for the maps, but even so, the type of landscape it does generate is very well done. As far as I know there is no other game of this type that has comparable map and city generation. Also the way the cities gradually develope is well done and satisfying. The speed at which they grow is largely based on how well connected the town is with itself and with other towns as well as how fully it is being supplied with goods.3. The realistic supply and demand of the passengers in the game is really nice and gives a lot of incentive to connect to every town you can. Every person has 4 locations they are assigned. A home, a place of work, a place to shop and a place for leisure. They will often re-assign locations based on what new options are available. They have a 20 minute deadline on any travel plans they make. So the faster your transportation becomes the further they can travel within the time limit and so the more opertunities exist for you to make money in transporting them.These are just some of the more prominant issues, both good and bad, that exist in the game. But it hopefully gives a sense of whether you might enjoy the game or not. The balancing problem I mention can relatively easily be dealt with through mods. Finding the right one for your tastes and installing them is a bit of a hassle though when ideally the game could have just been better balanced by the developers themselves.I personnally think it is a great game and have had a lot of enjoyment with it. But the lost potential of what this game could be is admittedly frustrating and I can certainly understand why some people might be too put off to continue playing it.

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I wouldn't buy it. Not yet.The game is a cross between Cities in Motion and OpenTTD. It's built in Unity and is a lot of fun to build train routes with.There are however a host of problems that need to be addressed before it's really a "final" game. The UI is cheap. Cities do not scale properly based on the decade you start in (1850 / 1900 / 1950) which can create monetary issues ias it lacks balance. Vehicles do not use stations in a smart way (a route will only use the same track, always.) and while pedestrians are very smart with their travel, the game doesn't seem to produce a lot of demand as you'd expect. The industries are not profitable with trains (because of their high operating costs)The game is also very laggy and processor-intensive because it's using Unity.Lastly a lot of things that should be easy (scheduling to prevent bunching up trains, upgrading trains and engines over time, etc.) that are in much better-developed, free games like OpenTTD are completely lacking in Train Fever.The developers really should have invested more into the game in terms of development. And the game could use more fine tuning before it's where it needs to be.But do I play it? Yes. It's still interesting. I'll probably get bored of it unfortunately like with Cities in Motion due to the simplicity of the game.

												Great game! Have no idea how it may have negative reviews, because the game is unique and don't have any analogue.Basically it is mix of OpenTTD and Cities in Motion, but with nice graphics and GUI!From OpenTTD it takes large maps with many cities, industry, cute trains and slow time progression from 1850 to modern world, through horse carriages and steam punk cars.From Cities in Motion it takes similar method to place stops and routes.The cons are:- No airplanes, helicopters and ships (will be added in the Transport Fever!) (hope helicopters too)- Only 3 industry chains and industry buildings is too small and not epic (hope it will looks better in Transport Fever)- Like in OpenTTD, trains still have a possibility to switch its direction instantly. It would be much better to make it realistically, like in Cities in Motion. Hope it will be fixed in Transport Fever.- No multiplayer. It's sad. Developers really should think about it! The new Transport Fever with multiplayer really may replace the OpenTTD!There is some another small problems, but this is not important, because there is no another games like OpenTTD but with modern graphics. Besides that, in this game, everything based  on curves (not tiles) as result, trains looks much, much more better.

number of helpful: 16 of 24 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Don't get me wrong. Train Fever is not a perfect game. There are some performance issues on larger maps, some aspects of micromanaging are tedious, and I question the balance between train and truck income.That said, it's still a pretty decent game in a genre that doesn't get alot of love. And if you enjoy building train lines and roads and such, there's a good chance you'll find something to like in Train Fever.I really like the UI, which is really important in this kind of game. It's simple, unintrusive, and fully customizable. You can follow any number of vehicles, lines, charts, etc. I also like how when you have a window open, like of a vehicle, you can zoom within the window, click on a building within the window, and that will open a new window.The building and terraforming tools are quite good once you have them fully figured out. Graphics could be better, but they don't distract from the experience. Good music.Even with its flaws, I can still recommend this game. If you have any fond memories of the transport sims of yesteryear, Train Fever is worth a play.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												You will find a lot of other reviews that pretty well describe the content of the game.Instead, let me recommend you this game or not depending on what kind of gamer you are. Because I believe it really depends on that.Basically, if you love to play with trains, trams, trucks and busses and to throw in some tycoon-like gameplay, this will probably be a game for you.If on the other hand you are looking for a strategy game, a business simulator or an advanced train simulator, this could disappoint you. Train Fever is a middle-of-the-road game when it comes to the balance between an eye-candy, fun transportation game and a hard-core ressource management game. Train Fever does have its addicting side though. Is the next train stop profitable? Did the passengers from the tram transfer to the train? How much faster did the track become after the rebuild you made? Oh is that the time? I should go to bed now.....I will....in a minute.....I just need to..... Lastly a warning to you if your patience with imbalanced games is short. Once you dig into the game you will (at the time of this review) find quite a few lose ends in how the game works. It is not something that is going to ruin the party for a casual gamer. But parts of the games' economic simulation is broken to be honest. TIme will show if that is adressed by patches or not. But it should.I'll give TF 4 out of 5 stars for the many addicting hours of play it offers. It would get 5 of 5 if they would fix the broken parts  and include either a multiplayer option or some AI. Sadly there is presently neither,

number of helpful: 26 of 42 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												I came to this game from a background of  RailRoad Tycoon 3  (Released 2003)  9.99 USD on SteamRailroad Tycoon 3  is getting a bit "long in the tooth" and I was hoping for an upgrade. While Railroad Tycoon 3 is not as pretty, in my judgement it is a superior game to Train Fever (and its sucessor Transport Fever) in many ways.Railroad Tycoon 3 has no signals and these are an improvement, it did have water towers and maintenance sheds that are absent from Transport Fever. Growing up in a railroad town spoiled me but I'd also expect a turntable. Railroad Tycoon 3  has no mechanic for returning empty freight cars for re-use. This game has them but unlike real world railcars, almost all wagon types are for a single commodity only. e.g. Why aren't coal hoppers and iron hoppers interchangeable?Railroad Tycoon 3  has a robust economic game with 30+ commodities in 1,2 and 3 deep production chains. Transport Fever has maybe a dozen commodities.Railroad Tycoon 3  had the ability to buy stock in your company and learn about the benefits (and dangers) of margin buying - no such thing exists in Train Fever.Railroad Tycoon 3  had a more robust undo ability for laying rail.Railroad Tycoon 3 had 66 Historical Locomotives rather than the 45 offered in Train Fever.Railroad Tycoon 3  had debt that changes as to rates making refinancing something that must be contemplatedRailroad Tycoon 3  had the ability to start (or buy existing) industries and businesses so as to further develop your transport empire. Railroad Tycoon 3 had AI Competitors that may require that you buy them out in certain scenarios.Railroad Tycoon 3 had AI Competitors based on real world people who played roles in the development of the Railroads. You got a bit of history with your gaming. Railroad Tycoon 3  had economic cycles that affect supply and demand. Nothing like it exists in Train Fever.Railroad Tycoon 3  had 20+ scenarios that really encourage you to explore the intticacies of the game . Train fever is pretty much sandbox only.Railroad Tycoon 3  had overview maps that made spotting industries and resources (and the demand for them) much clearer than anything offered in the "fever" games.Railroad Tycoon 3 had  the ability to build water towers and maintenance barns and the need to consider such things. Railroad Tycoon 3  had well laid out Train lists that show at-a-glance status information that you cannot see as easily in the "TF" gamesOh Yes... Transport fever offers planes and boats as well as rail and road transport. Unfortunately the basic UI and AI challenges that were handled so deftly in the antique Railroad Tycoon 3 are still handled somewhat poorly in Transport fever. There WAS and still is a lot of room for improvement in both games. Neither addresses switching engines. Those little workhorses that set up the long trains that we see crossing vast distances.  No marshalling yards are supported.  No telegraph service (an integral part of the US Railroads)  is modelled. Transport Fever LOOKS like a great game. I just wish that the devlopers paid more attention to what had gone before and incorporated some of the "things that worked" into their game design. I've played Train Fever quite a bit and once you get used to the demand driven economic model rather than the supply/price driven model used in the earlier game. It can be fun. But I do get a bad case of the "mightabeens" every time that I start to compare th game with its predecessor.   Now the discount offered to Train Fever owners  for the improved Transport Fever" brings the price down to $30 USD. The discount is going to have to be much deepr than that before I add  planes and boats and ignore the other shortcomings of the game.BTW... there ARE a few things that the developers could have done differntly that would have improved my rating:1) Track laying - Same day undo - allow any track laid to be demolished (on the same day) at no cost. This would somewhat make up for the lack of a real in-game track planning mode. 2) Enable ESC as a means of bringing up the main loading menu. The current method wastes time and screen real estate. 3) Make it easier to reload a saved game. I'm not sure whether this has been fixed in Transport fever but it required actually quitting and restarting the the game in Train Fever. 4) Options should also be available via the escape menu. If one wishes to turn off the game sounds or something similar one has to quit Train Fever. Why was music the only one that can be silenced in-game?5) If you're going to do windows DO WINDOWS. Windows should be resizeable. Scrollable left and right as well as up and down. Cut and paste renaming should be enabled as well. Allowing for longer names would be good too. Default names suggested based on terminals would be great. 6) Put a confirm on save game deletes. It was far too easy in Train Fever to delete the latest save game if one generally deletes a few saved games at start up time. 7) As with any simulator with economic aspects, graphs would be nice. Or even improved statistics on trains. 5 and 10 year running averages of revenue expenses profits, passengers.The graphs on cities in Train fever were there and useful but could be greatly expanded on. 8) How about a column on the industry list as to whether or not it's using a transport line. It's in the individual window so why not on the list? 9) Signals are important in this game. They should be easier to see whether zoomed in or out. 10) The Manage lines window should be sortable on Time, et al11) Station list should be sortable on cargo12) A button for next on line or next should be available in the vehicle details window13) The Mouse zoom feature should be more granular (more interim steps)14) A Trainopedia feature would be great.15) Towns list should show Goods needs supply and a few more details that are now only viewable in the city windows16) Commodities should be easier to see on a fully zoomed out map. 17) If this game were look more like Railroad Tycoon III as to GUI features, it would be great.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Wonderful game! Its fine as vanilla, and even better with mods. It's like having your own living model railroad, without spending a fortune. As the game goes on, the towns grow toward your stations, buildings, cars, and even the pedestrian's clothing styles change. You can spend hours just getting your lines set perfectly; the learning curve is not too steep, yet the gameplay is pretty complex, with each individual citizen having their own schedule, home, and workplace.All that complexity has a bit of a price though; I don't recommend playing a map size larger than "small" if you have a 32 bit system. Even with 64 bits, the game will start to lag toward endgame (there are now mods to help with that though.)The graphics are a bit cartoonish, which I think was the point, its like a model railroad, not intended for hardcore realism. The sounds are fine, but the music soundtrack leaves a bit to be desired IMO, it doesn't fit the mood of the game at all.Overall, I HIGHLY recommend this game if you are interested in trains, model railroads, or transit systems at all.

number of helpful: 17 of 26 people (65%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Definetely a big recommend!The game is missing a big tutorial, it just starts with basic tutorials how to set up your first transportation line with automatically moving vehicles. However, it's all about transportation and getting money for it. So there is not much more you have to use, except your human logic.So your transportation lines have to make sense. At first you have to check WHAT should be transported. For beginners, use trains and check out two companies that are close to each other.Company 1: Produces oil and sells it on the marketCompany 2: Needs oil in order to produce goodsSo, as you can imagine, in real life Company 1 would love to sell it's oil to Company 2 who absolutely needs it. BID AND ASK. All right, so just build two railway stations next to these companies, connect them. Create a new line in between these two railway stations, buy a train, tell it to drive according to the line you just created and thats it.The companies will notice AUTOMATICALLY that there NOW is a possibility to sell/buy oil from each other. The AI in this came is intelligent enough to notice this advantage. So Company 1 now notices, that there is a way to transport and sell it's oil to Company 2 using your railway station. What does Company 1 do now? It starts stacking up the produced oil barrels on your railway station. Your train will arrive, pick up the barrels, drive to Company 2 who automatically buys it. After arriving at Company 2 you instantly get the money. That's pretty simple.Now, for example, Company 2 takes Oil and produces GOODS. Villages and people living there need the goods. So what you can create a second transportation line between a nearby village and Company 2, in order to transport the produces goods to the village. Similar as in the example above, the companies/villages will notice this advantage and start ordering goods from Company 2 using your second line. Again you're earning money.Now, as the village gets goods to develop, you can also start building a THIRD line. On the lower right side of the user interface you can open a menu. One of the points allows you to show the houses of villages in colored codes. After enabling this option, you will see blue, yellow and green houses.Green houses = Houses where people live inYellow houses = Stores and places for people to have fun (e.g. after work)Blue houses = Offices/workplaces for the people that workIf you zoom in you can see that people have to walk a LOT from their homes in order to go to work every morning. So what you can do is simply creating a THIRD line to allow the people to travel from home to work by bus. Again the AI is intelligent enough to notice this advantage, so they will immediately start using your busses and pay money for tickets.Then, after more and more people work, your city gets more efficient. Companies grow and develop thanks to your lines transportating the workers, so after growing even MORE people can work there. Also the houses where families life in. The better the lines are set up, the more attractive the area in your city gets, leading to a rising population in your city. You really can see the city growing over time.So a last example, after work the people may be exhausted, so they need to relax, maybe going to yellow houses and playgrounds in the city. so why don't create a fourth line that transports the people in between work/stores/their home? They will use it then again.All you have to do in this game is thinking logically. The world is amazingly intelligent, it is fun to watch the city growing. Even companies grow if they notice that they can't produce enough products anymore in order to supply other companies. Every single move and line you create, every single bus stop, can change the peoples behavior and influence the way your city grows. This is fantastic.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												After weeks of playing this game half hour or less a week, I was very frustrated that it did not behave the way I wanted it to. Thoughts were - "What the hell is a 'Line' and why cant I send 20 trains to a single station all at once?""Why can't I re-create my dear old TTD stations" (e.g. RoRo)"Why won't this game let me have mega stations so I can show off my signalling brilliance that allows a 10 platformer to service 150 trains?"etc.Then, I got a good 30+ hours in the last two weeks. And I got to say, I like this train game the best of all the previous train transport games. (TT,  OTTD-my love, Railroad Tycoon series, Railroads!) and related franchises like Simcity, CIM.While all above whims I have didn't disappear, and the game still has some limitations and crazy roundabout ways of achieving simple things, once I left behind my elitist "this is how it should work because I say so" attitude behind, and went back to "trying to beat the game", everything changed! - I started appreciating the nuances of track building, which is brilliant!- I started realising that the passenger "line" system is very close to real life (I work with real rail companies helping them get more efficient). The vision of the developer is more passenger oriented than all previous similar games.- The train sets graphics are beautiful!When you take a time out from tycooning, and use the "follow the train" view, the sights and sounds are pure joy. - I did manage to create a mega station, which although wasnt OTTD-like in terms of scale, was actually equally or even more satisfying when completed!Icing on the already delicious cake: USA DLC - 10 hours into it, and its fantastic.So, my reommendation: if you've bought the game and its rusting away in your steam lib, get it out and give it a shot!!if you havent bought it yet, go get it now!!

												Currently it's hard to recommend this game. While I have been having some fun with it, it also has some very irritating bugs and shortcomings. It's not always easy to get tracks right, you have to build it in short sections, and there is no way to design a track without actually paying for it. I've lost millions of in-game money by placing a track, only to find out at the last moment that something is unable to align.I finally did manage to get a map working and see some nice action, only to notice the game performance collapsing in on itself. We've been discussing this issue a lot on the official forums, but until the developers fix it, i can't really give this game a recommendation to anyone else. When you got a lot of track on a big map and a lot of vehicles, the frame rate simply tumbles and at the end of every in-game month, while the game does some calculations, it will simply freeze for up to 30s. Enjoyable for shorter sessions, but in the long run the issues take the fun out of it.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												I see a number of people saying this doesn't work on an iMac. Well I bought it today (Sunday 21 Sep 14) and it installed and worked perfectly. In case anyone missed it, this title requires that permissions be granted via the System Prefs. On Mavericks go to Security & Privacy and then choose Accessability. Click the padlock in the lower left corner of the window and type in your admin password. That should case the options to becaome available. Scroll the list of apps down until you find Steam and activate the check box next to it. Close the window and restart Steam. You should now be able to get Train Fever to work. It does also appear to be a 64bit app if that makes any difference to anyone with issues around getting it to work.The game itself is pretty good. Ifound the thing a bit jumpy when zooming the map out until I adjusted the Shadows option to low. Having said that I also noted that it was a function of detail that cased the stuttering and that all the time you work at realtively close quarters to the ground you can actually have everything set to high including the Shadows option.It seems fairly straightforward to operate and I recognised a lot of how it worked from having played Railway Tycoon in my shady past. Would I reccomend it? Yes I think I would. I can see that anyone looking for a  detailed rail sim with mega amounts of choices on a Mac would probably be happier with Trains, but having said that I still think you would probably find this plenty enjoyable too. All in all a good buy.Hope this helps some of you having troubles with this title out there in Steam land.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												If you are a transport sim fan and you can't put up with the graphics of '90's legendary games any more, this is your game. It may need some more work to match the legends in terms of gameplay, but the platform is very promising. The company behind it seems to be keen in improving it and they also seem to be encouraging modders to contribute content. Pros:   good large random maps decent 3D graphics  dynamic cities expansion good passenger simulation and most importantly, it's the only trasport sim of our day (to my knowledge at least) supporting passenger+freight. Hence, our only hope.Cons: freight aspect needs some help could be smoother performance-wise UI could be prettier and easier to use a campaign mode would make it more attractive for non-hardcore trasportation sim fansTo sum it up, if you are a fan of the genre, you need to check this out eventually. I wouldn't blame you if decide to wait a couple of updates first though.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												I play this game since Beta and it is getting better and better. The developers listen to the community and already implemented a lot of wishes. If you played OTTD you should know, that this game is different in some aspects:- The industry chains are smaller but production does not increase/decrease at random and it matters where you deliver the goods because cities will only accept a certain amount.- The scale of the game is different, you won't have a station with 10 tracks in each town in this game unless you are crazy.  It is not like OTTD where you build 20 trains for one line, it focusses more on longer lines between cities. That said, you will most likely have less networks and less complex setups for station entrances and rail crossings because it is not so easy to build such things.- The terrain in this game really matters. In OTTD you can just terraform everything at some point and tracks can just go up the hill anywhere. Here it matters where you lay your tracks and you have to plan according to the contour lines.If you can live with that, you get a really good game with:- Great graphics- Already great mods (see trainfever.net)- Simulated people and goods- Simulated town growth- Great mapsSo what issues do I have with the game:- If you build a lot of stuff, it takes time to autosave and sometimes the simulation slows down- Balancing of some trains and cars needs some work, TFV for example won't reach 300 km/h on most tracks because of weak acceleration (they changed the TFV but I couldn't test it since the changes)- Trains sometimes drive one after another because of long boarding times. This affects profit and line frequency (this has now been fixed)-------------------------Addition now that the US DLC is out:Some of my concerns have been adressed:- Performance of the game is better, still a slight slowdown when autosave (but you can now choose how often the autosave is done)- Balancing is still not perfect but TFV is fixed- Boarding times are less of an issueThe US DLC works fine, I didn't see all the models yet. But there even seem to be options to enable all vehicles (Europe and US) and just play on a Europe or US map, which is great. I don't know if the balancing of the US vehicles is good because I am still in 1870.There are still some old bugs in the game but nothing game-breaking, mostly visual little annoying things like missing tunnel portals.I tested some mods and there are awesome vehicles available. Unfortunately the old mods are broken but there is already a solution out (the community has a mod manager which will do all the work for you). If you do some research it is easy to find new vehicles or balance mods and add them to the game. With the new ingame tools you should then be able to really customize your experience, which is great!

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
After 150 hours of playing time I must admit that I deeply love this game.It is amazing that it took so long for a new game in the railroad transportation genre to appear after all the successes with Transport Tycoon, Locomotion, Cities in Motion, or even 3DTT / Schiene und Strasse. With Train Fever today we finaly do have a worthy successor!I had the fortunate opportunity to be one of the beta testers of Train Fever,so I may have seen a big portion of the progress this game took from the first more or less playable version up until the release. I am happy that all important points and rough edges that I pointed out during the beta were OK in the end when the game was released. But the guys from Urban Games did not stop there, they did from release and still keep continuing development to make the game even better. Until this very day there have been maybe 5 to 10 patches after the release, each adding much sought after updates to the game engine, added features, new rolling stock, and improved usability.This leads me to say that the game is now in a very polished, playable and truly enjoyable state.Honestly, I would not have said so at the release, I think the game was released a bit too early for its state. But now, after all those fixes, There is not a single point left of those that kept me frustrating in the beginning. From my personal experience, I think it's very rare to see such a progress, as today most games are released and then abandoned by the studio, as they are mostly working on the next game already. But Urban games did not go this shady path.The fact that Train Fever was designed with deep mod support in mindfrom the first day of development makes the game even more exciting for me. There are a couple of mods that I really enjoy playing with. Most of them are additions to rolling stock, but for example there is also one that installs a much more complicated and challenging industry chain. In case you are german speaking, don't forget to look at one of the largest community portals of the game: http://www.train-fever.net/All this together with the quite low price they are selling Train Fever on Steamlead to my final conclusion: It really is a game worth playing. If you're into the genre I think it's an absolute must to own it! But even if you're new to the field or not so much into trains, trucks and transportation, I still think the beauty and realism with which Train Fever presents itself is worth to give it a try.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Train Fever is a game I enjoy but needs more work. I followed this game for a while before release and Urban Games seems pretty committed to making this a good game so I have confidence in them.So let's get the basics out of the way. On the one hand it's a pretty straight forward game. If you've played Cities in Motion or Tranportation Tycoon you won't be lost. The game looks pretty good even on my old computer and considering I'm using Vista it runs pretty smoothly.One of the first problems and it may seem like a small one is that you can't make tracks that crossover each other. You can make switches or bridges, but if I have two tracks (an up and down line) and I want it to cross over and merge with another set of tracks I can't do that. I have to make an additional set of switches. I imagine that will be implimented eventually but it really annoys me because from how I play in games like OpenTTD I usually have one or two main lines with branch lines feeding it.Another small thing that gets really annoying fast is that you can't build roads over track (unless you build a bridge). Again this will be a quick fix, but it will really started to make me mad when I was trying to upgrade my old lines to high speed tracks.One thing is that trains are supposed to dynamically spread themselves out they don't stack up on each other, but it seems it has somes bugs. At first it worked fine, but as I got into the late game the system seems to break down so I'd always have three or more trains at one end of a three station line and the other had nothing. I actually watched this for a little bit to figure out why and I think what happens is that when you get into the late game and have trains with a 100+ passengers that it creates  bottleneck with all those people loading and unloading.I'm not convinced that cargo is really flushed out. I struggle to make cargo lines to make any kind of profit and really by the 20th century it's better to use trucks.I think the building of roads and tracks needs work. Sometimes it's a crapshoot on what will work and what doesn't.Still these all strike me as problems that are easy to fix and probably the devs are on it already. Train Fever seems like a pretty solid base to expand upon and Urban Games seems to have big plans and if an active modding community can get off the ground I see great things for the game. This game is really for people who really love transport tycoon games.Edit: Well turns out the devs have fixed the problems in a way... they're releasing a sequel. Honestly I'm most excited about the ways they've improved track building and that you can laid road directly over track than the addition of ships and planes.I'm reserving judgement on Transport Fever until I can see some let's plays and see the game play in action but it does look like they'll fix most of my problems. Still no multiplayer but maybe the third game will include that.

number of helpful: 20 of 33 people (61%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												Looking really forward to Transport Fever, i decided to pick this up to get a bit of a taste.After a number of extremely frustrating hours, i have given up. I cant take this mess any longer. Being a huge fan of games such as TTD, Railrood Tycoon, Simutrans and the likes, i figured i should give this a shot. Unfortunately, all i ran into was frustration and subsequently, dissapointment.The basic idea of the game is simple: Starting from the 1850's until the modern era, you have to connect towns with one another, provide transport inbetween and the production of goods towards the cities. Growth of these cities is impacted by how much goods they process and transport capabilities. Unfortunately, it does neither very well. Whereas previous games of this genre have had a lot more possibilites for transport, you're limited only to trains, trucks and the odd tram system. While this wouldn't necessarily be problematic if it were well fleshed out, you're stuck with limited options and vehicle options. Often at times, you're only making a trade-off between 2 different vehicles or simply just picking the most modern one you've got - and there's no differentiating passenger needs either. Goods are divided between ore, coal, wood and oil - with only 3 different production lines. To be blunt, it's extremely basic.But even if that were functional, i'd still not be all too negative about it. The game itself suffers horribly from bugs. Thankfully, i haven't had a crash-to-desktop thus far, but that's all there's to be said. Sometimes, factories or other locations producing goods are simply not making any resources, with absolutely no explanation whatsoever. I looked up on the forums and guides if there was any explanation, but all i found was 'yeah, it's a bug'. Nobody can tell. Roads (and especially rails) are annoying due to the fact they don't connect well with high ground - even though it should be possible anyway - making for an extremely frustrating experience to actually get a connected line - and god forbid you're going to want to electrify your roads/rails, because it's torture to get that right, you're often better off just demolishing them as a whole and re-electrifying existing lines.In-game speed options are limited to only 4x speed, so if you want to pass the time a bit, i often alt-tabbed and browsed the internet a bit before jumping in 20 minutes later. Why there's no ingame high-speed option, i have no idea. Overall, its only redeeming quality comes from the somewhat pleasing aesthetics. Cities grow exponentially, depending on their use of transport and supplied goods, which is quite satisfying. The game's also highly moddable, and there are plenty of assets and mods to be found online. But to be honest, that's all there's to be said about it.I'm still looking forward to Transport Fever anyhow, but i'll be very skeptical. Train Fever is a mess. I hope they'll do it right.
