content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												This game is an intelligent and modern implementation of the railroad tycoon genre. I love it! The small development team has put a lot of work and love into details and created an impressing simulation that is also beautiful (except the user interface). - Procedural generation of large landscapes and growth of cities is stunningly implemented and very intelligent - this helps to creates unique cities and worlds with different challenges.- Track-laying is very realistic (wow, really what I was dreaming for in RRT 3 etc with costs depending on degree of terrain modification).- Beautiful graphics of engines (buses) and towns.- Challenging simulation - neat combination of in-city and intra-city transportation of passengers.- Nice timeline with great European locomotives.The focus is really on moving people around which is really enjoyable and the fun challenge to keep the economy running - I wish developers would not have listened to the community and rather would have entirely omitted the freight side of the game (to sell this feature separately later as a DLC!). I also find that the game's procedural world could have benefited from more variation, both geographically and temporally - there are no seasonal effects, and independent on height, the terrain texture is boring green lawn. I think they could have done much by simply changing textures with height (from green pastures to alpine rock desert) and over the course of a year (vegetation and texture change) - just to make epic playing over hours more immersive and entertaining.Overall I recommend this game - finally an intelligent, modern implementation of the classic genre after all the Sim City disasters (Cities in Motion being an exception).

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Train Fever is rough around the edges but there’s a solid foundation there that just needs a bit of refinement. This is a game that could have benefited from an Early Access period though not necessarily a very long one.The foundation of any transport game is the cargo modelling. If you’ve played Transport Tycoon there’ll be an adjustment period as in Train Fever industries “order” goods rather than accept them. In Transport Tycoon you can happily take iron ore to a steel mill all day long and make a tidy profit. In Train Fever that iron ore will only appear if there is a demand for it – the steel mill has to see demand for its end product in order to want to pay for iron ore and coal. No demand means no cargo to transport. Instead of setting up a transport route, you have to set up the entire chain. It’s an interesting mechanic but unfortunately it’s a bit finicky and it can be hard to figure out why an industry is not producing anything after the millions you have invested in a shiny transport network.Passenger transportation works differently too, as individual people and their journeys are simulated. People will walk from their residences to their destination if no transport route exists. If your service comes to their stop often enough (represented as Frequency in the game) then they may choose to ride your buses and trains. Conversely, if they can get there quicker by walking then they’ll do that. That means that whenever you set up a new route there is a higher expense because you have to supply enough vehicles so that the Frequency on the route is low enough for people to take it – another adjustment for those of us used to building a line with a single train set to full load and then letting it do its thing.Construction is seamless and mostly intuitive, which is lucky because the tutorial in the game isn’t particularly fleshed out. You can drag out new sections of road or rail, and rail will show you the maximum speed trains will be able to reach on the new section (based on gradient and the radius of the curve). You can tweak the height of the endpoint and drag it around to a new location until you’re happy and then confirm the construction. Unfortunately tracks can only cross each other without a bridge, which makes diverging routes harder to build than they should be once you have double track covering the map. The game will give you a message if you can’t build track in the way you want, but on occasion there’ll be no explanation, just no “confirm” box. This tends to be only a small annoyance, and most of the time building new tracks is enjoyable.Outside of the construction interface the user interface has a clean look. The highlight is the line manager where you can also manage your vehicles, easily sending all vehicles assigned to a line to their nearest depot and even having them automatically sold when it’s time to replace them. It can get a little unwieldy as you start managing more lines but the devs have thought of this with a “visible only” feature which filters out lines not currently on the screen. Depots make it very easy to buy vehicles and then add them all to the same line. There doesn’t appear to be a way to resize windows and the font can be hard to read sometimes – a UI scaling feature would be nice. A word of warning: the game seemingly has no keyboard shortcuts at all and so relies entirely on the mouse which can be fatiguing.Line management is intuitive as well – create a line, hit “add station” and click away on the stations in order. The game will calculate a path for vehicles to take, and vehicles will automatically space themselves out along the route. The more vehicles (or the faster the vehicles), the higher the frequency. Pathing works very well for road vehicles, but with trains it’s another matter. Currently train lines choose a specific platform to use at a station, and trains will usually wait until that platform is free before pulling in, even if your station has other empty platforms they could use. I’ve even had a train sit waiting for the specific platform so long that the next train on the line was queued behind it; the second train picked the empty platform instead with seemingly no rhyme or reason. I’ve started building platforms based on the number of lines that will be serving the station as opposed to the number of trains I expect to service the line, which is annoying.The game’s graphics are great as can be seen in the screenshots and videos and sounds are good throughout. Admiral James T. has done an incredible job with the soundtrack, with tracks which sound like tributes to themes from Transport Tycoon and even one which may be a nod to Theme Hospital. After about 9 hours of play I’m still enjoying the music and smiling when I recognise one of the tribute songs.Even with the rough edges however I’d recommend this game to anyone who enjoys transport simulations or trains. You’ll have to take some time to figure out the new mechanics and on occasion you will be frustrated by the mostly minor issues. If you can move on from those there is an enjoyable game here.This review was written after playing Build 4221.

number of helpful: 22 of 37 people (59%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												This game always felt like a very expensive Beta.   And it is. It's a 40 dollar beta.  It is unsettling knowing that the devs can essentially take the money and run at any point.   Though, they've stuck with it so far.So...why shouldn't you get this game?As stated, it's simply not finished.   This is hearlding to be the next Transport Tycoon/Locomotion.   And it's just not that.   Want to electrify all your rails?   Click every individual section,  miss one and your train wont run.  Don't know what section you missed?  Good luck finding it.  Want to built a road across your rails?  Too bad.  Demolish the rails and build the road first,  then you can fiddle around.The building system is beyond fickle,  though in honesty,  it has been improving.   It's still awful.   You will spend more time cursing it out and trying to get a simple little bit just to work.  It needs a lot of workNatrually,  there is no true build mode,   so any minor change that doesn't work will be bulldozed out of your own poked, paid to be laid again, and bulldozed when that doesn't work.  Early on, if you make even a slight error building your track,  you can break the bank.Likewise,  making a profit is not very difficult...but it's also not very intuitive.    Industry chains are short and pathetic.  They are rarely profitable, unless you manage to hook up differnt industries on one line,  and you're better off using Trucks most the time.Oddly enough, Intercity busses are perferred later in game over trains as well.   With roads being much easier to manipulate and control,  trains really just become a novelty.There is water in game,  however it serves no purpose other than to build bridges that don't like being built.   It's a shame because the water actually looks lovely,  and forms into huge lakes, rivers and streams.   It just begs for water transit.  The starting year is 1850,  Paddle driven ships were in full swing,  and hadn't fully replaced sail yet.   Maps are more than large enough. So yes, this is a positive.  They can be downrigt massive.  Archipeligo, and more water based maps would be completely doable.  Along the lines of huge maps,  unlike in Transit Tycoon, or Locomotion,  these are actually big enoug that airplanes would really make sense.    Unfortunatly, there are no airplanes.  Optimization is ok.  It chugs later on as cities grow.  But this too has been improving.  It also still needs work,Variation is low.      It's a solid start of mechanics...but there needs to be a lot of refinement,  a lot of additional content,  and♥♥♥♥♥ I dont' even care if ships, aircraft, are additional cost DLC,  that's fine. I understand these people need money to make their game,  but 40 USD is simply too much for such an incomplete game.  EDITYou will have fun with this game.  It is pretty,  trains do run once you -eventually- get the tracks down.  Profits can be had, the whole 9 yards.  You won't,  however,  have 40 dollars worth of fun with it.   It seems that not hours after this review went up,  the devs announced a North American DLC.   So,  variation in theory should be helped,  but the flaws of construction,  limited industry,  water transit, and aircraft still remain.    END EDITEDIT 2 - USA DLC released-Okay so we now have the American DLC.   It was free so if you haven't bought this game yet,   well, still don't buy it.   It doesn't really "Fix" any of the issues. If anything it makes the game much harder in the early era due to how the US stuff is balanced.  You still can't do basic things like buiding a rail road crossing with a road. (you have to built it with a rails overtop of roads),   building tunnels or bridges in a tight space is still a pain,  industry chains are the same,  etc, Nothing was fixed,  just content.  Vehicle content.  I hate being so negative about it,  but come on!  If there's one good thing to say about this,  it's that the DLC was made with help from the modding community.  That in it's own right is a seed of hope.  Hope that they get more and more help from modders and actually fix/add all the things this game needs to be good.If you see it on sale for cheap,  I'd say pick it up now, but it's still not worth the full price they're charging, so overall recommendation is "no"-END EDIT 2-A final note, The modding community is quite nice,  but unless you know german or russian.....well...hard to read.   The potential is there,  but  it needs a bit more realization on the dev's end before getting there.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												I think it's a good game.You can build passenger and cargo lines (with trains, bus, streetcars, trucks...) and connect the towns and industries to each other, which is fun.  The simulation is very solid. Every inhabitant has a persistent home, work, a recreational area and a preferred shop where he or she likes to go. Cities grow when they are connected to other cities via your transportation network or get goods delivered.The optical presentation is nice which makes it very satisfying to watch the networks come to life. The cities are very lovely done, except sometimes the surrounding lands feels a little bit monotonous. There aren't any premade maps, instead they are procedural generated.There are some rough edges at the moment, some are mentioning a bad performance. I had this problem at first, too. But simply lowering the graphic settings helped a lot. The biggest oversight in my opinion is that the developers somehow missed to provide a user guide and the tutorial is lacking. It doesn't explain all important things. Some people are simply lost and rely on user generated guides or youtube videos at the moment, which understandably frustrates them. So if you plan to play Train Fever I like to advise you to look at some guides and videos first. (Here is a very good interactive guide.[trainfeverguide.26miledrive.com])For instance there are things that work differently than in other transportation simulations or aren't very obvious: Stops don't have a coverage area, instead people are trying to reach their destination in under 20 minutes. For instance this can mean they are willing to walk 17 minutes to a bus stop, use the bus for 2 minutes and walk another minute (of course it's better the closer stops are). They won't use a transportation network if travel times are longer than 20 minutes or if they can reach it on their own faster (by foot or car).With freight it's similar. It's not possible to order freight, own can only provide lines and the  "business owner" decides whether to use your trains and trucks, to deliver freight on his own or to not produce at all. It needs to be delivered in under 20 minutes and the frequency and capacity of your vehicles determines how much will be delivered using your transportation network. What really stands out is the ability to mod the game, which will contribute immensely to the longevity of it. There are already mods available that add more vehicles or more industries and goods.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												Allright, the game came out this morning and i've literally been playing non stop.As a BIG fan of tycoon games, especially Chris Sawyer's TTD and the open source version, Words simply cannot describe my anticipation for this game.Train Fever is everything any tycoon fan could want, a game that feels like it was made by a A+ developer, funded by one of the big giants, but it's all made by a small indie studio, which makes it even more incredible than it already is. the tycoon genre has long had games that were good, but not great, and far, far too many games that were bad. But train fever stands out, it is truly an amazing game.The music is fantastic.It is tricky to learn and you don't easily get to a point where you are insanely rich and nothing stops youThe graphics, while they can be laggy at times, are stunning to look at. With good sound effects to follow, watching the trains moving along, while listening to the soundtrack is just great.Laying tracks is easy, but it can be tricky. However, like other parts of this game, once you learn it, you souldn't have problems. The game might not have a million features, and at times the wait untill you get a new train is long, but it's enjoyable. That's what is important, i really, really like this game. It isn't perfect, it's still a little rough around the edges, but i havn't had a single crash (although i encountered a few bugs).Overall, i can easily recommend this to any tycoon fan.In fact, if you are a tycoon fan, you simply must buy it.SHIRO-A RECOMMENDS THIS GAME!10/10!

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This game *is* Transport Tycoon but without a grid, and with prettier graphics. If you've never played Transport Tycoon, then this game is probably not for you.The good part about this game is - it's Transport Tycoon! You get to build road and rail, and buses, trains and whatnot. You start in the horse-and-carriage era and work your way up. Map and towns are generated and driven by supply and demand and it is up to you to decide what that means! For anyone who played the original TT, this is a blast. The depots, the newspapers, the lines! The game even includes our beloved train signals, which means that you can also compete with yourself in getting as close as you can 100% track utilization!The bad part about this game is - it's Transport Tycoon. Transport Tycoon was relased in '95 and that means that we have gotten quite far since. When playing this game, it really hits you how things have changed. The general UI design is: 1) Open a window for everything, and 2) Provide very few hints. Want to know the coverage area of a bus stop? Well, you can't. Want to replace your fleet of 100+ vehicles with an identical replacement once they reach a certain age? Well, you can't. Want to understand why the iron ore mine that has a production capacity of 25 only outputs 1 item a year? Well, too bad, but you can't.Furthermore, the game is a sandbox, offering no AI enemies and no multiplayer. While everything is freshly generated every time you start a new game, I'd probably say it's repeatable rather than replayable.The steam community is right in giving this a 'Mixed' grade right now. Me, I am going to go ahead and click recommend, because it's Tranport Tycoon, you know?

Posted: September 26, 2014
												UPDATED REVIEW!!!!!I have almost 1000 hours of play time so I will now take the time to edit my review....If I had waited a week after launch before buying this game, I probably would not have purchased. All the beta tester reviews were positive but this game still needs a lot of work. As far as I'm concerned its still in beta.*edit* The above is still somewhat true and let me add that I get the vibe that the game developers are relying too much on user created/mods to make the game complete.My biggest gripes with the game:1. Cargo trains don't make any money but cargo trucks do.*edit* Making money with cargo trains takes time but can be lucrative.2. Track laying can sometimes be a pain in the neck.*edit* This was understated; it really is a pain!3. The game needs some sort of manual to better explain things. Most of the help and guides I have seen are done by people whose first language wasn't English.4. Don't get me started on signals. I still do not fully understand how they really work so I haven't been using them, hence the need for a manual.*edit* Okay, I understand signals now but I still think the game needs a manual.5. The biggest gripe I have is that McAfee detects one of the Train Fever files as a virus and quarrantines it. Eveytime I want to play I have disable real time scanning and have Steam re-verify the file. I don't like the idea of having my computer vulnerable but I'm willing to risk it. When I'm done playing I'll turn real time scanning back on and once again it will detect the file as a virus and remove it. then I have to go through all the above steps again. *edit* This was fixed a while ago so no longer applies.I mean the game is fun, but you have patience and stick with it.  I don't want to not recommend the game but it doesn't seem right to recommend it (at this time) either.*edit* I hear a lot of people comparing this to OTTD. I never played that or the original but I have played RRT2, Sid Meier's Railroads, and Locomotion. This game can be better than all of them but still hasn't lived up to its potential.

												Just love it, almost about to crack 2 billion in the bank for 200 yrs of railing... on a small map mind, The large maps, once you have half a dozen industry's around too.. can get clunky, not to bad but enough to be anoying after a few hours. the last patch did help that for me.The track laying is very easy yet powerfull, I think of it like trainz on micro scale with industry's that just work...Glad to see some free DLC due ina  month or 2, as it seems very limited in choice of vehicles so far, but there is enough variety to make it enjoyable and get your old brain working.Some more tree's in the landscape would be nice, every map no matter what size comes across as pretty barren. Also it doesnt seem to randomize a new map that much different from what seems to be 'base' map. I fiddled for a while with starting new games and same map would show each time for quite a few times in a row before something slightly different would show. A larger variety of ground textures to randomize it up a bit more would help.Road networks can be a pain, you cant fix or upgrade rail crossings without ripping it all up then laying your road then hoping your rail line wont conflict. And now since last patch you cant disconnect a main highway without first bypassing it, this can make for some mucking about (And funds watsed) that just isnt needed. These sections should upgrade themselves as time goes on or find a way to upgrade them in a click.. In the next patch.I basicly start each game paused and go to my 3 or 4 major towns on the map and widen every road you can to 4 lanes instantly around the city and most importantly get 4 or 5 lines across the major in roads for your station sorted to 4 lane roads asap. save you alot of mucking about later.The road network side to it is also amazing and could of been a game in itself. Though it does need work, Very poor usage for bus's and trams means that you eventualy cut the service all together, I used to instantly lay tram lines for future use now i just dont bother, nice to look at but they dont get through traffic any easier than a bus does. The last patchreally did fix up the bottleneck issues to. Brownie points for that fix!All n all.. I'm loving it, its being patched regularly and works better each time, DLC soon and just endless gameplay at hand, Its easy to move around, easy to find your vehicles, upgrade them, or just watch there finances and adjust routes , Wyes and loops it seems all sorts of quirky lines can be built, Its a great that the trains will work to the grade to, ie: if its a big hill to climb and you dont have the power.. it wont go up very fast. The time clock for days and years seems to run to fast for my liking, That said, playing this on anything less than fast forward mode, can be very slooooooowGet it now while it $2026/12/14

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Played this game for a bit now, trying out all sorts of difficulties, settings and map varriants. in overall i would say that it most reminds me of the early days of Transport Tycoon(build, setting, trains -etc), with a mixture of Industry Giants(time line), and Cities in motions based line building and interacting system. the playing it self feel fine and good on higher difficulties the game can become quite challanging as well to make the most of your little company and set-up a profitable line system to not run to deep and debt and fail, although the 3mixture seems like a real good combo there are also down sides, such as the line system not being able to work out how switches interact on multible track stations. which severly limits your options in station building and useage of the stations, when you make a loop track with 2 lines going opposite of one another the game will still run both trains in the same direction which will lead to a full stop since the trains will meet and be stuck since non took a side track. The industry is really limited and seems to dislike trains for cargo, as i placed many times tracks + freight station next to a industry which will then refuse to use the station and line, and even when it uses it, it just does not want to increase in production nor upgrade to match the capacity of your trains on its side. that said, it will interact propperly with trucks(tried on mutlible time era's (1850's, 1900's, 1950's and ++)).that said in overall i would say the game can be very fun if your a true fan of the series like Cities in motion, Indrustry Giant, Transport Tycoon -etc. so far even before the patch the game ran really stable on my system and never resulted in crashed. big maps can take a while to load but are worth the wait in the end. the start no matter how you start(easy, medium or hard). is a challange, setting up wrong will make you fail and quickly run in debt which then leads to a restart of the game. The one thing that was quite annoying is to see that your passengers will just dissapear from the train/bus they sit in as it moves(had a train with 120passengers leaving the station, to arrive at its destination with just 105passengers).Pro's:- Big maps.- good city devolopment.- Infrastructure build option.- Line system.- loads of options in difficulties and optimizations of the lines/tracks/roads.- Easy interface.(though feels a bit empty).- Easy train/bus/truck build mode.- 3-D- MusicCon's:- Industry dis-likes trains.- Very limited Industry options.- The build system although good working seems to have troubles adjusting to slightly lower tracks then railroads, making it hard to build tunnels and overpasses easy.(eg. it wont suggest to make a tunnel or bridge if it cant make a on level overpass. but just keeps saying "Collision" when you then raise the terain for say a bridge overpass the road will collide with the raised height for the bridge)- Passengers will just vannish from your trains as they ride.- Trains/Busses dissapear as purchace options after a X amount of time, sometimes forcing you to buy a to expencive train to keep a line open.- City's seem to expand away from your station(at least in my games Xd).- Not easy to upgrade a train/bus/truck. said item needs to first go depot, trucks and busses need to be sold(very easy botton for that though), but upgrading a train, means sending it to station, open the train window + Depot window + Buy train window, Buy a train, remove the locomotive of the said train(sell or move). then place the new locomotive on the excisting train. re-assign its route and send it out again). It in overall is not a dissaster, just time and engery consuming if you get a big network with 50/60 locomotives that need to be replaced since they ran over their livetime span.In overall though despite the "flaws" that i have encountered i still love this game and will continue playing it with pleasure, some of my con's might just be from still getting used to the building of. for instance, though seeing somethings added(maybe as optional options(like TDD). where you can keep the old steam locomotives/carriages/trucks/busses -etc would be nice to see, as well as more industry, and no Anti-train mentenality on industry would be very nice as well.all in all i would still rate this gate with 8/10 cause i just love these games, and this games somewhat cleances my thrists after TDD :D

												Since its launch in September this game has received several patches which has really improved the gameplay. Apart from several bug fixes and performance improvements there has been new features and content. Such as auto-replacement, a much needed feature when you get 5+ lines, several new vehicles and more realistic un/loading.This game has now been polished to such an extent that I can recommend it. As a bonus there's also a free American DLC-package on the horizon.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Finally a transportation management simulation that has the potential to be a successor for games like OpenTTD or Locomotion! It needs quite some polishing though. The dialogs are rather ugly and it takes some time to get used to the track building mechanics. Trains, trucks and busses look great, but open cars (early game) lack a driver and seem to be driven by ghosts. Train signals don't visualize their state and all railroad crossings are unguarded.Despite these drawbacks, the game is really fun and the developers are working on improvements so I'm confident this game will become even better.

												Awesome little game, in the style of Sid Meier's Railroads! or Railroad Tycoon.  Starts off simple, but gets more challenging as the years roll on and the cities grow.  Nice graphics, really well modelled, and it's always fun to play with trains. :)  And buses and trams in this one!  Highly recommended if you like an economic simulation type game.  Fun!

Posted: September 10, 2014
												This game has alot of potential but can be alittle spazy when loading into maps. compaired to most simulation tycoon games this one has its own way of working. Unlike most transportation based games you cant force it to do what you want. Each enity (person and cargo) has a place it wants to go and you cant always force the entity to go where you want it to go, you need to work with the entity to speed ups its movementThere is already a few good mods showing up it is sure to be a good that will keep improving both with its own way of working and with the comunities helpPathing for trains and vehicles can also be a bit spazy and will sometimes forget where it should go but if you have your signaling right you will have very little issues. With the map you wont be able to jump right in, when you load into the map you will need yo pan around to load the map completly otherwise you will lock up and load slowly by doing that you will be able to run your game with very little hickups with loading.

												Ok, it's "early access" so it has a few issues. Like, the longer you play, the longer it takes to quit. Also it does crash now and again.But did I mention it's Sandbox? Now to the good stuff.This is a Transport Sim where you sit down to play for an hour, but when you stop it's seven hours later. The music helps, if you turn it down a little. Larger maps...?More buses/trams/trucks/trains...?Ability to see the finance report for all years.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												I now spent a nice amount of time with the game so I can voice my opinion about it.In many ways it is exactly what I needed, although it could sure use some improvements down the road.Good:- Nice graphics. If you're like me and still play openttd / RT3 etc. occasionally, this is pretty cool. I like the vehicles, it's quite nice work on those. It is not a console like 'detailed but cheesy' kind of Gfx, it is not the genre that requires that imo, it just has enough detail where it's needed, like vehicles and cities.- Interesting economic model. Once you get to understand it the demand based economy is quite simple. I like to follow people to see where they go sometimes, it helped me understand how things work. It's a good challenge to make cities grow, although this means you'll end up with some local lines going into loss, which is pretty realistic I guess.- For me it's a big plus that it works on Linux. I have been experimenting with living with a desktop Linux for the past few months and it helped a lot to get some nice games on it once in a while. :)- The modding possibilities look like it will help with replay value. I didn't try mods yet, didn't quite "finish" with the stock game yet but I am sure I will at some point. The challenge will just be to find the more finished, 'professional' mods.- The cargo moving model can be a bit confusing at first, but it's a nice all around model with the lines, frequencies, the rule that passengers look to find routes that are within 20 minutes of travel time. It challenges you to build more efficient networks so people can get far by combining the use of different vehicles.- Dev team seems pretty responsive. In a couple of weeks they released 2 patches that deal with stability issues and help those that have problems running the game in the first place. Although for me it worked out of the box in both Win7 and Ubuntu.The problems I have:- Building railroad tracks is very challenging at first, although it does get easier as you get used to it. A lot of 'collision' messages, sometimes feels a bit too restrictive but most of the time you can work them out.- Bridges - I did have a little problem building overpasses at first, you just have to learn that the game doesn't allow too steep slopes. Prepare to have enough room to raise a track so you can cross another, or a wide road.- Roads crossing railroad lines - at irst this was impossible until I learned that using M and N shortcuts you can raise or lower the middle of the road section you're building. This way I have succesfully built many roads over tracks which was helpful in extending cities around the railroad stations.- Terrain tool - it provides little information and I hate it, can't use it efficiently.- There are optimizations required, towards the year 2000 game becomes quite slow. Perhaps it is because so many people walk around and at that point they start using their cars to go around. Although dev team promised to look into it, it will probably require a few weeks to get the first patch or two that deals with these things.- For a game called Train Fever trains are very expensive to build and maintain so it always requires careful consideration.- Traffic jam issues late game. Here it helps to plan ahead and use trains for passanger traffic between cities but it's financially non trivial which was difficult at first and I sort of like it now that you need to think and plan a bit ahead so you don't commit financial suicide.Overall I think it's a nice game. I am glad someone released a game in the genre, always been a fan of these games. TF is good to go from the start, but a few patches will be welcome to iron out some issues. Mind you it's a very small company with a very low budget - raised 250k euros last year for the game, when you think of it some studios spend hundreds of millions. I think it's good to have these independent companies, with all the hit and miss, they sometimes bring a fresh perspective.ps. Some people seem to have issues with replacing vehicles - it's one of those tings I never had problems with, you can send and sell all vehicles from a line to depots with 1 button, and normally you do it once every 20-30 years, you buy new vehicles in the depot and then assign them to the line once for the whole batch. It's only a pain with trains which I don't use a lot since they're expensive to maintain.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												This is a very excellent game, I really enjoy it.  I love watching my empire sprawl across the map, never to be tamed.Unfortunately, there are a few gamebreaking issues.  The game is called Train Fever, though the best use of your resources is with trucks delivering cargo.  Busses are cool and work in conjunction with trains well, but they bring in very little profit, if done right.  Cargo trains can bring in loads of profit, but are unstable.  It is hard to balance the correct number of cars and how much the factory produces.  Long distance cargo runs are not profitable.  The train maintanane cost outweighs the profits, or the factory/factories will not produce enough to make a train worthwhile.  Often times, neither factory on the lin e will increase, even though both are getting all their goods shipped in a timely manner, resulting in profit loss as the train gets older and becomes obsolite.  Trucks work better, with very tiny maintanance costs, and can therefore better serve the cargo industry.Passanger trains are another matter.  Connecting 2 nearby cities with a single train works well and is very profitable early on, but this is train fever.  That means we want to see some trains running around.  So you improve your tracks, and have 4 cities connected in a loop.  Guess what?  Unless you get newer, faster trains, they aren't going to make a profit.  So now it's in the 1950s, and your loop is profitable.  So let's expand, shall we?Except passengers don't want to go, which doesn't make sense.  A distant, far off city is now accesible for a short train ride, but still no one does.  I have three train lines, one is a loop of four cities.  The other two use that same loop, but also add 2+ extra cities in a bigger loop.  The first line is the most profitable, because for some reason the simulated citizens DO NOT like to go very far.  Anyway, enough ranting.Other than that, the game is very fun, and I would definately recommend.  It could use some work, but I still play it and it makes me happy.Then there is always that dude who jumps off your train mid-transit.*I got this game on sale for $3 (90% off)

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												I have to say, this is a great tycoon game (It is not a simulation), because of the sounds of the locomotives, music is good to listen to.This game isn't too distant from another game I enjoy, called Open TTD, but there are stuff I'd like to mention that I'd like which are:Grid less terrain is a welcome change to what I'm used to. The 3D aspect of it makes you have to carefully choose where to put the lines, it also makes track and road laying realistic, including gradients.Contour lines makes it easier to dictate slope steepness and greatly assist in designing a railway.The procedural towns and cities are a welcome sight as it makes them fully dynamicThere are a couple of bad points that I'd like to mention though:The game needs a great deal of polishing and optimisation as it runs poorly on my PCConstructing railways I find, is difficult, you can't exactly plan the entire line in one go.For example: I'd like a feature where you can place and move multiple "sections" of track by moving their nodes, then placing stations and depots.The design of stations are limited, what I was thinking was having something like Terminal platforms.Also, I'd like to be able to choose where the building goes as the building dictates where the road joins onto it, then choose the location of the platforms seperately from it, possibly include bus station / stop facilities which are connected to the station instead of having it as an afterthought.What about the platforms themselves? The platforms don't have to be built straight, they aren't modular either, they also aren't built to a specific length.There's also no mention on how stations are upgraded if the trains get too long.Other then that...?Well, there is the lack of vehicle spacing in the game.There's the odd "feature" in the game, where you can load both cargo slots in a wagon, effectively making the said wagon carry twice as much compared to making it carry a single cargo (for example: an open wagon can carry 4 items of coal, as well as another 4 items of iron ore, together the wagon carries 8 items, where if you're hauling a single type of cargo, you carry a maximum of 4 items).I'd like to see this gone, you can only haul a total amount of cargo instead of a maximum for that particular type of cargo.Why are the loads measured in items? How do you define an "item" of cargo?For example: Goods, How do you define an item of goods? Size of the item? Weight of the item?Or perhaps a lump of coal? in which case, an open wagon carries 4 lumps of coal.Or perhaps more lucrative would be items of oil? a wagon can carry 10 items of oil?It doesn't really make much sense in those terms.I'd prefer terms we can relate to, such as the Cubic metre to define capacity of anything or metric tonne to define weight.Or perhaps represent it as a percentage rather then items... After all a percentage does make a lot more sense then that since it is expressed as a ratio compared to a figure.It would be nice to have a more in-depth tutorial about how to make services between cities and industries compared to how to make the said link between them.The "cargo display" doesn't really help all that much, it should show links between industries as either a straight line or a line along the roads compared to icons.I also find the cargo icons confusing as I can't distinguish what industries have the appropriate icon.You also can't connect just any two industries together, the industries "pair" themselves up with another industry which the link isn't easy to change, this problem is a type of game breaker for me.There also isn't that much pressure forcing you to actually have trains in the first place as it's perfectly fine having roads deliver loads along with trains, You could make an entire network formed up of trucks and buses if you wanted to and still come out with a profit, completely defeating the name of the game altogether.It's not the best transportation game out there (I still prefer the Transport Tycoon game play over train fever's), but it's a good to play every now and again.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												For those wanting a modern, 3D Open Transport Tycoon Deluxe, Train Fever isn't quite that, but it is close. If you have an open mind and enjoy the genre, you may like TF.TF has a much more basic gameplay, does things differently from OpenTTD, and has a few technical and gameplay issues, all of which can be disappointing initially if you expect it to play like OTTD. However, if you look past all that and give yourself time to learn how it works, you'll find it to be a solid game at its core with an awesome 3D world to build a transport empire on, without being constrained to a grid. Perhaps both the developers and the modding community will improve it over time, too.Edit (May 2015): And I was right, the devs have significantly improved TFs performance since writing this.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												IF YOU LOVE TRANSPORT TYCOON OR OPENTTD AS IT IS NOW CALLED, BUY NOW!For veterans of Transport Tycoon [deluxe]/ TTDPatch, and OPENTTD, this is a game you will have quite a time with, for quite a time!  For 20 years I've been holding out on one of the best Truck/Train shipping/logistics games, Transport Tycoon (also: now OPENTTD)... and now we have a 3d version.  Albeit it does not have all the fancy configurables that OPENTTD does, any fan should pick this up.The game engine is quite similar to CITIES XL, but without the glitches and other issues of XL, that is where any semblance to XL ends however.  This game is definately right in the same flavour of Transport Tycoon, so if you like that one, I can recommend giving this a try.  You might just become absorbed for the whole evening in it, unable to let go.  Quite challenging to make profitable train routes, though busses are pretty easy to work with in terms of turning a profit, one should start there.  A few bus lines up and running in a few different towns, then link them with trains.  Make sure your bus passengers get dropped off near the trainstations in each town, and you'll have a good train service in a few years time.  Remember, as in real life, people will want to use their cars more and more as an alternative to the logistics services you provide, especially as the years progress.  This coupled with the fact that every year equipment gets older, it costs more and more to maintain.  Keep this in mind if you're thinking about short-cutting your train route with a super-highway.  People will notice this and ridership will fall for your trains drasticly.  There is a mod to change the simulation's car max speed to encourage more folks to use your transportation, use that mod if you can't seem to turn a profit, but only as a last resort.  The challenge keeps this game fun through the years.  There isn't quite the hard falloff that TTD had, once you got to a certain point is was easy cruising without a care in the world.  Here, the challenge stays especially if you overlook things or become complacent.This game was quite rough when it first was released, but now with the patches, and the FREE USA DLC (via the DLC or STORE page for this game), there is so much more to offer, and a lot less bugs.This game can run for over 10 hours and not have crashing issues.Good patches last fall/winter and now the DLC update allowed me to update my review.  Train & Bus lines now working as intended, especially where they were problematic before when upgrading.  Loop routes work excellent, give them (and any train or bus line) a few years to mature fully + the grow with town growth, just like in Transport Tycoon.Landscaping/terraforming tools leave a bit to be desired, can take some time (this is no Simcity).  I can now build farther and longer than before with a section of rail without it failing to smooth terrain.  Before the patch it was mayhem trying to keep with the grade/slope.  You shouldn't have too many problems.  Building a road across double-railroad track is next to impossible, however, so you should lay roads before laying dual traintrack where and when possible.  It is possible to cross with bridges in most instances or tunnel under if you have the room, but this can be quite a test of patience at times and may prove a waste of time in certain respects.   On the flip side, since the patches the other month, building rail over road is much easier.  You shouldn't have too many instances where you cross roads in a manner that prevents you from laying track.  Try to build over the roads closer to a 90 degree angle to make things easier, even if it means making the track bend a bit.  Remember, running a successful business may be challenging, but it is also rewarding.  Very Very rewarding, mind you.  Staying on top of things, with all the effort it takes, really comes with a good sense of accomplishment.  You might really enjoy this one, it's turned out to be a diamond in the rough after the updates - it really shines brightly!  Would be nice to have bigger map size for those of us without lag issues, could build rail systems like they were meant to be.  I don't think the computer processing power/video processing power is quite there yet to be honest, for bigger maps.  Don't let this stop you.My only one complaint is being unable to lay road overtop double-raid track without knocking the track out first.  Sometimes also, the game may not let you remove certain roads if it feels the road is necessary to the simulation of people moving on their own.  You may have to fool around a bit building a bypass or two before it will let you remove the offending road if it's the only access between two towns or between a town and industry.  This is realistic, however, so who am I to judge negetively on this matter.Graphics are plenty good for a modern game, way better than 20 years-old gfx.  The USA DLC is really stunning, and is free, so definately a feather-in-the-cap for the developer, especially considering there are many (purposely) community-source models here (the developers actually enlisted the help of modders to package this all up and purpose it for something totally awesome for everyone to enjoy).  Moves like this are extremely respectable, as they really give the customers value for their money spent buying the original game. Sound is on par where it should be and music is better than many other city-builders, though it is typically the jazz/muzak kind of thing.  Fairly typical of the simulation genre.  It doesn't seem to get as annoying or bothersome as the music from Simcity 4 however.  If you liked Transport Tycoon's music back in the day, you'll most likely be okay with this.Sound effects are appropriate and expected, they do not dissapoint.Really is becoming an awesome game.  I followed this game development via youtube for a few years, and I am glad to see it finally mature into a stable, enjoyable product that without a doubt sucks me in for many hours, sometimes a whole night.  I can't say that about too many games.Don't let the mention of Cities XL push you away, XL is not near as fun, addicitive, and bug free as this game is.  This game is 64bit, and multi-processor compiled.  This will use every bit of gfx and cpu horsepower you can throw at it.  i5 or i7 strongly recommended to play on the largest maps without any significant lag.  To turn on all the bells and whistles graphically, you'll want atleast a radeon 7700/7800 series graphics card (R 260 or better!).  This will run on intel integrated gfx but again a good Radeon or Geforce video card would be recommended for the largest maps on the higher graphical settings.  Users with only 4gb of ram may wish to bump up their machines to 6gb to 8gb total system memory or more, as this game was using 3.5gb of ram on a large map, to help avoid hitching and lag that having only 4gb or less will give you.  Load times on a solid state drive are plenty fast so also no worries here.  If you use a small or medium map you may not need more than 4gb but see the system requirements for more detailed info.   Plenty of community mods are available, but with the recent update this past week, you'll want to make sure you clean out all your old mods, and update them to the new versions otherwise you'll have a bad time with things.  The game gives you an option to load/unload mods right from the menu screen and there are front-ends for this purpose also that work with the DLC.  Check the Steam Forums for more info on this, as it is posted.Do enjoy, if you loved TTD, you'll enjoy this quite a bit!  To the developers personally, thanks for finally giving us a game to give us our OPENTTD/TTD fix, as after 20 years +, I think it's time for an update to the old favorite.  Still love TTD though, as always will.This game is 100% non-violent, and child friendly, but also deep enough for adults.

Posted: September 11, 2014
												I feel that if you have played Transport Tycoon, Open TTD or Railroad Tycoon then this is the game for you. Personally I feel there is room for a bit more improvements like more train choices, pre-design track layouts (making a normal T junction can be a pain), more verity in what the towns look like and an improved tutorial. Thankfully though there are quite a few guides already online but you shouldn't have to look up to move freight. In the main though it is fun and the track laying is simple and easy to figure out. There is a lot of joy in making a working train line and seeing it become profitable.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Had this pre-ordered and finally had a dabble last night.First impression is that it has potential but very rough around the edges. Guess I need to start on easy mode on flat terrain but I found setting up a simple single track rail line between two towns used up pretty much all my starting capital. Very hard to get the track to match in some locations without a "too steep" or similar message. There's no "undo" button so demolishing track and starting over actually costs you money. Then there's only one train type to choose from (with horse and cart for road transport), the downside of having the game start in 1850 rather than (say) 1880.Also missing is any feature to "ride" or attach to your vehicles and follow them through the network.Will persevere but I don't think - at least on initial experience - that it's as good as TTDLX or its clones, or Railroad Tycoon (2 & 3). Will probably appeal to those who found A-Train 8 a bit too complex but overall at this stage I would rate it 6/10.

Posted: September 25, 2014
												I have not owned this game very long, but I have to say I am pleasantly surprised how enjoyable and easy it is to play.The game itself lends elements from various other franchises like the tycoon series, cities in motion and even Railroads (One I love). To start with it is set in the 1850's, but as you play you unlock more vehicles and as you go through the ages you will be able to start in the more modern era's for future games.The maps are a fantastic size, although I tend to play on Medium size at the moment with flat terrain, still getting used to the game personally. But setting up routes and laying tracks and roads is very simply.One thing the game lacks is time tables to allow you to set times for trains to use tracks in certain directions which would make building lines cheaper and a little more realistic with the real world, but it would also add more complexity which is why the developers may have left it out and this makes the game very simplistic to play for everyone.You can check out my You Tube series which I am starting at:https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL0VtYD7C_Qrc20H7R1uojceCgQEoDY6d2

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I've played this for nearly 24 hours.  I wanted to give it a good play before reviewing.  Let's just say I've had a lot of fun with this, to a disturbingly addictive level.Stuff I like:+ Nice big maps.  Bright colours but it adds to the charm+ Cities Grow+ You can watch a single person go to work and back on your network.+ Once you pull off a complicated track arrangement it is incredibly satisfying.+ The way cargo works makes sense to me.  You can't just deliver coal to a factory and presume you'll make money.  The factory has to have it's goods going somewhere too.+ You find all kinds or nice looking views and moments when touring your network, a track wrapping around a hill, or a large train emptying dozens of people at a station where a bus is waiting.There is a somewhat steep learning curve at the beginning, mainly because there is barely any manual and only a brief tutorial.  There are plenty of steam guides though so make sure you read them before playing.  A little tip for those just starting: Build your railway lines in smaller chunks, and avoid going directly up a hill.There are a bunch of weird little bugs, for example, you can build tracks over roads but not roads over tracks, which you have to work around, but it seems the developer is still working on things, and there are bug fixes on the way apparently.If you are coming from Transport Tycoon to this, be aware it doesn't do everything the same, in particular, trains only use one assigned platform at a station (devs also working on this).If you are thinking of buying this, don't be fooled into thinking this is not an intensive game on your system.  Double check your system specs before buying.Also, this game is mod friendly and there are already fan made mods available, including a largely expanded cargo network.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
~~AS OF APRIL 1, 2016~~     Train Fever offers some great gameplay and trasportation simulation that made me think, "Just one more delivery" then it's one hour later and the sun is about to come up. I was very hesitant at first when I was reading the reviews, then I watched a playthrough on YouTube and the urge to buy it was eating me up on every video I clicked, so I finally musterd up and bought it. I certainly don't regret it and the reviews that people are nagging about are relatable, but definitely tolerable. Of course it has it's flaws, and yes, it is lacking on other key features... Such as a world editor or even scenarios. This game has none! All you do is just build routes for trains, trucks, trams, and buses. Don't get me wrong, it is a fun game. The level of simulation and detail is very stunning when you get down to street level. The way the game tracks every citizen in every city, then those citizens have their own destinations such as, work, leisure, shopping, and home. You can either follow your tains, or follow someone's life. This is what really gives me a rich gaming experience is just how detailed it is. Although this game offers much playtime, after a while, you run into some obsatcles... After you unlock every vehicle, you run into a "what now" situation.. especially if you already connected every town and industry. You do have achievements to unlock, but those aren't exactly 'scenarios' per say. I really wish this game had some kind of opposing AI or scenario/campaign option and a world editor as well so you can make your own scenarios.   Some people call it a "tycoon" game, but it's honestly not. You don't "own" a company, and you don't "own" any industries. You literally just build lines for your vehicles and make/lose money. There is an economic model in the game, but it's basic. It's not like the Railroad Tycoon series kind of economy where it was rather advanced.   One of the most annoying things that take away from the experience is when you need to upgrade your bus stations/train stations. When your cities grow, more people will use your lines and time advances so you get really nice and new stations, but you first have to destroy the old ones. Oh, and if you have buildings really close, you'll have to destroy those too before you build your new one!, which can be very costly! The game gets real finicky when you try to make/change: bridges, stations, crossings, and tunnels so beware! The game engine is not fully optimized since it's custom made for this game. So, be aware of that after many in-game years your cities will become large. And as they grow, your game will start to suffer in FPS. It doesn't matter how beefy your PC is, it will struggle to keep your FPS above 30 if you have a city with 1,000 people. The devs need to implement an upgrade system for your stations where you click once and hit 'upgrade' instead of making it harder to bulldoze and stuff, but that was just me from playing Railroad Tycoon 3.The PROSthe simulationthe amount of detailgraphics are good, although some others would disagree, but it's not about the realism in this caselots of vehicles (trains, buses, trucks, trams...)towns grow into large cities which makes for an interesting gaming experienceFREE DLC (USA DLC)mod support, and built-in modsmoddable config files which goes to my previous bulletThe CONSlaying track/roads can be tedious at timesupgrading roads/stations can be difficultno tutorials, scenarios, or opposing AIyou can lay track over road, but not road over trackgame optimization isn't the best for late game (low fps) My Rating: 8/10A good gaming experience if you're willing to put up with the finicky crap.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												This game gave away all its potential and i'm sorry to say that, sucks in the long term.The key feature of the game - building tracks - is annoying and doesnt work properly like hell. If it works the way it should, it's totally hard to handle and not a useful tool. Given the fact, the devs advertised the game by pointing out the building tool, this is even more annoying.See, the trains ingame can't climb or decend steep slopes, which is perfectly allright, since this is the same in RL. This is why tracks often are build on a dam or an expensive tunnel is build. The thing ingame is that the building AI doesnt always build cost effective or with common sense. So you start building in small parts of the track just to find out, when coming to the end of the planned track (e.g. another station) you cannot connect it. Sometimes it's not even because of the terrain but because of nonsense like can't build a bridge, cant put a switch here and so on. It's so frustrating.There are various other reasons why the game is no fun, such as a very simple and monotone economy but the track building tool, which was highly advertised by the devs is the worst. I feel i'm playing an early access game. Other studios certainly wouldn't have sold that as a final.Hope this helped, deleting the game from my lib now.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												This review of mine is based on the latest version (build 5798). Train fever is unique in its gameplay. Each and every passenger and goods in the game have their own choice regarding their destination. Their choice is not fixed but depends upon your transport  network. Better a route, more chances of people travelling in that route.  They also may change vehicles in between their destinations.Its basically a Sandbox game and you are free to chose how you transport people (or goods). For example you might want to create 2 railway station in 2 cities to transport people. Alternatively you can build a railway station on outskirts and then transport people from various part of the city to the railway station from which they will be travel by train to another train station. Its all up to you. This freeform of gameplay is really addictive.Graphically the game looks awesome. Animations are superb and sound is quite nice. Specially the train sounds.The game also supports MODS, which means lots of user made suff is availableSINCE ITS RELEASE THE GAME HAS IMPROVED in terms of performance and user interface. However the downside of this games are:It still has performance issues specially on large mapsUser interface has issues There are very few industries in the game. However few mods are already availabe that increase varaiety.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												A game that is going to grow greatly, and has very helpful and supportive devs! So far my playtime with this game has been amazing, and I can't sum it up any better then that! But I will! The game excels greatly in being a fun loving Train focus Tycoon Business game. The mechanics are fun and simple to get the hang of once given the game time and to grow (in-game), so you see how things work. I have not played OpenTTD, which many that play Train Fever, are coming from / fans of. But I have played Banished, and Railroad Tycoon. Which are both what I would say Train Fever is if they had a baby IMHO! (Add oTTD, but I never played it :D so). Graphics and Sounds are amazing for the games custom built Engine. The details once zoomed in and watching your trains go, will look amazing to you! The sounds are also perfect and immerse right with the graphic detail. The music on the other hand. Its a huge hit & miss, you like it or don't. It's got some "special songs" that pay tribute to past games though ;)Now the flaws, as every great thing has one. It's still a tad fustrating at times for some things. Not as much for me, but more so from what I am reading closely from fans of OpenTTD. The things that work there for them, sometimes don't work here. For me, its a new experience, so I am learning and enjoying. The game offers few glitches and complications when comes to hilly terrain for track placement. Line Management is not solid completely for picking station platforms. Upgrading existing vehicles can be a pain if its not all at once (this is apparently fixed soon), along with Stations are not upgradable (being added shortly).Bottom line, a fantastic game that will grow strong with a already strong community! Oh did I mention Modding? Tons of it already! Why? Zee Germans LOVE Sim/Tycoons! So this game has a great Modding community already from Beta!Highly Suggested!

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Train Fever harkens back to the days of Locomotion and Transport Tycoon, where one was able to build a great transportation empire and accumulate millions or billions while watching a fascinating world grow and become more and more lively. The game world has varying degrees of difficulty and scale, allowing for beginners and veterans with machines varying from toasters to supercomputers to enjoy and play as they like. Pro's  Dynamic game world with a diverse terrain style and everexpanding population centers User friendly interface and game mechanics with simple construction tools Active modding community to be found at  www.train-fever.net [www.train-fever.net] Extremely beautiful environment and overall a good looking game Con's  Limited content due to constant developement post-release Still contains some bugs that need to be ironed out Lacking variety in transport options and freight typesOverall, I would rate Train Fever as a 7/10 as this game still has very high potential to grow and expand as the developers are very passionate and constantly work to improve it. If you are looking for a game that will suck you in and keep you engrossed on trying to figure out the best way to move people and goods around in the best way possible, while observing and enjoying a beautiful world, then Train Fever should be at the top of your wishlist. At the very least follow the game and its developement, watch some gameplay, and watch it grow into something better than its current state, because this game promises to be great among tycoon fans and casual gamers alike.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												If you like Railroad Tycoon then keep an eye on this title but as of right now (2014.09.06) many little things need fixing but the main points are.#1 Fleet management is a real pain to deal as your network expands. Developers please copy OpenTTD fleet management.#2 Track laying is more work then fun and its not helped by the constant complaints about "too steep", "can't do that", "can't do this", etc... want to connect a town at a hill? Do you self a favor and forget that town.   Give it year or two for the developers to iron out the flaws and I think it would be fun to play.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												The greatest thing of this game is developers continuously update and fix their game.When the game is just released, game is playable but feels unfinished. Huge lags when your population is large, somewhat lacking variety of vehicles, loading/unloading is unrealistically slow, vehicle replacement is awful, etc.But now lots of things have been changed. Performance is still needs to be worked but much better than before. Upcoming USA DLC (for free) adds much more variety of vehicles, loading/unloading problem is solved, Vehicle replacement/adjustment still needs to be enhanced but much better. There are still have some problems but devs are aware of them and would be fixed later.And excellent modability is also be good side of the game. A lot of things are modable and you can see modded vehicles, stations, structures, industries, etc. on fan communities. Overall, this is a good game. Unlike Cities XXL, it provides patches and updates (including multi-core support) properly with no charge. Unlike Simcity 2013, it provides excellent modability and no online-only BS. provided with much larger map and there is a plan for even larger map size support (not sure they could do that because of the performance issue). Unlike Cities in Motion 2, Dynamic growth is much better and properly worked if you provide good transportation network on your cities. city growth is the best thing among the transportation games I have played and even better than most city-building games in some aspects.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												So, you know, this is my first Review ever.I bought this game a week ago, date of this review is 05.02.2015.I have, at this time, 88h in the game, and i dont regret one single hour.This game, as it is, is a fresh feeling game for me. I tried a lot of games, i played a lot of games, and this game feels fresh and accesable to everyone from beginner to veteran.At this point, the game is very well playable and even after you know the drill of how to run your company, every game you start, feels different and gives you different options.In my Opinion this game is, atleast for the late game part, for people who got no problem with putting a lot of time into it to get that perect train connection, that perfect busline and so on.Of course, as it is with new games, it has some trouble to get through.For me, the most remarkable problem is the late game lag. I dont know if its just for me and my computer, but the Lag in the Late Game ( eg. Big Cities, lots of stuff going on ) gets annoying at time. There are some Bugs, but its nothing that would destroy your gaming experience, for example dont let you do certain things.I just want to note here, that the modding community does fantastic work and the devs are, at this point, working closely with the community and let them create stuff for the game, that they can then release in future updates and gives the devs more time, for vrious other improved.So, to sum it up, if you like a solid Tycoon game, that does nothing special, but what it does pretty decent, you like trains etc., you wont regret this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												Frustrating, steep learning curb, and with some controls that would irk even Mother Theresa, this game will bring you joy and hours of fun once you get the hang of it.For what it's trying to attemp, it's a great game. It's fun seeing your trains come in and out of your stations, seeing them make a profit, seeing your towns grow and expanding your network. If you enjoy sim games, you'll enjoy this one.BUT, and it's a big one, it's not an easy game! Have this clear as you make your first map (maybe even the second map), you will fail. The tutorial is mediocre at best. Go online and find tutorials to help you figure things out. Building bridges and tunels is frustrating. Almost makes you feel like you actually need an engineering degree for it. However, once you get the game's logic and figure things out, it will become easier and less infurating. More over, it will bring tons of satisfaction as you (finally) figured out how to build bridges and passes and see them allow your trains continue their routes and bring in profit. Seriously, once you get things working, you'll have so much fun, a few hours will just banish and you won't even notice. I already have 65 Hrs on this game in just a couple of weeks.Again, give it a chance. If it becomes too frustating or difficult to play, just look up tutorial online. IT IS NOT AN EASY GAME.

And besides there are rumors of DLC's to come. So in many terms is it like TD, but still not. :)

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I got this game during the Holiday Auction for a VERY good price (thank you devs!) and I have really enjoyed it. I have never played the original Transport Tycoon but I have played my share of OpenTTD as well as games like Cities In Motion. If you like those games, you'll like this. It's as simple as that. Imagine a game like OpenTTD with graphics better than Cities In Motion. I think the overall reviews give the wrong impression. The game needs more development but as it stands now you'll get hours of enjoyment from it if this is your kind of thing. If you've never played Transport Tycoon type games well then that's another matter. There isn't a lot of hand holding here. If you don't understand something you're going to have to look it up in the wiki. The price is going to be a deterrent to a lot of people as well. As the game stands now I think it's priced a little high and I wouldn't own it if it wasn't for the auction. It needs more content like more industry, planes and boats. Especially boats. But the devs have promised more content is coming and a free DLC was just announced. If you're on the fence about this game and you haven't played Transport Tycoon, I suggest downloading OpenTTD and see how you like that first. It's free.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Cautious recommendation. It's got trains in it so that's nice, but it has too many problems to be really great. Many people before me have mentioned how the terrain always screws you over while track building. Connecting rails in hilly areas is a chore, and the lack of an "Undo" button doesn't help. Building level crossings is a crapshoot, and building overpasses is even worse. It hardly ever works. The UI is a mess, with pop-up windows behind menu buttons, too many pop-up windows that open other pop-up windows that open other pop-up windows. Some drag'n'drop features here and some double clicks there could make a lot of stuff way more easy.That being said, it's got trains in it and that's nice. The creators obviously are enthusiasts and the game sometimes really gives you that model railroad feeling. If they continue to improve the game while adding new content, this could become the definite Transport Tycoon clone.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Let me say that many of the issues discussed in other reviews are likely to have been adressed with the various patches, though I will say that this game is well detailed and as such you should have a 1Gig graphics card and 3gb ram minimum.The maps go from small to large, and I generally find medium good, large can get excessive and small can get crampt once you've connected what you want to. The only negatives I have are as follows:> The stuttering at auto-save (which occurs at midnight December 31st) which can make you think the game has crashed> the lack of variety of vehicles. There's about 5 trucks in the game, and there really should be more. Likewise, there are only a small number (comparatively) of railway engines, despite the variety of real life examples available.> AI bugs out when altering tracks on a route, even if the route itself isn't broken (e.g. 2 track line reduced to one track temporarily)

To be honest, I only bought the game because it was on sale, and thought, well it's cheaper than usual so why not give it a shot. I can only speak for the USA DLC, because naturally I live in the US and would like to see the trains and other options that are more localized for me. However, with that being said, I have genuinely found this game to be enjoyable, and would recommend it to train enthusiasts or management tycoon players alike. If you are a mixture of both, then you get even more out of it. The only rough side in my opinion is that I found myself on my phone for extended periods of time when I was waiting for new trains or unlocks, and due to that, the cash just flowed in - now I doubt money will even be a problem and I am only in 1910. With that said, I still continue to be excited for the next technological advancement and am pleased with my purchase. I hope too see this game continue to be added too.
