number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2
												I have no idea why there are so many negative reviews. I think the game is excellent if only people paid enough attention to it. It might not be as complex as other games out there but then again there aren't any new games that offer the Transport Tycoon and Railroad Tycoon experience. The game is much closer to Railroad Tycoon 3 than Transport Tycoon, that's where transport Fever comes in. Fair enough if the game was a developing bench for Transport Fever but I actually see nothing wrong with that, besides if Transport Fever is so much more complex then I am happy I am getting trained on Train Fever beforehand. Industry is pretty basic and you don't get the stock exchange from Railroad, never like that anyhow.I have purchased the game on 80% off, so for me this is a massive bang for my buck. The graphics are great, the trains are great and in addition you get a few trams, buses and trucks to go alongside them.For anyone that loves transportation simulators and don't want to buy Transport Fever get Train Fever at a fraction of the cost and enjoy it, I have for so many hours. Th game comes with the USA vehicles and a few Mods.I shall give my words of wisdom for anyone looking to play the game. If you start the game at the earliest time, 1930 it will take around 20 years before you see any upgrades coming up. This gives you time to build-up your connections or you can start the game in 1950.TRAINS:When connecting town, try in the beginning to connect the closest town together. I have actually made a full circle of the map by connecting one town to the next as and when I could afford it, not by creating a full circle map and a train going from town to town which might have been better but also very costly unless you have infinite money. Then at the end I connected any leftover towns in the middle to one or two of the early connected towns. It is also a good idea if you can start placing train stations when you can afford, no need to connect them but have them placed so the towns grow around them. I have reached 2010 and I have only used the first platform length, doesn't seem to affect the trains even if longer.BUSES/TRAMS:To be honest I didn't have much luck with buses/trams, they seem to bring low income if at all, especially within the same city. I have had a few buses/trams connect two closer cities making a steady income but nothing to shout home about.If you use buses and trams make sure you upgrade all the roads used for your routes with BUS LANES. Even better if you can go for the wider 4 lanes roads as the first lane is kept for your vehicles (trucks, buses, trams) and the rest for traffic. This will help them getting stuck behind slow moving cars.TRUCKS:These little things brought me the mos profit early on. Check each city, see what their goods needs are, the more and unfulfilled requests the better. If the factory producing the good is in between two cities great, set up two different routes so it produces good for both cities. Easier to start with Wood or Oil as each factory only needs 1 resource, the Ore factory needs 2 (coal and iron) so more costly for you to run. Take a Saw Mill and Forest, pause the game, place a truck stop by the Forest, 2x truck stops by the Sawmill and truck stop in the City, try to get the stop near the Industrial area, when you switch on the colours and good lanes, bottom right hands side, the blue buildings. If the city demands 40 Goods then start with 4 trucks, 4 transporting wood, 4 transporting goods. I always started with 4 or 5 trucks even later in the game. This is why I have said to place 2 Truck Stops by the Factory, at one stop you drop the goods, at the other you pick up the goods, if you use the same stop for two lanes you can end up bottle necking as the trucks wait for goods produced.Same for a 2 resources factory, 5 trucks bringing 1st resource, 5 trucks bringing 2nd resource, 5 trucks taking goods to town. You can use the same stop for resources as the trucks will just come in drop resources and go, but good should have a separate stop as truck can queue up. Try to place them so the truck bringing the resources don't get stuck behind the ones waiting.ROADS/RAIL:This is where the game has a bit of a fail. There is no way to upgrade a road once a rail track has been placed on top of it. Make sure when you go over any roads with a rail track stop a few meters before the road then continue placing your tracks, stop a few meters after you pass the road and continue with your long track afterwards. That way when you want to upgrade the road, you can just delete that small section for the rail track passing over the road instead of a costly track running for miles, tracks with bridges or tunnels can cost you millions to lay down, too costly to delete just to upgrade one tiny piece of road which can bottleneck your trucks, buses or trams.Good thing is that you can upgrade your rail tracks once electric and high speed track become available without having to delete your old track. Same for the roads, as long as there is enough space for them and not going under rail track they can be upgraded.ALWAYS ALWAYS have your 4 lane roads with BUS LANES, as I mentioned before, your trucks, YES the TRUCKS, buses and trams will use those bus lanes but local traffic will not which means your trucks will fly by all other traffic and not get stuck behind slow moving cars. However, all your vehicles will use that 1st lane, be it bus lane or not, therefore they will get stuck behind the slowest going vehicle. Best to use separate roads if you intend to use vehicles with different speeds.INDUSTRY:I would imagine that later in the game you could start using trains to transport goods but I think trucks will still be better. They cost less than the trains in initial pay and maintenance, not to mention that a truck will leave as soon as it is full up but a train with 4 5 wagons will stay there until full slowing production down. If you have a train with 4 5+ wagons going back on forth between stations without maximum load what is the point.The industry is based on demand and supply, so if you stick 2 trucks of 10 cargo hold each on a route, both the resource supplied will be 20 production and the good produced. If you stick 5 trucks it will be 50... and so forth hence why a train is really not a great idea. Frankly speaking I could have 2 3 trucks doing my journey as they are fast enough to do full trips and handle a production of 200 but the industry will only see my 3 trucks assigned to the route so it will assume I can only deliver 30 goods/resources.Also avoid trying to supply one Factory with two of the same resources, let's say wood from two Forest to one Sawmill. On of the Forests will just stop production and you will lose money on it.If you supply multiple towns from 1 factory the goods production will go up and therefore the demand for resources will also go up so your forest will start producing more, just make sure you add 1 2 extra trucks.

												Much awaited railroad building game that i have been waiting for ever since the last RR Tycoon. Good graphics and a strong array of trains to choose from and not to mention the large landscapes on which one can make their own rail and transport network.a few quirks still exist such as the signalling system (which should only be one way and allow trains from the opposite direction to pass), the main roads fix (which doesnt allow you to upgrade the country roads) and probably a few more types of switches and track crossings which all exist in real life.a suggestion would be to have the player make his own platforms rather than using the preset layout in the game.edit:need more locomotives and wagons...not that there arent enough...but once you see the various mods...you wish they were available in game as well...yes it will mean a lot of work but i wish there were more types to play and experiment with. i dont want to be downloading mods all the time.ps:  an option to change the colour scheme of the trains and vehicles would be nice...just to add a bit of variety.

Posted: May 29, 2015
												this game bring me back to the old days of when i was MUCH younger and all i played was Chris Sawyer's Locomotion. in concept, this game is highly similar. You build routes, make money, and try to build a transportation empire for the ages. the main difference, and the thing i love, is that it feels like you have so much more control over what you are doing with your empire. the only real problem with this game is that it was put on full release way to early, as there were still many features to be added. But, the developer is stepping up, fixing bugs, adding features and actually listening to the community in what they want to see in the game and trying to make it happen. My big problem was the lack of x crossings for track, and they just announced it will be in the next patch, so after that i will probably be able to say with great confidence that i can put away the Locomotion disc and switch to this as my only transportation game!

Posted: February 6, 2016
												I was a little skeptical about this game initially, largely due to the seemingly "love it / hate it" nature of a lot of the reviews.  However, I was kinda "between" games, it was on sale at less than the price of a prepack sandwich, so I thought what the hell.  And you know what, I'm pretty glad I did.I'm not going to deny that it has its problems; the interface is a little awkward and clunky, the economy side of things can be pretty brutal sometimes and it will take a fair few hours to get your head around both of those issues before you really start to see the game shine, but when you do and it does, you'll find yourself up 'till 3am modifying your lines, checking their profits and hankering for that next locomotive upgrade.I would probably agree that it's not worth £20, but what is essentially a virtual train set with an economy that drives the incentive to make it bigger, it's definitely worth persevering with.

												Really wanting to like this game, I love the transport tycoon game....but sadly there has yet to be a game that comes close to that classic....this does not either.Graphics look great, but sadly there is little game play or any real purpose to the game.Management games like this need to give good feedback as to whether what you are doing is making any real difference and I feel that this information is missing or at best hidden.Then comes the performance of the game, often missing frames and freezing while selecting menu items...too much work being done in the GUI / event dispatcher thread perhaps? content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												A total surprise. I played for hours the first time I launched it. Really fantastic, fun train simulation -- with buses and trams to get goods around cities & to stations. Seems to be modeled after the original Railroad Tycoon (which is a good thing), it lets you build tracks and schedule trains, and actually has signalling, something which later RR Tycoon games "optimized" away. The early years have slow trains, and you have to patiently build up your company. Expand too fast and you'll go broke. The graphics are gorgeous, tons of detail, fast.Some aspects are a little rough, clearly parts of the UX were an afterthought, but these aren't critical to the game.

												This is a little gem that I loved from the start if you  know games like Railroad Tycoon and Transport Tycoon you will know exactly what kind of game this is. Big surprise this game is about building a transport empire linking cities together by rail or road trying to connect resources to factories which will process the resources to products you can transport to the cities and earn a profit or you could just focus on transporting passengers between cities by train,tram,bus or even horse carriage but of course transportation by horse is only in the beginning. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												This game started as a massive frustration to play. I played OpenTTD and Train Fever for the first time in the last two weeks, and having never played any transport management games before I was quite surprised to find the much older OpenTTD far superior..at first. My first impression of Train Fever was that it was in an alpha state with too many bugs and missing or poorly designed issues that could have been resolved with more time in development and testing. However I stuck at it and after a 5 or 10 hours of effort I became a little more familiar with the game's ethos and foibles, and am really enjoying it.Pros:+ Graphics are fairly good+ Frame rates ok but become slower the larger your network becomes+ Fills in a much needed gap in the train management genre+ Addictive management elements+ Large amount of very detailed models+ Vehicles slowly introduced in a historical manner as the years pass+ Demand must be met before supply can be achieved is good for realism+ The whole system you set up is interconnected in a realistic way, any problems in the demand/supply chain are of your own making. There is a wonderful 'butterfly effect' to your actions so you have to think carefully before you cancel your old routes/vehicles.Cons:- Cargo appears to 'walk' on its own which was annoying at first and initially made no sense why it would walk and ignored my routes. After a few hours it became evident what I was doing wrong and what the game mechanism trying to do, it became very useful in identifying what cargo was doing.- No good tutorials. This is a massive problem as you then have to spend a lot of time on the web searching for basic underlying game mechanisms. Compare this to Transport Tycoon where you have to do the same but at least with that game you end up finding useful information and climbing up the learning curve in an interesting way, whereas with Train Fever its more of a frustration.- Menus are a little cumbersome. Some features like the ESCAPE key just don't work to close individual menus, meaning you have to click DELETE to close ALL menus which is annoying.- Laying track and roads could be better.Neither here nor there:- Cannot demolish some roads without mods, but enabling mods to bypass them would kill steam achievements. Conversely I guess it adds realism to how you would lay track, but I feel the game needs to emphasise a little more that it wants to encourage you on the realism aspects - otherwise it just seems like the game logic is being weird. Again a tutorial would have solved this.In conclusion, the game is definitely worth buying if you like this genre, but be prepared to spend a few hours being frustrated at first climbing up that learning curve, it then becomes very enjoyable to play.When Transport Fever is released I suspect it will surpass this in every way, Transport Fever may still be worth playing if the price is dropped as otherwise just wait for Transport Fever. I recommend playing Train Fever however as you will appreciate Transport Fever even more!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I don't have any other train gaming/sim experience so my opinion is only off of this game and not how it compares to others. Also, I'll add some minor tips/spoilers at the bottom for new players. The game is fun and initially very challenging. The lack of tutorial information or quality "let's play" guides and videos left the learning/discovery pretty much to trial and error. But the process was fun and because it was challenging it caused me to want to do it more. One initial trial game on small/flat/easy allowed most of the advanced features to be figured out. And FYI to all new players the videos and forum posts on creating bus routes and cargo lines was all based on the AI prior to recent patches. My experience did not show those tutorials as being accurate and was a bigger source of frustration than anything in the game itself.The game is more difficult initially than most maybe, but as long as you like the city/world management types of games but on a transportation level you can spend some enjoyable hours on it.  The graphics are good and it is neat to follow your trains/vehicles around, especially across that bohemoth bridge you built just for the sake of doing it.Spoilers/Noob Tips:  • Build rails in small steps to avoid heavy $$ costs.   • Local bus routes are keys to developing a prosperous city, and may not be lucrative themselves.   • Big picture perspective is needed to get you through the long game.   • Not all resources are to be connected to a town or factory   • Most resources should NOT be connected via rail, early on anyway.    • Signals and waypoints are your friends, use them

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Train Fever is a railroad-focused business simulation game. In other words, it's a modern-day Transport Tycoon with procedural content and a sophisticated city simulation. 


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Train Fever' 

			Views: 82		

			LOVE MUSIC? - GRAB SOME GREAT MUSIC HERE: http://paradisedecay.bandcamp.com/ Massive Thanks to the Dev's for the review copy!		

"It’s the year 1850, and there are great times ahead! Establish a transport company and be its manager. Build infrastructure such as railways and stations, purchase transportation vehicles and manage lines. Fulfill the people’s needs and watch cities evolve dynamically. Train Fever runs on an engine specifically developed for this game. The engine has a great innovative scope and is specialized in procedural content and urban simulation. A key point is the fact that there is no grid that game objects have to be aligned to, allowing for a great degree of freedom. - Recommended!

												While the game showed a lot of promise when it was released it had lots of flaws and bugs. I played a couple hours but soon got annoyed. I.e. there was no option to automatically replace aged vehicles, building tracks was more than just challenging and the performance of the game was bad. Really bad. Still it was fun to a degree... so I gave it a rest and decided to wait until the game would be more polished.I recently gave it another try and I wasn't disappointed.The game has been massively improved since its release. Game performance is better - it is still resource hungry but hey, you shouldn't play games on a 10 year old rig...Lot's of small improvements to the building process, upgradeable tracks (you don't  have to rebuild your tracks to upgrade to high speed tracks), one can set up automatic replacement of aged vehicles, free DLC with American trains and vehicles. And the game is modable now which has started to spawn lots of interesting and fun mods.I can now recommend this game to any train enthusiast.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Train Fever AKA Stage Coach Fever. Because you will make your early money that way, building train lines is expensive!I got this during the $11.89 sale. Have played a bit but am making money.Went with a default map in USA dlc (free). started arround the middle where I could see resources and a factory near a town. Built a Stage coach route in the town with 7 stops. Also built goods stops right next to a coal and iron mine, plus one next to a steel factory. Built a new road direct to the town plus a stop on the edge for dropping off goods. Minimal number of vehicles to start as there is a delay while deman builds.When I built my stations built them on the outskirts of town so they would be away from any new houses that could appear. Linked them via my stage coach line so people pay me to go to the station. Built another stage line in the next town to funnel passengers between the stations.Working better than it did in Quill18's youtube play through last year. I like the cancel option when laying track and roads. Would like a warning symbol to indicate a tunnel will be built. Love that the track shows the speed limit as you lay track.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												I hesitated on buying this game because of the mixed reviews, but ultimately I'm glad that I bought it. It's not quite a Transport Tycoon replacement, but it's a step in the right direction, and there's still a lot of fun that can be had from the game. I don't think the price adequately reflects the value of the game, however, so if it's on sale or if the regular price falls to below $15, it's worth a try.A number of newer negative reviews point to how the developers plan to discontinue supporting the game in early 2016. While disappointing, the openness about the limitations of Train Fever (particularly in terms of being able to mod elements of the game) gives me hope that a sequel game would be built from the ground up to be modded.I enjoyed the game. Maybe not as much as I would have enjoyed a perfect, 3D recreation of Transport Tycoon, but I feel satisfied with my purchase. And hopefully the amount I feel that I overpaid for the title is working toward the development of the game I wanted to play. I remain optimistic.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												Not really a review as such; but I do wish to point out that this is a 'fun' train 'simulator'.  Sure there are problems with the coding that can bug the hell out of you - no pun intended... honestly!  And there are simulations (name withheld), that perhaps do a better job of 'simulating'.  But hey!   When you get one of those 1950 era electric locos pulling 5 carriages into a station.... oh sigh.... the graphics make up for it.  For the most part I don't mind the way you can/can't change terrain etc. it still looks good to me and works well 9 times out of 10.    I won't go into the 'little' details as enough has been said on those.  What I want to get across to people is it is a 'fun' game with really nice train 'pixels', yes I am using old terminology here but run with it.... I'm old - seriously do young people even 'get' trains? LOL.  And yes I know... using too many quotation marks.  Never played OpenTTD, suspect I'd probably quite enjoy it.   BUT, from the sound of things it is outdated graphics wise, which is why I am happy with  TF.  I like to just sit back and watch the loco pull the cargo up the hill towards the destination.    If there was one thing I'd really like to be implemented, it would be a loco POV.    Other than that, I'm really happy with the game - and yes, as many people have pointed out.... steep learning curve, but well worth it my friends.  AND.... if you are not happy with the vanilla... there are PLENTY of mods that can help with that.My first 'review'.  But in all honesty this game is a keeper.  I live in Oz, so I pay more for Steam games, and I'm still happy with the price tag.  If I were a Kiwi, I'd be whinging though; because it costs them twice as much in sheep  :-p

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												Having owned Train Fever since before Xmas, and played it long enough to earn a reasonable about of money, I have to say I'm finally disappointed. Firstly the time cycles are outrageously swift - it can take days, weeks, decades and months for vehicles to move around the map, and eons to increase product demand of the various services. But what has really broken the camel's back is the road and rail building mechanics. I've played many similar games, as I'm sure most people interested in the genre have, but laying a roads, rail and especially bridges or tunnels is way too fussy and time consuming. Add that to how quickly the time elapses, many years will have passed whilst you try to understand why portions of a bridge turn red when there's nothing noticeably obstructing it.  Finally, the costs to demolish buildings and road to make way for redevelopment are ridiculously priced. Hundreds of thousands to remove a small building is unrealistic and punishing if you're struggle to make money. All in all, the transport/city building genre is making serious comeback - Paradox seem to be leading the way with the likes of Cities In Motion, and I cannot wait to play their new title Cities: Skylines. Having watch footage of the latter, when it comes to the simplicity of building and redeveloping, it should be the least tasking portion of a game, and I'm afraid Train Fever has really understood this. I was really looking for to the game and the replayability factor. Since it's been a couple of months since I last tried TF, I had hoped my concerns would have been noticed and perhaps updates to improve the building mechanics - unfortunately the issues remain. I do hope this can be improved upon after this published my review. As things stands, there are better options than Train Fever.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I am sorry because I really had faith in this game but this game sucks and if I could, I would like to get my money back.Everything looks beautiful and the game really feels a bit like OpenTTD, but there are some huge issues which make this game nearly unplayable: - There is NO way of building railroad-crossings. You can not build a basic X with railroads. This makes much setups unbuildable - You can not build bridges over railroads (or at least I couldn't figure out how) - The game is a lagfest. R9 290X, 6 core AMD CPU and I get 20 FPS and amssive frame drops on medium quality - Sometimes the game tells you things like "Not possible - please build in two steps" or "switch construction failed" and you have to remove and rearrange parts of the track. This is so annoying. - There is no way of building multi-track-trainstations. The train chooses one fixed track and sticks to it. If I have a trainstation with two tracks and 3 lines using it, it might occur that one track is free but both lines are assigned to the occupied track so the incoming train is waiting, even if there would be a free track. - It is not possible to delete parts of tracks, only the whole track - Sometimes, for odd reasons building tracks is not possible, and you will have to split it up in parts, or remove/rebuild parts.This game is unfinished. Or at least it feels like it. It feels like really-early-access and I am not sure if they are still working on this and listening to the community. I hate paying money for unfinished games. This has sadly become a trend recently and I hate it.Fix this game, give it one more year of development and it might actually be playable.

Posted: July 14, 2016
												So much potential fell so short, I used to love railroad tycoon and although this is similar in concept its a really terrible game. The graphic assets look promising, but the game play has disappointed me in several respects. The Ai is awful and things eventually get clogged. Once you get to any level of complexity with sets of intersections and switches, the trains just do the stupidest things and even though your tracks make sense the trains get backed up behind each other instead of taking reasonable routes. The interface is awkward to use. You can't modify gameplay while in game. The rotations of the terrain via the mouse are counter-intuitive. The game constantly lurches every minute or so while it seems to do a mass calculation which constantly gives you a feeling of discontinuity. I'd love to take the assets from the game and build something that's actually fun to play. Train Fever just annoys me.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												As much as i would like to recommend this game, i can't. If it would be cheaper and in clear early access sale then it would be a great thing to go for. Unfortunately it is sold as a finished product and most of the time on full price. Game can offer you a decent amount of interest and even some challenge, but so many annoying features and even more so, missin features, are driving you nuts in the later game. Performance gets killed at later game and you may have to wait 10-15 seconds for the calculations to be completed at the end of each month. And since the month is less than a minute long, you get the idea what it is like... And during the month performance isn't that great either. Lot of graphical bugs, onlogically working build tool, not enough information, no X junctions on railways, no road over rail build etc. are seriously limiting the great fun factor. Selection of vehicles is poor in the main game and only with mods it will get interesting. Also the latest update introduced a feature which doesn't allow player to delete certain roads which game classifies as a main connection. So you can't fully do what you want to do, which is how this game actually was sold at the beginning... So, if you are looking for fun and Transport Tycoon or Railroad Tycoon kind of experience, keep on looking. If you want to be a part of the beta team and get constantly frustrated then join us unfortunates, who went and bought this game at its alpha stage.Edit 13.01.2015:


What the F....!

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												Very good thought, but very badly done. Graphic and models are nice, but build anything is really pain in the a**. It really ruins the game, because after several dozens of minutes you will end up in deep depression, because you find out that nice track you built is screwed up and you can't fix it, because game won't let you or don't undestand what you want to do. This bad design feature is even more screwed up by missing UNDO function, which means everything you make bad (rule here is 10 times bad, after that you maybe find the right combination) costs you in game money.For example, I wanted to replace track junction with single track (detach the branch). I couldn't remove only branch, I needed to remove whole junction and place new short track instead of that deleted junction. But what happened? Game says, I can't place track there because of bad terrain. How it is possible? There was juntion few seconds ago! But what that means for me? I can destroy whole track layout around the junction because I can't fix that missing piece of track. It really pi***d me off and I turned of the game!It's absolutely unbelievable, that train game is unable to make track crossing, bridge above the another track, or underpass under track. If you want to cross over another line, you need to join them with junction and than make another junction in another opposite direction. this means, it is impossible to cross two perpendicular tracks, because of limited curvature you need lot of space to make those tracks parallel and then turn it again to original direction.On top of this, bad optimization of this graphicly simple game causes stuttering and big FPS drops even on machine, which is able to run new titles on Ultra. And I can get 60 FPS only from top view. When I move angle to see far, it drops below 20 fps. I really don't get what calculation this game can do on background.Really, this game should be Early access and there is a lot of work to do. But it seems, devs are not interested to much polishing. But I think they rather work on Train Fever 2, that turning Train Fever into useable game.So to make a decision - this game has very big potencial, if will be continuously improved in future. But I am afraid, it will not. For now, you will be much more satisfied, if you will play OpenTTD for strategy, or Train Simulator for graphic.

number of helpful: 23 of 44 people (52%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												This game gets 5 out of 5 for most dissapointing purchase of the year. There is so much potential here to be a top of the line logistics/transport simulator. Yet I find myself crushed under the weight of the poor interface. I can put up with the fact that it takes many, many, many clicks just to place a short peice of road. Or the fact that laying track is the worst experience of my life. But what really grinds my gears is when I get a popup notification letting me know that my vehicle has reached it's life expectancy and should be replaced, and then when I click the notification, there is no option to replace it from the vehicle menu. Only to send it back to the depot where I have only one option, to sell it. Not a damned thing about replacing it. So now I have to sell it, and buy a new bus, and then select the line I want that bus to run. Instead of simply clicking "replace vehicle with".   Needless to say, managing more than 5-10 vehicles quickly becomes a nightmare.And there are not even simple features that add depth and personalization to the game such as naming your own company, or picking a logo, or at the very least a color!   Nope, your just some business without a name, connecting the world because you can. Also, I love it when sometimes the WASD keys, and somtimes the arrow keys stop working when I want to move around the map. Forcing me to mouse zoom in and out a couple times to "jog" the games memory a bit and let me use the keys again.I bought this on sale, and I'll remain hopeful that it improves. However this game has had many bad reviews from others before me and nothing seems to be improving. Don't buy this unless it's on sale, and even then, still don't buy this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5
												I conditionally recommend this game. Things to keep in mind when I say "conditionally":- I'll share my silliest gripe first: I'm pretty sure the trailer should say this is "digital heroin" not "heroine," but it doesn't look like the developer will ever re-create their trailers, so that cute typo stays with us for the ages.- On the topic of things never changing, Transport Fever has stolen its thunder, but that's to be expected when quasi-sequels emerge - it has been almost three years since this title came out, after all. This does mean you're going to live with the game's quirks without much in teh way of changes, so you'd best be getting this on a good sale!- There are persnickety background rules. Fail to deliver within 20 minute? Your passengers spontaneously disappear. If you can't accept this, don't read any further, go find a freeware copy of the original Railroad Tycoon instead.- The interface is the gaming equivalent of working with SAP or any other program with minimalist UI. You have to adapt to its quirks rather than vice versa. The developers, to their credit, finally added a dialogue to let you see your old saved game names so you can over-write a prior save if you like doing that sort of thing. I originally used 1-letter saved game names because there was no way of clicking and selecting your old saved games. This, plus finicky track laying mechanics, are prime examples of the challenges you used to, and still deal with, respecitvely.This review started off as a comment to the discussion boards asking whether this game had any life left in it. I started with the following anecdote: I hadn't touched Train Fever in 11 months, but the introduction of Transport Fever inspired me to go back to this game and a world I had paused on. It's still great fun, but a source of occasional massive frustration. I built a small junction of tracks which confused the heck out of the pathfinding - of course this led to all passengers abandoning my profitable mainline route because it appeared to not exist even though the trains still knew where to go! Absolutely bizarre - I realized I had a problem when my $30M cash stockpile began crashing to less than half that (I was distracted by other side projects connecting spurs).In the end I destroyed the buggy junction, rebuilt that chunk of mainline and re-created the entire route. This interface issue actually brought a bit of a challenge back to the game, as I had inadvertently created my own "rescue your company from your own sloppiness" scenario.Compared to the original Tycoon games I miss a bit of the challenge from fighting real competitors on the map as opposed to the imaginary cargo transport forces and the tyranny of the automobile stealing your customers, but all-in-all, it's still an addictive timesink. And the graphics are average to gorgeous depending on how you admire the world, so that's a plus too. Did I mention the free DLC adding North American vehicles makes it especialy awesome, given the number of Canadian transit vehicles? That's a big plus too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												I really liked Sid Meier's Railroads. When I discovered Train Fever and decided to buy it, I really hoped it would be a worthy successor, as Sid Meier's Railroads is pretty much an antique by today's standards. I've been editing this review quite a few times as I've been playing and learning the game, and after playing for around 25 hours, I believe I finally have a good enough perspective to give a thorough and fair review.The positive points:1) The game is, or at least *should be*, fun to play, if and when it works properly. Needless to say, I wouldn't have wasted 25 hours playing a game I didn't enjoy playing, so that fact speaks for itself.2) The vehicles look good, graphically. I can't judge for myself how accurate and realistic they look, but by reading other reviews and comments, I got the impression the developers did quite a good job about that. 3) The soundtrack is nice and fun to listen to while playing.The negative points:1) The performance is *really* bad. I have a decent PC. Nothing too fancy or cutting-edge, but enough to run most modern games smoothly on medium-high settings (Cities: Skylines, for one). Train Fever, on the other hand, barely works. It starts out okay, but as soon as the cities get a little larger than their starting size and there are over 30-40 vehicles moving, the game stutters constantly. I read somewhere that the main reason for that is that the game only uses one CPU core, as it doesn't support multi-core. All in all, the game seems not to use the hardware resources it has, which implies poor programming. 2) The interface is very uncomfortable, there are no tutorials or in-game beginner-friendly guides to help understand how the game works. The information screens are vague and confusing. You pretty much need to learn the basics by trial and error, which is quite frustrating, considering you also have to struggle with the lousy performance while at it. I work as an accountant and I deal with companies' financial reports on a daily basis, but even I have been having troubles figuring out the financial data the game gives me about my company. Totally counter-intuitive. Needless to say, I know practically nothing about engineering or anything related to trains, which seems like a serious disadvantage when playing such a game. I've managed to improve a bit in my track building skills, but I'm still pretty clueless about how the cargo industries work, and the little I do know - I had to learn from a guide I read online. The little information the game gives about that is so cryptic, that it made me wonder what the developers had in mind when they released the game in such a state.3) Not enough content. There are no AI competitors, no random events, no side-quests, missions or anything else to make the game more interesting. While the game could be interesting enough without all those things (if it worked properly), they would sure be an important addition. All in all, I only recommend this game to hard-core fans of the genre, and even then - I'd suggest waiting for it to go on sale. For anyone else, I'd suggest to pass on this game. Not worth it.===========EDIT (August 7, 2016):   While I stand by my analysis of the game, I decided I've been enjoying the game so much (as evident by my play-time counter, that has already passed the 100 hours mark), that it would be unfair on my part to leave the negative rating as it is, so I'm about to flip it to positive.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												If you like building things, watching trains move around a landscape like a virtual model railway then you will probably enjoy this game. Good graphics, gameplay, and ever changing cities keeps the game fresh and if you don't like the world you have created, then go get yourself another randomly created map.There are some aspects that can be tiresome, such as what has become for me the dreaded terrain collision when trying to build across existing items, and the 'must build bypass first' before deleting town connecting roads. There are some things that could be tweaked from an ease of use point of view, but they do not detract from the overall game.The game clearly benefits from being actively developed, and new features come along all the time, the recent free DLC that adds a USA style map for example.Edit: Recent updates, and a clearer understanding of the game mechanics has made the game even more enjoyable, the danger is that you lose yourself in it and lose track of time far too easily. At the current discounted price this is a must have for anyone that enjoys sims, if you are a "Tycoon" style game fan or otherwise.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Rule one - buy it ONLY on sale. Not worth 24,99€, all and all 4,99€ is about right.How would I describe this? If EA would make a tycoon game this would be it. Details are lovely but the cost... I would say the game is trying too hard even - yes you can check every single pedestrian who has an ID on him, know his job, home, relaxation and shopping habits. So you know where to transport him/her. You can also find the details of the locomotives, carriages, trams and buses are lovely and not just that the cities and cars too. Also the game never crashed on me (running windows 10 64 bit - respect!) Those would be pros.So what are the cons? No ships, aircraft, monorails, maglevs, subways, city management, AI, multiplayer. The construction of railways can be a real pain in the butt, endless collisions with terrain, improper angle for road crossings and no matter how much money I invested to a straight line across the map I could never get 300 km/h from the fastest train. And the game feels kind of limited in a sense. Why for example can´t I combine a tram and a train station into one ? Overall I realize that this game is from a new developer therfore I am not as critical, I believe (rather hope) new features will appear eventually. The game is fun for quite a while if you learn the basics and have a big enough map (reminds me can we have a map editor pretty please?). So if you want to support an indie game wait for a sale(!) and go for it. If you want to have similar amount of fun for free go to google and type in openttd.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Nice game with some limited touches. Having played Railroad Tycoon(RT), RT2 is my main playable (replayable) game of this type. RT3 and Railroads were poor implimentations of this type of operating/ management sim. Train Fever goes along way to redo this type of sim and the graphics are very good. Similiar feel to Cities in Motion(CiM) which I have over 1000 hours playing. The time is worth it and I would still play CiM if it had a slight improvement in CiM2 but it appears to have had a complete rewrite to the interface which has put me off.This game takes me back to RT2 but with the ability to build tunnels! It takes a little work getting how the interface works  but have now played 25 hours and am still learning some of the more advanced gameplay features. Do not be put off because the game is a joy graphics wise.What are my limited touches:Firstly, only 3 levels of difficulty (Easy, Medium and Hard) whereas in RT2 you could set your own level (if only a little) in the scenarios.Secondly, it looks like no scenarios are provided each new game builds a new map. I enjoyed playing the NE corridor and Mid west scenarios in RT2 so it's a bit of a shame that these maps do not appear available. (Note: I have not yet tried the USA(DLC) so this maybe corrected.)and Finally, Not enough choice of trains and resources. This limits the game somewhat but too many resources would make it Transport Tycoon a game I dislike a lot!After reading all this is the game worth it? Yes but do not expect quick action and that suits me a lot! One other issue for me is the use of mods. I am not very technical so why put additions in through mods? It would be better from my point of view to have mods as part of a DLC package which could then be chosen before a new game begins. Any thoughts are welcome!The ingame music is very good (Admiral James T - Cricket Post /Harvest)anybody know if it is to be released?

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												The good stuff: Probably the best train game in many, many years. Varied and good content where you don't need to play a financial analyst, you can concentrate solely on your "train companies".The bad stuff: The game crashes spontaneously, hangs sometimes and after 47 hours of gameplay all my saved games are unusable the game hangs at 69% Loding no matter which file I try to load.After a bit of googling, I see that this is a fairly common problem. Obviously updates helped many users but sadly enough too many forum threads end without any proper solution.I tried to postpone my purchase and have followed the game since last September but now I could not wait any longer, I had to have it. For others who have not bought it already, I just want to say, try to wait another six months so maybe the developers have solved more of the problems of spontaneous crashes and loading errors.Otherwise, one of the best if not the best game for train geeks, when the game doesn't crash or hang. I recommend this game but if you don't have to have it right now, wait until they made a couple more updates

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Quite enjoyable.  I did not find it as irritating as I thought that there are not many commodities, given that you have to configure your consist with the right rolling stock.  Requiring different stations for goods and people seems realistic to me, and adds limits to work around that make the game more interesting, with more need for crossovers and track/signal management.  Proper signaling is a fun puzzle to solve, and now that you can use a signal or waypoint in a route, you have fine control over which track is used.  Once I figured out the right way to lay track, it became highly enjoyable, determining the best way to navigate a slope.  And it's a gorgeous game.  Perhaps there is more work to do on this title, but I find it to be great in current state.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Like many comments before, this is a game with great potential.  If you can get past the rather odd and very slow start, it's really quite fun, even in this skelton form and clunck track laying mechanics.  But it's a strange place this Tran Fever Land, not least because of ghostly, empty and too-modern looking and generic towns for 1850 and a landscape desperately lacking in flora and fauna... or life of any sort.  Or anything for that matter.  Indeed, with no 3D texture to the grass or cropfields alike, it's like a tabletop.But perhaps that's where the character of the game, today at least, comes in.  It's a nice cross between a huge model railway and a 3D animated world.  Any new game is like watching a new sitcom on TV - you have to wait to get and idea of the theme, characters and essense before you can settle in.  And you have to give it a number of hours to do that.  so BE PATIENT.  Don't switch channels to soon, folks.Once I got into the visual style and the towns grew and new vhicles came online I found myself getting quite excited to see old style cars doing the long drive in and between towns (although again the game years and vehicles some out of alignment).  Enthusiatic to get the new, bigger locomotive, combine the stations and bus stops and see passengers begin to bustle and jossle to get to the bus and train.  I even held the trains up a few times to wait for the busload of commuters whose had just pulled up.  Did I care about them?  Or did I just want their fare?  Both actually.  And that means the game is already OK - but it COULD be great.I certainly hope the makers finish the game.  With the addition of more life to the worldscape, some greater variation in the people (visually and movements), and simplification or vehicle replacement, this could truly be the next generation of Transport Tycoom Deluxe.UPDATE 4-14-15:  Well, the updates have stopped, so I guess th develpers have moved on.  A pity because with a few enhancements they could have had a really good game here.  As it is, it's an OK game and I stick with my thumbs up.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Fun, easy to learn and nice graphics! I can absolutely recommend this transport-(mamagement-) simulator!Short description: Quite like Transport Tycoon, but better graphics and better gameplay. For guys who know Simutrans, Train Fever is the a little less complicated, but easier and graphically more enjoyable alternative.It's basically a complex 3D transport simulation game, where you can build and expand (reinvesting your revenue) your own transport network across about 100 Years in a random generated map.Positive:+ Easy to learn, so it's also easy to build your own transport-worlds full of marvelous train lines, for goods or passengers.+ Best graphics for a Transport Tycoon I've seen so far.. Really great for rail-fans, thanks!+ Enjoyable from the 1 hour to the 200 hour of gameplay (and further, if the developers continue imporving the game).+ You can and have to really build everything along the railway line, so stations, slopes, bridges, tunnels, everything has to be done by you. You can build everything exactly as you want it (if you earned the money). Still (especially compared to other such simulations) it's easy to learn and sooo much fun!+ The train and tram models (mostly swiss) you can choose from are gorgeous!Negative:- Some bugs are still in the game (eg. occasionally building tools do weird stuff), but most of the severe bugs have been repaired quickly. The developers are quite active.- The user interface is not very nicely designed, but you'll get used to that after 10 mins.- Only trains, trams and buses so far (no ships, planes, underground trains, cable cars)..- Not many train models to choose from yet, but the ones they have are very well modeled!- No DLCs yet, but the still small community is quite alive.- You can not drive the trains in your world. But the graphics from looking at them should already warm the heart of any train-fan.- Passenger behaviour is not yet as complex as in Simutrans Experimental, so sometimes it's not 100% realistic... But for most purposes it works even better than most other transport simulations.- Only stations with up to 5 tracks and no underground stations or big city infrastructures available yet. So in its current form it's more like a transport simulator for rural railway networks, not megacities yet.Conclusion: It's great fun for railway fans! With Train Fever I can finally my own beautiful alpine railway landscapes - and gampeplay is really fun... I love it. Buy it..

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 22
												First off, this game is a ♥♥♥♥ing piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ don't buy it.Secondly, this game is an addicting masterpiece, go buy it.This game reminds me a lot of OpenTTD, but without confining the user to the grid system, and also in 3D. And also with really good graphics. There are some extremely annoying bugs and poor implementations of some features. Things that I can think of at the top of my head:- The way that vehicles are guided through intersections is a pain in the pineapple, and often unnecessarily causes delays of 20+ minutes. This is especially annoying early in the game, and/or on hard mode. - The terrain is extremely difficult to deform, given the limited and pretty much broken tools available.- Vehicles never change lanes/tracks, but instead their routes are absolutely hardcoded. This means that, for example, a train will not "choose" the best available platform at a station, but instead wait until its designated platform is free.- The amount of money analysis tools are very limited, and overall vehicle management is pretty much non-existent. As frustrating as it is, this game is beautiful, addicting, and super satisfying. If you like OpenTTD-style games, you should consider buying Train Fever.

												Train fever is a good and fun game to play overall. It is in my opinion the best train tycoonish game around at the moment and judging from past updates, it should get better with time.Pros: It's fun! Nice graphics (maps, trains, other vehicules), good audio design, unique music, easy to use building tool.Cons: Building tool needs more advanced options for more complex networks, performance gets bellow average on large maps in the late game, yearly savegame process is horrid.TF features a sandbox setup and very good looking proceduraly generated maps. It is really just that though a sandbox and it doesnt feature any tycoon options like campaigns and/or competition. Instead here you are fighting the elements such as hills, rivers, main roads, vehicules decay, etc. The maps look good and not two games are the same since they are generated. If however you are looking for real world maps, you won't find it here.So what do you actually do when playing TF? You build train, tram, bus and otherwise truck lines to move either passengers and/or cargo around while trying to make enough money to survive another year.So how is the building tool since it's most of what we do in this game? It's okay but not great. Building basic rails/roads is easy enough once you learn how the tool reacts to roads and rivers for example. It always try to save you money by proposing the most economical option (bridge, tunnel?, going over?). It also tries to make the best curves and slopes possible automaticaly. Setting up two lines next to each other is also a charm since the tool acts like a magnet and nicely sticks that 2nd line next to the 1st one. For all the basic stuff, it's great.The building tool really lacks more robust features though, features such as seen in other titles like Cities Skylines. In short, you can't easily cross any other line that already exists. The tool isn't letting the player decide on elevation (page up/down in Cities: Skylines) and there's no way to build X or + connections between two lines. Sure there are tricks around this but it isn't friendly and it makes a mess. As long as you focus on building railroads for EITHER passengers OR cargo, it's fun enough. But as soon as you try to setup multiple lines for BOTH passengers AND cargo, the building tool just falls short. You see, passengers and cargo require different kinds of stations. But since there is no way for a line to go over or under an existing line, it's just not fun to try and build large rail networks for both passengers and cargo. You end up with a spaghetti of parallel lines preventing you from building additional ones.As a result cargo trains are being left out for the most part and focus is more on passengers ones. It feels like a whole portion of the game is not accessible because the construction tool isn't robust enough and that is my main issue with this one.Sure experiencing better performance on large maps, being able to buy industries, maybe have credit quotations for loans and see more tycoon features being added would be nice. But first, fix the building tool. I recommend this game because despite it's obvious flaws, it's fun in it's current state and there are indications it should get even better.Thumbs up!

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Bought this game because everyone says it is like Sid Meiers Railroads, a game I love but can not play since switching to Linux.Now the only similar thing is the building of train networks between cities and resources but that is where it ends.  The game actually is more complex.  Laying of tracks and setting up trains requires more work than Railroads.In Railroads you simply lay your track then pick your train and train cars for that section of track.  In Train Fever you must do more, like create a train depot which MUST be connected to the track you want to train to be on.  I could not figure out how to delete a train nor have I figured out yet how to properly connect resources.  BTW, every station MUST be connected to a road which makes placing your tracks even harder.On top of creating train routes, you also need to create bus routes to move people around each city to your train station.Unlike Railroads though, there doesn't appear to be any computer players to compete against.  For some people like myself, this can result in a not as fun game but if you are a huge fan of sim city type games where there is no one to compete against then you should enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: January 22
												First off, this game is a ♥♥♥♥ing piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ don't buy it.Secondly, this game is an addicting masterpiece, go buy it.This game reminds me a lot of OpenTTD, but without confining the user to the grid system, and also in 3D. And also with really good graphics. There are some extremely annoying bugs and poor implementations of some features. Things that I can think of at the top of my head:- The way that vehicles are guided through intersections is a pain in the pineapple, and often unnecessarily causes delays of 20+ minutes. This is especially annoying early in the game, and/or on hard mode. - The terrain is extremely difficult to deform, given the limited and pretty much broken tools available.- Vehicles never change lanes/tracks, but instead their routes are absolutely hardcoded. This means that, for example, a train will not "choose" the best available platform at a station, but instead wait until its designated platform is free.- The amount of money analysis tools are very limited, and overall vehicle management is pretty much non-existent. As frustrating as it is, this game is beautiful, addicting, and super satisfying. If you like OpenTTD-style games, you should consider buying Train Fever.

												If you love transportation games such as Cities in motion, and railroad tycoon, and/or you just love trains you will waste many happy hours on this one. Probably the most real life accurate train management game I've ever played. Track gradiants and curve radius' matter and the computer does not manage the trains for you.  No auto "phasing" out trains because another one is coming, or imaginary "hold" tracks that you can't see, you must manage all the trains and where they go, or enjoy your giant cluster %&$^# because you didnt build your tracks right and/or signal them right and/or manage your lines correctly.They are a few minor issues that the dev's are still working on but its quite enjoyable. Plus their releasing a free DLC come febuary.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Train Fever is a delightfully enthralling management game that you can plunge hours into. I found myself staying up all night in a 'Just One More Turn' sort of way, either because I was desperately trying to keep my fledgling Rail company above water or because I wanted to see if new technology's or expanding profits would allow me to splash out on a new project or to reinvigorate an old one. In terms of management, I've found that learning the basics isn't overly hard, but mastering it is the real challenge. In other management games, I have often found that once you plug the main problem, you have nothing more to do; it's too easy to find the perfect equilibrium and once you've played it once there's little reason to go back and play it again and you rarely had to restart for lack of skill in the first place. In Train Fever, you'll solve a short term problem only to later discover that there's a much bigger long term problem built upon more short term problems. There's lots to manage and lots to do (although not so much as to overwhelm you), and as technology advances new avenues for profit and loss will open up and you'll have to adapt to changing circumstances. Things that are in 1850 unprofitable and infeasible may in 1900 be profitable and very doable.In short, Train Fever is a game of adaption, of chasing profits and avoiding losses, which can be tough, but very rewarding. You may have to play a failed game or two before you learn all of it's secrets, but a management game in which you instantly have the cure to any ailment is a short lived and unrewarding one.7/10

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												Conclusion: awesome track laying game that poorly explains itself (aka has a learning curve)I am thoroughly enjoying this game but many, many feature only become apparent after looking through guides on steam and after trial and error. For example I thought there was a cargo staying on the platform bug.. I had 1 route designed like this: pickup cargo, drop off at station 1, pickup cargo again, drop off at station 2. Turns out.. the demand for goods in station 1 is low, so the goods stream in slowly, so the train keeps waiting to fill it up - and never getting to station 2 which is building up. The easy solution: create 2 separate lines and all is good. So after learning how to lay bus tracks efficiently, place signals effectively, build bridges, ... you end up with a game that's a bit like it suggests in title.. first a fever to overcome it, then a fever because it will suck you back in. Because you can borrow enough money and making it profitable at easy level isn't all that hard, it's more a game about making a beautiful operating railroad than a tough challenge. And that's fine to me. It's the best game in laying out an efficient routed railway - in any game. I really can't remember that that part was executed that well, and looked this good. I personally love setting the landscape to hilly and create a great flowing double track railroad running through with tight blocks so accommodate all the goods & passenger traffic. The game runs very well on my GTX 970 at 2560x1024 with everything maxed out. There are some quirks which I'll hope they fix soon, and I do want to mention that it's good to see the devs have just released another update and support the product:(1) Keys only work after clicking on the landscape(2) No mention when trains get stuck (especially after breaking up a section to expand)(3) The 'two steps'  required is tedious and doesn't belong in games.. figure it out guys(4) Upgrade a street won't fit while staying a 2 lane road.. really?(5) Bigger stations please(6) Allow alternative platforms through alternative waypointsSo all in all it's a very enjoyable game, if you can deal with it's learning curve - and especially when on offer for a special price, it's great value. If you liked transport tycoon, or similar games from Chris Sawyer or Sid Meier ... you'll enjoy this one. I think it's beaten their latest efforts for sure.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												I can't recommend Train Fever even though I'd like to. Train Fever can be a fun, charming game at times. It's beautiful to look at. Watching your train go across the countryside or following a tram through your city is just beautiful. It's relaxing (when it works). It's charming and I really gravitate to that. I like the ability to create my own transportation networks, plan routes and create my own little empire. But it's fundamentally broken.1. Performance is exceptionally poor. By the time you get to 1950, expect your computer to stutter badly even on small maps. This has been only somewhat fixed in subsequent patches but the overall performance still is lackluster.2. Game mechanics either don't work correctly or are so poorly explained as to be frustratingly obtuse. Some things - like resource production or auto-replacing vehicles - only work sporadically. Others like city growth and even how to set up signals are so obtuse they're not fun. They could have done a much better job of either providing more information on screen or perhaps a better tutorial. There are some quite un-fun mechanics in here that could and should have been much more elegant. 3. Gameplay is fairly limited. There are precious few industries, a static map (there's never a new resource node or challenge you have to react to), limited supply chains, etc. All of thise makes for a less-than-ideal experience. Transport Tycoon this isn't, even if it says it would like to be. There are no ships, no planes either. In short, nothing dynamic happens even though the time period encompasses the Industrial Revolution, 2 World Wars, etc. Cities grow slowly and vehicles change but the lack of industry growth is a massive flaw. 4. Probably the biggest killer is a lack of feedback to the player. There is very limited information. Want to know how many people use a bus stop? Sorry. Want to know why someone decided to walk or drive to work? Sorry. Want to know where that passenger is headed? You could be delivering plenty of coal and iron to a plant and production won't rise but the game won't give you an inkling why. You simply don't know what's happening or how to optimize. In other transport games you can get a sense of where the problems are and how to rectify them. This is a fatal flaw in the game and is the reason for the thumbs down. This was so close to being good. But I think what may have happened is that they ran into such a roadblock with performance issues they never got around to really polishing the gameplay or creating the reporting tools needed by players to make good decisions. Then they went on to Transport Fever and did basically the same thing. It's quite a shame to say it but this one is more frustration than fun.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												I am only recommending this game on potential, not how it is at the moment.Pro'sIt looks really quite nice, not quite as pretty as the 'tilt shift photography' method of Sim City but certainly passable, i would say it's probably around the same as SM Railroads +If you have played CIM the lines are going to be very familar to you +The framework for a replacement Railroad Tycoon 2 is definately here +Current Con'sIt has an internal logic, but the developers don't want you to know what that might be.  So you'll end up with trains using what track they feel like or sitting at lights for no reason at all. --No significant tutorial, coupled with a entirely opaque UI, be prepared to spend time on goggle learning how to play. -Track laying is both powerful and at the same time utterly dreadful, it forces you towards level tracks, generally good, but it will give you bridges for some drops, tunnels for gentle hills.  You can get around this, but you have to very carefully lay small segments of track, obviously you start to lose sight of the other station. -Making money is very hard, at least at the begining the maintence costs are simply punishing, trains are a giant money sink, road transport makes money, rail transport costs money, -Industry model seems broken to me, like the above, I am sure there was a reason my carts were sat waiting for coal, but the game wasn't about to tell me. -This really isn't ready for prime time, i could have added more issues, but it seems unfair, the framework for a good, possibly great sim is here, but this really isn't it.I would wait for patches and/or mods before purchasing.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												After reading some of the other "gushing" reviews (best train sim eva) for this game I put up the dosh and bought it. Seems to me that the "this game is awesome" reviews are shills and/or have never played another train sim in their life.10 minutes in, I want a bitumen road from town 1 to town 2 and get a whole heap of BS about bypasses to remove a dirt track. Despite building a *parallel* paved road I cannot delete the "main connection" dirt track. Seriously. I setup a route and the wagon uses the *dirt* road - not my brand new flash-harry paved track. Now this is apparently a recent "ïnnovation" because some idiot knee-jerker thinks SINGLE PLAYER games shouldn't be able to be exploited. (ie: delete track, install rail, remove competition). I'm fine with that but I'm UPGRADING the *road* - the very same thing I'm trying to delete - the dirt version.The music is no better than some mad science experiment about feeling "good". Took all of 15 seconds to turn it off. GFX are reasonable. Everything is green. Ho-hum tbh.  Slight improvement on 2000 version of "Sims" when zoomed in. UI is odd. (Just make damn sure your bulldozer is OFF before you do ANYTHING!)Apart from the track deletion (stupid, stupid) I decided I wanted to start later in the century because horse and cart is of NO INTEREST to me. But.....I have to complete "achievements" to be able to start at a later time. Really???!!!Incomplete. Marginal. Limited. Quaint. It's not Early Access but should have been listed as such.I got it on special. It *still* cost too much.5/10. Will update review if they sort this crap out. Caveat Emptor.

												If, like me, you are utterly terrible at transport management games because of their insane, in-depth levels of detail such as setting fare prices, goods prices, schedules etc, but you enjoy playing them regardless because you like watching the little trains and buses go pootling around, then this game is for you.It's simple, easy to learn, and a complete doddle on easy difficulty, yet still largely entertaining. number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Played for a few minutes, maybe I should write something down.1.  It immediately reminds me of Transport Tycoon Deluxe, as well as the 3D attempt (3DTT) fell through some 15 years ago.  The depot placement is surely 3DTT, and the financial setup is similar to TTD.2. The line feature is the most prominent feature of the game.  It has its limitations though, such as cargo will vanish if the player removes the associated route.  Therefore route planning is essential.3. Station mechanism has a bit of problem.  Train stations have to be physically connected in order to exchange cargo.  This make putting a station in the middle of a built-up area unwise.Generally a good game, and hopefully this game can sooth the sorrow of 3DTT not making it.(v1:  2015-10-21)

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												Initially I didn't get it because it is different from the old tycoon games. Then I figured it out (read some of the guides)... and now I'm hooked!Game economics and growth are more realistic. Think closely about supply and demand, supply chains, and how stimulate growth. And be careful with choosing which means of transport to use and start small, then grow it (hint: trains are expensive to run so you want them to fill up).Amazing details and it feels like you can do anything. As you travel through time, everything changes.If you were hooked on the old railroad games and need a greater challenge, then this is the game for you.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												As a huge fan of the "Transport Tycoon" genre, I was extremely excited to find out about Train Fever. However, because of a lot of negative reviews at the time and the fairly high price, I was a bit put off for a while. When I found it in a store for a third of the price, I instabought it. I can now say that its definatly worth the full price and is an extremely good game.Pros:- Very nice looking, I could watch my trains for hours.- Large modding community to expand on the base game.- Runs very well, has been updated a lot since release.- Free "USA DLC" which adds even more- Good achievements which are fun to collect.- Building is decent, not perfect but does the job fairly well.- Is quite simple if you want it on the easy difficulty but still provides a pretty big challenge on hard.Cons:- Lacks Ships and Planes- Lacks multiplayer- Doesn't have enough industries in my opinion.Apart from those few cons Train Fever is very enjoyable and I believe is well worth the full price but pick it up on sale if you still believe its too pricy.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												The game have pretty graphics thats all. And because of that it makes you wanna play more and more. The trains are very detailed, the wagons, the sounds. But don't bother getting it. Another unfinished game on Steam.- The game lags absurdly. My machine can run GTA V at full specs no lag. But cant run this game on a medium sized map with 20 trains running without lagging every scroll of the map. The devs already released 5 patchs to improve performance, still same thing. It will never improve. The engne is broken.- The cargo system is broken. No mods are able to fix that. The industries only produce goods if the entire industry chain is linked. That causes 2 main problems: industry chain in the game is ridiculously simple. The most complex industry you have is: Coal + Iron = Steel = Goods. That's all. Second problem is that if you want to make any changes in your line (put a more modern train, remake a connection) all the industries affected by that line will drop production to zero. Because they cant wait a second more than 20 minutes to receive goods. And to increase production back it take years. That means you lose a profit of millions for years and go bankrupt, game over.- Game balance is horrible. Put trains, trucks, buses and trams in one game was a huge mistake. A bus makes profit driving a feel blocks, to simulate a town. So if you want to get filfy rich you make a bus drive between two cities and you get more money than a train. Cities are too small, train stations are extremelly huge considering the map size.- There are way too many industries in the map. You can make the entire thing on trucks and buses, no need for trains. Of course, neither way is possible because after you buy your 10th truck or 10th train the game will lag till you want to punch the screen.- The game has nothing but connect point A to point B and look at pretty graphics. RRT2 from 1998 has 10x more features (a decent financial report, stock market, buy and sell companies, competition, etc). Well it has less features than Locomotion (a game that Chris Sawyer made while sleeping). Focus too much on graphics all the rest is left aside.It took me years to write this review, but I cannot avoid this conclusion. The devs are dedicated but unfortunately they made a big mistake on development. I don't know why small devs make their own engine. Use Unity or other. CO made the same mistake with Cities in Motion 1. Very nice graphics, thats all. Lag as hell. If its a small team use your resources to finish the game, not start from scrach.Not wroth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												This is definately no Railroad Tycoon program. It is much more simplified.In a way it isn't even a Train Simulator.  In fact you don't even have to run any trains if you don't want to.You can run a Stage Line instead and still make millions of dollars.  Of course you can run both trains and coaches.The trains are hard to operate unless your simply running pont to point.  The signaling system is too simple to be of much good if you try running multiple trains on one track.  There is only one size Train Station, BIG.  There is no small Train Station that you can place at a distant Industry. There are three different sizes of train stations but even the smallest takes up space equal to 3 city blocks. They look silly sitting next to a dinky logging camp.The industries are spread haphazardly about the map.  You might find an Oil Well but the Refinery could be halfway across the map.  It isn't cost effective to service since comodities bring very little cash compared to Passengers.  You can of course but it will take years to get a return on your investment.Cargo hauling by Horsedrawn wagons or Freight Trucks is more cost effective than trains but unlike trains they can't haul freight to an industry and then pick up the goods produced. For example a Truck delivering lumber won't automatically change and take a load of goods made from the lumber.  You have to buy a seperate truck for goods, Not very realistic.Graphics are pretty bad,  Inside towns or cities it's not bad but out on the highways and tracks it's bad.  The land is bare and boring with an occasional tree or two.  Even shades of green would be better than dirt and sand.If you use a Trackball or a wheel less mouse you will have problems scrolling some popup windows once you exceed 9 Lines.  Scrolling these windows requires a Mouse wheel.  Poor design. Now you might be wondering why I recommend this game.I'm enjoying running Stagecoaches and fine tuning the profit making.I like being able to zoom in and see my coaches moving along and looking at all the people inside towns.Cute things like watching a coach stop to let pedestrians cross the street.I'm sure to discover new things as I play along.  I'll add them here if I do.I'm having fun,  so yes I recommend it.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												1. Frustrating. Non-existent tutorial makes this a tough game to jump into straight away. After spending an evening watching YouTube videos, I was finally able to get a business up and running and breaking even. Raw materials are scattered across the map, as expected, but the factories are also stuck out in the middle of nowhere, instead of congregating in the industrial sectors of your towns. Not having the ability to build new factories, where you really need them, is also extremely irritating. 2. Fun. Not nearly as playable as Sid Meiers' Railroads and with no real goals or opponents it boils down to a straight builder. If you like SimCity or Banished, this is for you. 3. UI. Horrible. To track performance and profitibility you need to have several windows open which cover most of the play area. With no ability to push these windows over to a second monitor you have to pause often to review your status. When new trains become available there is no accompanying information to let you know if they are passenger or freight trains. I really was expecting more. Hopefully there are expansions, updates or mods out there to make this a better, more satisfying gaming experience.

												Another one rides the bus! There is no such thing as a straight line and inspite of the terrain looking flat, the game finds a way to build a bridge or tunnel and spend your money. There are stiill bugs in the economy. However, after playing for an extended length of time I've grown to like this game.
