Catch the ganme on sale (unlike the bulk of us) and enjoy the new DLC with U.S. vehices and trains Once you understand the mechanics, I think you'll enjoy it.  Here comes the bus, bye.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												1. Frustrating. Non-existent tutorial makes this a tough game to jump into straight away. After spending an evening watching YouTube videos, I was finally able to get a business up and running and breaking even. Raw materials are scattered across the map, as expected, but the factories are also stuck out in the middle of nowhere, instead of congregating in the industrial sectors of your towns. Not having the ability to build new factories, where you really need them, is also extremely irritating. 2. Fun. Not nearly as playable as Sid Meiers' Railroads and with no real goals or opponents it boils down to a straight builder. If you like SimCity or Banished, this is for you. 3. UI. Horrible. To track performance and profitibility you need to have several windows open which cover most of the play area. With no ability to push these windows over to a second monitor you have to pause often to review your status. When new trains become available there is no accompanying information to let you know if they are passenger or freight trains. I really was expecting more. Hopefully there are expansions, updates or mods out there to make this a better, more satisfying gaming experience.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I have played many games of this genre before, including Locomotion, all of the Transport Tycoons, Railroads!, all of the Railroad Tycoon games and a few others, and never before have I encountered a product as well balanced and easy to use as this. Granted, the economy works differently than most other games in this genre. For example, in most transport games, trains only run when they are full of goods in order to make a profit, however, in Train Fever, running trains without them needing to be full is essential to make a profit, because, much like in real life, a train on a siding is burning fuel and going nowhere, while its load decays in value. The game is well priced and has a strong user interface that is easy to use and a refeshingly easy approach to replacing and re-routing vehicles. I higly recomend this game to anyone that wants to think while playing a game, and or is interested in logistics and transportation. Pros:1. Easy to use and understand interface2. Infinent possiblities for every diffferent map3. Amazing graphics and genrally good polish on everything4. Hyper-relistic simulation5. Fun and interesting mechanics make for a great expriance6. Runs smooth on max settings on my pc (AMD six core 3.5 Mhz, 16 Gb RAM, 3Gb graphics, 750 watt power supply)7. Makes for a lot of fun for a good price8. Devs are adding more every month or soCons:1. Lack of good tutorial, recomend going to the fourms and reading about mechanics of game before playing2. Not a huge diversity of vehicles, can be fixed with mods3. You won't be succesful on your first try, its a thinking game, and takes time to learn the ropes4. Small dev team means progress is slow5. No AI competitors6. Production cap on industries, just a personal pet peeve of mine. It should be about 1000, accounting for the economic value of one unit of goods carried to one city and the nubmer of jobs provided by that good, but its capped at 4006. Not many useful guides on steam, go to the fourms for better ideas and solutions

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												This is definately no Railroad Tycoon program. It is much more simplified.In a way it isn't even a Train Simulator.  In fact you don't even have to run any trains if you don't want to.You can run a Stage Line instead and still make millions of dollars.  Of course you can run both trains and coaches.The trains are hard to operate unless your simply running pont to point.  The signaling system is too simple to be of much good if you try running multiple trains on one track.  There is only one size Train Station, BIG.  There is no small Train Station that you can place at a distant Industry. There are three different sizes of train stations but even the smallest takes up space equal to 3 city blocks. They look silly sitting next to a dinky logging camp.The industries are spread haphazardly about the map.  You might find an Oil Well but the Refinery could be halfway across the map.  It isn't cost effective to service since comodities bring very little cash compared to Passengers.  You can of course but it will take years to get a return on your investment.Cargo hauling by Horsedrawn wagons or Freight Trucks is more cost effective than trains but unlike trains they can't haul freight to an industry and then pick up the goods produced. For example a Truck delivering lumber won't automatically change and take a load of goods made from the lumber.  You have to buy a seperate truck for goods, Not very realistic.Graphics are pretty bad,  Inside towns or cities it's not bad but out on the highways and tracks it's bad.  The land is bare and boring with an occasional tree or two.  Even shades of green would be better than dirt and sand.If you use a Trackball or a wheel less mouse you will have problems scrolling some popup windows once you exceed 9 Lines.  Scrolling these windows requires a Mouse wheel.  Poor design. Now you might be wondering why I recommend this game.I'm enjoying running Stagecoaches and fine tuning the profit making.I like being able to zoom in and see my coaches moving along and looking at all the people inside towns.Cute things like watching a coach stop to let pedestrians cross the street.I'm sure to discover new things as I play along.  I'll add them here if I do.I'm having fun,  so yes I recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												OpenTTDs more attractive cousin. Quickly you'll realise she's a bit simpler too.While the graphics are great to look at, you'll soon work out the further you get with this game, how poorly optimised it is. I don't think there is a computer available today that can deal with large maps and an abundance of lines of trains, trams etc.Gameplay while not that deep, is pretty laid back. You'll either give up with the path signals or realise how awesome they really are. They can do anything once you get the hang of it. Train selection is pretty good. Most satisfying aspect of the whole game is making lines more effecient and profitable. Do you add another train and sink millions to lower its frequency or pack it up and try again later?Overall, for the right price, it is recommended even with its short comings listed above. Great game to chill out with and not too taxing on the brain. Make yourself a giant line that loops the map, sit back and enjoy the ride afterwards.The music is pretty sweet too.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Wonderful transport simulation game, amazingly beautiful and fun to play. The game feels very realistic, much less schematic in depicting the physical reality than, say, OpenTTD (it seems that some people dislike the limitations based on real-world constraints, such as allowed rail curvature and slope, but I enjoy this realism a lot).It looks like the most complaints about this game and negative reviews came from the initial release, and most issues have been solved by now.I give Train Fever 8 stars out of 10. If you are like me a long-standing fan of Transport Tycoon, TTD and OpenTTD, I definitely recommend you to give Train Fever a try.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												It's not Transport Tycoon. Yet. And look at the differences between OTTD and the original Transport Tycoon Deluxe. These things come over time. These guys know that community development is key, and mod support strengthens the game immensely. Whilst not perfect, the game fares really well overall and is the first game to do free (non-tiled) track building really nicely. And it's quite hard to master, even for a TTD-veteran. There's some more room for features and content, but that's always good, and they're continously working on the game, still. Also the music's spot-on, and really nicely following the TTD/Locomotion/RRT-style of smokey and jazzy bluegrass-esque mixtures.If you're into trains, or at least into transport sims, you're not gonna regret this. There's a nice community behind it, and there's tons of mods already around. But the vanilla game - plus the free DLC, not to forget - are good enough to have a great deal of fun with. These games are rare enough in itself.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												•	This is the first ‘Transport Management’ game I have bought in a few years (I was a big fan of the Railroad Tycoon series) – the game doesn’t disappoint – the graphics are very good and for the most part the interface is intuitive. •	This isn’t a game you can pick up and play proficiently after 5 minutes – the game has a steep learning curve. I recommend watching a few YouTube tutorials before you get started (there isn’t a ‘guided start mode’ – which is ridiculous for such an in-depth game).•	 The interface itself could defiantly benefit from being optimized (more ‘sorting’ and ‘apply to all’ required). •	The placement of roads and rails is somewhat infuriating at time and there is a well reported ‘bug’ / ‘feature’ that prevents certain roads from being upgraded. •	The game itself is divided into ‘eras’ with different vehicles becoming available when certain dates are reached – as a new player you aren’t able to jump into a ‘modern era’ without first playing through the early eras.  •	I haven’t experienced any crashes or glitches in the game.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												I rarely comment on games and I rarely regret buying a game, since I have generally no higher expectations than providing some entertainment for a couple of evenings in exchange of a couple of bucks, but Train Fever made me to comment. This game is a bad joke, unfortunately. First the name: the game is about road and railroad transportation, unlike its name implies. I wish I had no other problems... Oversimplified economy and simulation. The paradigm of keep it stupid simple created a Railroad Tycoon in full HD – but the complexity of economy, traffic and simulation has not really been improved from the game title from the early 90s. Boring gameplay. No challenges other than repeatedly creating bus lines between towns. For me, no local routes could reach any profit, the only thing making sense in the game is to connect different towns. Boring graphics. No more than a couple of variations of each types of buildings and 3 or 4 differently looking sims made the game tedious in two hours. Undetailed graphics: A horse wagon with horses but without carman? In 2015? Buses and trains stopping, but no doors opening and noone taking the vehicle or getting off? Joke. Adding several vehicles to a route will cause them to start at the same minute. Why the hell developers thought I will want to wait with my fingers crossed until my first vehicle reaches 25% progress in its total distance just to manually release the second of the four vehicles on the route and so on? Weird time simulation: Having build the 6th line with no pause between building lines, and the game reported vehicles on the first line reached their maximum age of 15 years. What?Unfortunatelly, after a couple of hours of gameplay I could add a dozen more items to this list, but I do not want to waste more time with this game.If you ever wanted a nice state-of-the-art city builder or transport simulator, and you passed age 6, you do not want to try this game. Feeling so disappointed. :(

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												Gamedesign is very solid and it makes much fun building the traffic lines and earn money with them.The vehicles are designed well and with the USA DLC theres even more diversity. However i still think vehicle running costs could be balanced a little better.Building train tracks(double+) is also a little frustrating sometimes when you can see no logic reason why the terrain can't be aligned and will drive you nearly nuts when trying to connect two stations through a tunnel or when the station istelf has to be in hilly terrain.However after some time practicing one is able to mostly avoid such situations.Well considering only Gameplay/Design i would give the game a 8/10BUTThere is the technical side that is pretty much a gamebreaker. In the Endgame or roughly after 1950 when the Cities start expanding the frame rate Drops significantly (for me from 60FPS frame cap to 8-15 FPS depending on camera view)and the autosave at the end of the year tends to stop the game for several seconds) Having the line overview open or a train window (the one where the train is viewed in the frame of the window) will drop the frames even more.All in all it can be called a slideshow.All you can do against it is play on small maps then the performance drops are kept at bay, but with a middle to large map (which are much more fun) you are pretty much doomed.The perfomance issues seem to be caused by poor programming since cpu Utilization never rises above 20-25% and the graphic card is only utilized to a third of its potential.So even having a pretty high end system won't help much, since only 1or 2 Threads seem to be used by the game.In my case its an FX8320(overclocked to 4.5ghz) paired with gtx 980 ti.my final Rating would be a 2/10 considering perfomance drops in the endgame nullify the fun of the work you invested in the Previous 100-150 simulated years. This Review was made with the latest patched version.

number of helpful: 17 of 34 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												When I first played this game, I found it frustrating and clunky. I thought I'd do the right thing and give it 12 months to see if it got better and from what I can see it didn't. As someone who was a massive fan of TTD almost 20 years ago and in the last few an even bigger fan of OpenTTD, I was hoping this could be something similar with improved graphics. I will give it some credit, the graphics are great. Beautiful models and nice, if not largely empty, maps but it goes downhill from there. I found the total lack of a tutorial map a massive turn off and found it insulting that the developers had the shear audacity to link to player made guides when I needed in depth help. There was a simple help tutorial which was vague, just lines on message box and no pictures to illustrate if you weren't sure. I found trying create lines difficult and not always obvious as to why it worked sometimes and not other times and that when I was trying to added new stations to a line it would just select the station instead of adding it. Ultimately this game is definitely not worth $30, and honestly I would still feel like I got ripped off at $10. I'm going to put this in the "Got burnt hoping this game would be like something else" pile. What saddens me most is that I'm a huge fan of the Business Simulator genre that has fallen into obscurity in the last 10 years but it's games like this that give the genre a bad reputation and stop other, better games from being developed.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												Promising game.... though its incomplete and it looks like the developers address new DLC in favour of fixing the game itself. This game is in a state of "Early Access", i wouldn't even call it beta maybe a pre-beta.Nice graphics and music. But that's not enough for a good game.TF lacks an intuitive interface and track building is a real pain in the a**. I could live with that, but the annoyance just starts there. You may start with 1 track and one train between 2 stations. Now look into the future, you may want to extend your station - bad idea, you'll have to burn the old one down to the ground and replace it with a complete new one and even that one is limited to 5 tracks.... sorry guys that's an insult for every transport tycoon! Then there is that .... AI ... no, its more a very simple script that tells the train where to go. If you have more than one track at a station, the trains of a line (the list of stations to approach) will ALWAYS use the same track.... even when the others are unoccupied and more trains of the same line form a queue behind the first waiting train.... and other trains of other lines aswell.In other words: Its too difficult for casual players (interface/track building) and lacks very basic features for the expert players coming from OpenTTD or Railroad Tycoon. But hey, it's in real 3D and it looks good.....I am very disappointed and do not recommend this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												How would i summarize this game? ,♥♥♥♥♥♥, i have tried to like it i really have and there is alot of potential here, but the tipping point for me writing this review, after putting up with all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and finally getting towards late game , random crashes to desktop , to me it looks suspiciously like an out of memory bug ( the engine not my comp, it has 16gb , win7/64 )Here is what needs to be improved to get me to recommend this game- Fix the ♥♥♥♥ing late game crashes...- Improve the track editor so it doesn't feel like someone has installed HAL into the engine " sorry i can't let you do that dave " - The intro movie shows fantastic bridges / road network , yea ♥♥♥♥ off show a video of someone actually doing that in real time with no mods as it plays in the game, good luck on a 30 minute boring♥♥♥♥♥clip... - No competitor AI - The cargo logic makes no sense, everything must be delivered in 20 minutes, really ? , why ? - 4 industry types really? thats all there is... In short this game looks like it should have been in for development for another year and it would be this generations Open TTD, but instead we get a buggy engine that crashes and stutters even on high end machines, a frustratingly stupid track building system, and a road building system apparently inspired by " lol i can curve da road "... Likely to keep playing TBH , as it does have its fun moments, but be warned the devs are about to give up and move on and the problems are not likely to be fixed as some like the track building issues / terrain alignment issues have been present since launch.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Unless you want to experience countless hours of frustration and disappointment stay away from this. The construction process is undoubtedly the worst and most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ever devised. The only thing you can do if you want to avoid mind boggling snafus is to lay a few single tracks and watch the trains as they roll. This game is a crossbreed between  Locomotion and Cities in Motion and tries to accomplish everything but fails miserably in every aspect. Track layout is like in Locomotion except you have more chances to win the Nobel prize than to build a tunnel. Junctions can only be very far apart so you'll have a difficult time building a non-trivial rail network on the very limited space and uneven terrain. Train routes are like the subway lines in Cities in motion so all trains on a route will use the same line in a station regardless of how many there are. Every time you alter a route with so much as a signal it will be reset and the passengers will disappear. They also disappear from the trains while they are transported. You can't build roads over rails, you first have to demolish rails, place the road and then build the rails again. You can't demolish reasonable rail segments the game arbitrarily chooses large chunks and even both rails if they go over a road or there is a junction. Terraforming is horrible as you level terrain, you can only raise, lower or 'smooth' it and only in three circular brushes although all buildings and tracks are rectangular. You can build while the game is paused but this will still erase the passengers waiting at stations and confuse the trains.There are only few vehicles and their running costs are excessively high, especially for trains. Mines and oil wells produce too little and have to be 'persuaded' to transport their cargo with your vehicles which takes a few years during which you'll only register big losses. You can't set the price for the The ui is ghastly and cumbersome. The game freezes for many seconds at times and this gets worse as the game progresses.Documentation/help is missing in action. Not even a few lousy tooltips like transport tycoon had 20 years ago.It's such a pity there are so many serious flaws with a game which looks so good and has such detailed models and nice sounds and lighting. I really enjoy watching the vehicles move around and use the follow camera but whenever I have to build something it makes me so mad that i want to crash a few trains (which you can't do in this game by the way).

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Plus:+ This is one of the best replicas of TTD(Transport Tycoon Deluxe) I've played to date.+ game is simple, easy to manage+ easy to build railroads+ an already present road system so you only need to plop down stations and depots and you are good to go road side+ really nice order setting menu for your vehicles+ an interesting mechanic that somewhat forces you to build both a rail and bus system in a city and they work off eachother to make more money.+ easy to replace vehicles+ graphicsMinus:- some factories dont produce goods if they don't have anywhere to deliver within a close enough radius- this does not change even when u make a station for said factory and there is nothing in the game implying it- poor terraform tool and no way to make elevation change projections before building, to save money- no easy way to make overlapping tracks or bridges over lines- poor optimizationI would give this a thumbs up and play the game a lot more than I have if it did not crash for me repeatedly, shortly after 1900, on two separate playthroughs. Worth a buy for under $8, but I don't think there is any guarantee the game will run well in to the late game.

												This is not a newer and prettier OTTD! As much as they tried to recreate the experience, and they came close, trying to play with no mods (to get achievements) is beyond frustrating. To lay one section of track can sometimes take forever because the building system is just not intuitive, refined, or even understandable at times! This one issues (and there are only 2 or 3) takes away from the game so much its not even enjoyable, and I have tried to play thru this ONE issue. 136 hours on record. If you don't care about any of the achievements (and other things in game), then you can enable mods to by pass the FRUSTRATION of not being able to delete the game generated roads (because they are main connections, and you spend an hour drawing OTHER MAIN CONNECTIONS that never work so you can get the useless road out of your way!). There have been many times Ill just quit in the middle of a game out of frustration. It is pretty, simple, and addictive if you vaguely enjoyed OTTD. But this ONE issues needs to be addressed before its really playable. Sadly until then, I would have to recommend to not buy it, unless its on sale for $5.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine  PLEASE NOTE: I recommended this game with some exceptions, overall if the game did not live up to just a tiny expectation, I would not have recommended it at all, so please read the review carefully if you are thinking of buying/playing this game A new fever is in the works, it's called Train Fever!Not really... Train Fever is a game developed by Urban Games and published by Gambitious Digital Entertainment and it's mostly like the classic Transport Tycoon Deluxe and OpenTTD, only... it's not as goodTrain Fever is a fun game to play, although I don't know why they just called it Train Fever as you can also add buses and trams but anyway, however, the game is very clunky and sometimes annoying. The train tracks to place them onto the landscape can be the most annoying bit of the game, this also includes bus stops and tram linesAlso, the game can be very annoying with the transport AI. I built a massive train system and thankfully it worked very well and made a lot of income, however, when I requested a train to go into a depot, it completely went onto a different line and completely ruined the train service (just like the Tube) and everything stopped making the game compeltely unplayable...Another thing which bugged me was the level of difficulty. The game is not easy and you would end up bankrupt immediately if not selective. Of course I understand that the game has to have some challenge but you can fail instantly if you muck up somethingTrain Fever also gives you absolutely no tutorial, it just throws you into the game and makes you read a long boring tutorial... no. Also, when placing the train tracks especially, the game's framerate chugs like hell, so much so, I have to stop and wait for the game to regain the framerates to make it even playable. Also, the game freezed for a couple of seconds to autosave which can be annoyingHowever, the game does have a fantastic level amount of detail. From the trains, to the house, people and cars and landscape, this also includes the sound effects, especially the train sound effects. The music on the other hand, isn't that greatI knew that the developers wanted to make a very good Transport Tycoon game but did not manage completely but tried. Thankfully they gave away free DLC which takes place in USA and they are developing a sequel to Train Fever called Transport Fever which I have high hopes forTrain Fever is a mixed bag when it comes to purchasing, I am in the middle when it comes to recommending it or not. I highly suggest that for this game you check out some reviews and gameplay videos before considering purchasing, but overall, Train Fever isn't that bad! RECOMMENDED :)

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Great game with lots of potential (mods!). However, there are also some very weird, random, and obvious shortcomings (some are really really annoying) in this game, such as:- No real tutorial available, while the game has a steep learning curve.- No background sounds available, which is a big shortcoming!- No clear way to tell where people want to go to/work/leasure, which requires a lot of expensive trial and error. Use the Traffic Giant method by showing through colors where people work. Now only a 'Land Use' map is available, but it doesn't mean people actually work next door (why have a transportation simulator otherwise).- No minimap in the game, a big shortcoming with the huge maps.- When you have many lines, it becomes very hard to distinguish where lines are headed on different tracks, especially when you are colorblind. Would be better if you could highlight certain lines more clearly.- Very few vehicles available in the game, although modders are working to change that- You can construct railway crossings over roads, but not the other way around, which is SUPER ANNOYING- Only straight railway stations? Really?? - Upgrading railway stations is incredibly annoying- Depots are one way only, which is terrible in case you have to replace a train in late game. Drive through depots are more realistic, and much better.- For some weird reasons,you cannot construct "X" crossovers for rails, only Y mergers, which is very annoying when you merge a lot of rails. "X" crossovers are part of elemental train track design, and leaving it out is completely random and not well thought out.- They should have made it easier to make flyovers. Making realistic flyovers is very hard due to the way the bridge pillars are implemented. Tunnels should be easier to make, too.- No way to customize the paint schemes of the trains. Devs say this is for reaslisms sake (while oddly not incorporating any realistic logos), however in real life, trains have been in different color schemes all the time in different decades (e.g. german trains) or special schemes. The trains are also a random collection of german/swiss/austrian trains, which makes the lack of paint schemes even more weird and unrealistic.It just seems to me that the devs didn't really think it through that much. However, despite these shortcomings, it is still a great game to play. Lets hope that the mods or devs will alleviate these weird shortcomings soon. Some pros:- It looks great- Trains are nice (especially steam trains!)- Runs smoothly for me so far (Retina Macbook Pro, with nVidia card, with Bootcamp), no crashes or bugs to speak of- Give it a few weeks/months when some mods have arrived, and it will be even more awesome.

												I personally enjoy train fever, i picked this game up just after the big update they released that optimised the game very well, however in the late game there is a bit of lag at the end of each month due to there being so much things going on in the game. my only downfall with the game is the lack of content, yes the content is good quality and there is a free usa dlc to download which is basically a big overhaul to the game and changes everything into their american equivalent. however there are only three types of transport in this game: Buses, trams and trains, personally i have found the trams useless and just use buses every time. content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Don't get me wrong; The game looks great, and I waited for this for over a year.The modelling is great and I love the general idea. The maps are too small. 16 cities? I understand the game is using a lot of resources due to excellent graphics but I am used to Simutrans maps with 200+ towns. I have gone back to playing Simutrans so many times because it feels so much more in depth. The cargo system is too narrow. One type of carriage can carry several types of cargo in many cases (Simutrans has this)The names of towns are English but the rolling stock is Swiss/German at least without mods. I did not see any language button. I know German but my Steam account is in English and I would love to change the language, if that changed the names of the towns.. The scheduling garage/depot system from Cities in Motion 2 was good in certain ways, would love to see some improved version implemented in Transport Fever or some other game;You have a x number of maximum units that can be utilised on a lineDepots have units/rolling stock and lines assigned to themScheduling was done on a week basis (more passengers mon-fri rush hour, less at night etc)Maybe I am just grumpy and have not given it a proper chance.. I doubt I will, im afraid.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												Let's start with cons. I hate the cargo system. First of all, it works on demand, not on supply, which is an economical error. Second of all, it's buggy as hell. Several times happened to me that a cargo line was used for half a year and then it became unused for no reason and would remain unused unless I changed line's options. (Point A to B switched into point B to point A and everything came back to normal for another half of year). This is really irritating since cargo lanes are the main source of money.The third thing is the variety of vehicles in the game feels really narrow. You start with two trains in XIX century, maybe fifteen trains in XX century and a couple of new ones in XXI century. This many trains should be available in only XIX century at least. Forth thing is this game is unbalanced. Providing goods to towns is less profitable than providing goods to factories which is totally incorrect. Moreover, on hard mode providing goods to towns with trains is money wasted, because there's no way to make any profit out of it. Some vehicles are highly profitable, while others are just garbage.Well, about pros. They are still developing this game so hopefully all of this will get sorted out.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												A swiss company tried to do the next "Transport Tycoon", but they are not Chris Sawyer  (the creator of the Transport Tycoon games) and now we are not in the 90's.The result? They built a slow-at-the-end tiny-map game that at maximum is a communter train simulator for a middle-sized city in a incredibly boring map. Graphics, other than trains, are simply "meh". Plus, you do by far more revenue with buses (in a game called "TRAIN fever") that with trains, even more, you go bankrupcy with trains if they are no 100% full all the time and only 5 years old.What has gone wrong? Easy, Chris Sawyer developed the original game using a programming language called "Assembler" that allowed him to juice ALL the resources of the computer at that time so the result was amaizing. The swiss team but used a 3D engine base, that also is based in tons of another programs, so they had little control of where the resources of the computer are spent. Actually is not their fault, the 3D simulation and its level of freedom of possibilities is by far more complex than the 2D graphics of the original game plus using that kind of programs is a normal choice by small software companies.What to do? Play OpenTTD (it's FREE), and if you love it, help it to fund a better graphics patch. That's all.Finally, please note that is simply impossible to do a decent high-scale 3D transport game, too many resources spent for a game that will be used by not a big chunk of people (hoping that I'm wrong about that last sentence).

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												Perhaps now that this game is officially abandonware my review won't get downvoted by frosty-eyed shills.I deleted my first review because some time after I posted it I presumed it would be long out of date. Unfortunately the game remains unfinished, now officially abandoned, with many important features for creating a network such as simple crossovers are left out, many promised features abandoned such as content expansions along with further support for a game that is still pretty broken. The engine seems to have been unfinished or unsuitable from the start, an inability to cross roads over rail is something which apparently can't be fixed. The building system is frustrating, the game is feature lite, the whole experience has been frustrating.I wanted to like this game, much of my play time is idle time spent minimised while I while away frustration in order to give the game more chances. Maybe buy this game on sale for a fiver if you really want to♥♥♥♥♥♥♥out playing trains and you keep wishing there was something more modern than Railroad Tycoon or OTTD. DO NOT get burned for full price like I was foolish enough to be.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												Very nice graphics and enjoyable to play. In an older version trucks could transport ore to a refinery then pick up goods to take back to town. Very useful if, like me, you have a map where your raw materials and refinery are on opposite sides of the town. However this is no longer the case and I lose a lot of money with empty trucks having to run a long distance to return to a goods pickup. This and little niggles like this ruin this game for me. It isnt all I hoped it to be. I really hoped it would be a more up to date version of Transport Tycoon (one of my all time favorites).I have to give this a thumbs down until these little things get resolved (and I hope they do).Would I recommend this to someone? Not at the moment I wouldnt ..no.Update: No updates have been made available for this game. It seems the developers have abandoned it. It is a shame as it had the potential to be a good game, a really good game. All There is left for me to do now is say save your money and go find something else. What a great, great pity..

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
TL;DR: Buy on sale, and only on saleWhen I first bought this game and played ~3 hours, I was enthralled. This game had reignited a passion for trains (steam trains especially) that I hadn't had since I was 10. The game immersed me in a potent mixture of nostalgia and wonder. I recommended the game based on these feelings. Another ~5 hours later and the illusion of wonder has worn off. The cracks have begun to show, and now I understand why reviews are mixed. Because the game is essentially a mixed bag - here's why.My specs I've been playing this on are:Intel Core i5 @2.5GHz8GB RAMIntel HD 4000 Graphics (mobile)I'm gaming on my subpar school laptop. The game actually doesn't look bad on the lowest settings. Stutters a bit when zoomed completely out and viewing the full map, but as long as I don't zoom out completely, it plays pretty well. Props to the game for that. Moving on: the gameplay - you build bus routes to ferry your passengers around inside cities, build train stations in these cities to connect cities to each other, and watch as the passengers line up at the station, begging to be allowed onto one of your fancy railroad cars. Add sidings, loops, or even another whole length of track to allow more trains to ferry your passengers between towns. Expand to another town, repeat the process! Dig tunnels and build bridges! (you even get to choose your kind of bridge truss!) Add more cars to your trains and upgrade them as technology advances with time! Cargo trains are much trickier (based on what gameplay I have they seem more like a late-game feature), though they are much more complex than simply connecting passenger lines together. Hook up different industries and resources like coal mines, ore mines, sawmills, and more and connect them to goods manufacturers like oil refineries, lumber yards, and more! Pay off your initial starting loan and make millions! Sounds great, right? Well, it is. What ruins the experience in the long-run is the UI.The first (and biggest) mistake the game makes is lumping all your bus and RR lines for all cities into ONE management window. Doesn't seem like a big deal, right? Not at first. But it becomes really frustrating later on when I'm trying to see which bus lines correspond to which railroad lines, which ones are running cargo, and why some bus lines are losing money. Every line is numbered. So if I create two bus lines in three different cities, and then connected two of the cities with one RR line, it would look like (ignoring the parenthesis and the words inside parenthesis):LINE 1 (bus line city 1)LINE 2 (bus line city 2)LINE 3 (bus line city 3)LINE 4 (railroad line for city 1-city 2)Yes, each line is color-coded, but that doesn't significantly alleviate the problem. Additionally, the way line numbers are listed, it's extremely wonky. Say I have 30 bus and railroad lines. The game will list the lines as follows:LINE 1LINE 11LINE 12LINE 13[...]LINE 19LINE 2LINE 20LINE 21[...]LINE 29LINE 3LINE 30THIS IS HOW TRAIN FEVER NUMBERS ITS LINES!!! It becomes a logistical nightmare to manage your trains. Make no mistake, large corporations can be bureaucratic minefields to one degree or another, but Train Fever takes it to an unreasonable level. The other major part of my beef with this game is the laying of track. Specifically, train stations. So I want to have a passenger station and, the way I was planning it, I was going to have a cargo train directly across from the passenger station. No biggie, right? WRONG, WRONG WRONG!!!> try to build cargo station directly across from passenger station with tracks in between> TF hates me> lay down second line of track and over a road just outside of where planned stations will be> creates two-line railroad crossing> still can't build cargo station without the game raging on me> give up after 45 minutes> try to delete one of the lines crossing the road> TF wants me to delete both> rage> begrudgingly delete double-RR crossing> try to lay down new track to reconnect original passenger station> Unable to place track> Rage> delete road> able to lay track > try to repave road> Unable to pave over track, you must build track after paving road> RAGEOn that note, the game will seemingly at random not want to place track in a given spot or create a split line for whatever reason. It's frustrating when it seems it happens for no good reason.I bought this over winter sale for 80% off ($6 USD). That's all it's worth.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												I was on the fence for a bit as to if I should purchase this. The mixed reviews made me cautious, but experience has told me that some of the worst rated games have been the most enjoying to me personally, so I've learned to ignore them (for the most part). I bring to you now a cautionary tale of my journey. Day 1: I took the plunge and bought the game. Being a conductor for Union Pacific, I have a good idea of how railroads work. This game caught me by surprise. Everything in the game world is modeled realistically. Everything from the trains, industries, supply/demand, and even the individual people who walk on the street have a home, a work place, and a leisurely activity location. Day 2: I made a large map with some hills using the USA DLC. I built a passenger line from San Diego to Temecula, the year is 1850. I enjoy the little steam engines and the simpler way of life. Horses moved my little village people to and fro. And I was satisfied. Day 3: I've been up all night trying to establish a profitable passenger connection to Modesto and refine and upgrade my rail network to incorporate and support newer rolling stock and locomotives. My wife says I've been on the computer too much. Day 7: My wife is worried, she says I haven't spoken to her in days. In more important matters, I've recently connected the San Diego oil fields with an oil production site. I've linked it's distribution to San Diego, Temecula, and Minniapolis - effectively shutting down and putting the local lumber company out of business. I feel invincible. Day 12: I've lost my real life job. I've found that my virtual empire needs me more. The year is now 1950 and my rail empire now spans over a dozen cities with a conglamoration of rolling stock with newer as well as vintage locomotives plying the lines. I've established a second oil field in the town of Houston, which now distributes to over 7 outlying cities. Day 21: My wife has left me and taken my 2 year old son. Now that I have some peace and quiet, I can continue my domination of the digital world. My diet now consists of purple coolaid and stockpiled beef jerky that I kept getting for christmas. Day 30: My body is weak, I smell, I'm hungry, and the sunlight coming through the window hurts my eyes. But in other news, the year is now 2025 and there are but 2 cities left to conquer. They have remained untouched due to their inaccessible locations at high elevations. I plan to conquer them with trucks and busses and then tie them into the rail network. Day 42: I have achieved perfection. Every road and rail network is upgraded. Every line is profitable. Every train is properly balanced. Day 43: I've ventured out into the real world again. My body resembles that of a holocaust victim. I decided to go to Subway for a bite to eat. Standing in line, gazing at the menu, I decided to order a foot-long steak and cheese sandwich. As I sat down, I could hardly wait to bite into the sandwich. As my teeth sank into it's toasted, warm, and soft outer buns, a tear rolled down my cheek - not because I had forgotten how good real food tasted, but because I had remembered that I had forgotten to upgrade the old railroad crossing in San Diego. 11/10 I would buy this again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												TLDR: while it looks great and has a wide variety of trains to choose from, especially thanks to mods, it is just not a great game and the DEV's are moving on to another game. I mostly played this game earlier, before the US update, but I reinstalled it some time afterwards and gave it another shot. Not that much appears to have changed, which is disappointing, as there are still quite a few things that could be improved. They promise they will keep supporting this one at least for a while, but major updates probably won't be forthcoming. I'm expecting only some bugfixes, not added content or changed mechanics. Such a shame. It is, in many ways, a decent game. There are also various mods which improve the game even further. But it is certainly not a great game. It really showed a lot of promise and might have ended up as a much better game than even Railroad Tycoon or any of its successors, never mind Transport Tycoon. Now my hope for that is fading fast. So not recommended, unless you're a hardcore train fanatic, eager to play anything to do with trains.Long version: there are many good things about this game. It looks pretty great. It allows you to play with trains and road transport alike. It allows you to build a transport network across a map, connecting various cities and industries, which evolve and grow as you play. New trains and vehicles are unlocked with time. You can play with European or US buildings. It can be a lot of fun to lay out a track and watch your trains, even high speed TGVs, race across them. Unfortunately, the flaws of the game are very distracting.Track laying is often anything but intuitive. There are a few guides on how to create overpasses and the like, but that kind of thing should be easy to do and it isn't. It often feels as if you're wrestling the game, to try and trick it and get it to do what you want it to do. I've had episodes where the game kept telling me something couldn't be done, or where tunnels ended up coming out just wrong so I had to relay track that then didn't match up, costing me literally millions or whatever coin is used in game, bankrupting my company so I had to restart from a save game. Sometimes I was just trying to lay track alongside of existing track, or turn a single track bridge into a two track bridge and the game just wouldn't cooperate. Why is there no option to lay out track, check if it is the right way, THEN confirm to actually lay the track? How about an undo option? Sometimes you try to lay track and the game things it is easier to carve down a hill, costing you millions, instead of just building a tunnel. Although there is something to be said for the feeling of being victorious when I managed to do something that the game had absolutely refused to cooperate with, even told me repeatedly that it couldn't be done, I highly doubt that any game should be made that way and that people would want to play a game that worked like that.I also ran into trouble trying to get my trains to pass each other at a crossing. They ended up stopped, again costing me millions before I was able to fix it or forcing me to go back to an earlier save. Just when you think you've laid it out properly, a train stops, for no apparent reason and just turns back, headed the wrong way, all the way to the other side of the map, only losing money in the process. This game really should be able to use signals in a proper and realistic way. But even trying to create proper switches or points (intersections) is next to impossible. When I think I've managed to do exactly what I wanted, they end up confusing my trains so much they just stop altogether or start running on the wrong track. This is a game that tries to appeal to train enthusiasts, the trams and road vehicles seem to be thrown in as an extra, but it doesn't even get the train thing right. All in all, it feels unfinished.Some things are really still pretty basic. You can't create a map from scratch or adjust the random map in any way. So no placing industries, creating or deleting villages, nothing. Adjusting the settings un such a manner as to make it as flat as possible still results in a map with significant hills, so I can forget playing on a map that even remotely resembles my native country, never mind create an exact replica of an existing area, no matter how small, as the maps are also still pretty small even at the largest settings. The game inclused road vehicles in addition to rail vehicles, but don't include either water or air transport at all. This makes no sense and further limits the opportunities in the game.Improving or deleting streets is also quite difficult. Some options, like highways, don't even exist. Other options don't work very well, as you quickly end up having to destroy entire buildings, at great expense. In the end, you still end up with gridlock, with no clear way of getting people to get out of their cars, to take public transport. I have a sneaking suspicion that the AI that governs where people want to go is very, very basic and very, very flawed. That makes a game like this pretty much pointless, as instead of a realistic and challenging transport network, you end up having to play along with some obscure rules.When I played earlier, there were several serious issues, that should not have been allowed to exist in a released game. At one point, I ended up with several corrupted savegames, at another I was completely unable to remove sections of road as they were deemed to be an essential connection, despite them not leading anywhere. I haven't played the current release of the game long enough to be sure, but I haven't encountered them again and am willing to give them the benefit of the doubt and assume both are fixed now. However, it says something about the state the game was in when I bought it and the level of Quality Control that these flaws were in a released game in the first place. So what hope do I have that their next game will be released in a better state? Why would I preorder that one, or buy it at full price, or even at all, based on this experience?This game comes pretty close to being great however, which makes it all the more sad. With the Developers moving onto another game, there won't be as much support as there was, so all hope of this game being improved to be all that it could ever be, seems lost. It is not terrible, but it is certainly not great. It has something for enthusiasts, but mostly because of how little competition there has been in this field in the past few years. It leaves me feeling disappointed and sad, eager for more. And yet it could have been so much more and seemingly without too much effort. I've seen some interesting suggestions on the community hub and if the publisher changed its mind and came out with a solid update, that would fix the remaining flaws of the game and expand on its possibilities, I might even be persuaded to buy it. Something that I would do with reluctance, as it is still rewarding a company for releasing an unfinished game, but if it was good enough, I'd be willing to set that aside. They have people to feed too and moreover, I really want a game like this, only better. Just a bit better. I get the impression the developers were disappointed too, that they were too ambitious and now want to wash their hands of this game and move onto the real thing. But that would be wrong. Not only because they risk losing the trust of their customers forever, but also because they pass up the opportunity of making something really impressive out of this. They should invest in this game and really build it into a flagship product, show us what they really can do. Then keep releasing expansions. Then move onto the next engine and improve the game even further. They could milk us for years. How is that for a marketing strategy?

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												UPDATE 2: It got worse. Much worse. After some time, I decided to play this game again. And I have to say, despite all the updates, the performance (lags, stutters, freezes) and graphic issues (flicker, things popping up from nowhere, screen turning black for a second) made this game unenjoyable, unplayable even. At least for me, I hope not everybody has the same issues.....UPDATE 1: With the addition of waypoints, it just crossed my personal threshold to be recommendable. One can clearly see that it got and still gets better!This game has huge potential but it fails to deliver. I played for a couple of hours and it was a constant back and forth between like and dislike. I really, really, try to like this game and although I somehow do, I can not recommend it in its current state.PROs The look and feel. It is a pleasure to look at the cities and vehicles. The dynamic city grow. Modding support. The fact that the devs have a post-release plan. Setting up lines is easy and enjoyable, it gives this "let me optimize that line even more" feeling. Every type of vehicle (road, tram, train) has its purpose. Real Swiss trains!CONs Poor performance, it constantly stops for a fraction of a second, especially if you follow vehicles. Build tracks and roads is a pain. "Collisions" and "Terrain alignment" all the time, even if you can see that there is nothing in the way. Lines get messed up randomly (e.g. inserted loops around the block). Vehicles can grid-lock themselves. Train networking is very limited (no train crossings, no 3-way switches, no cross-switches, a line is using only one track at a train station even if there are other free ones, signal usage limited).I think the CONs are fixable. If that happens, it will double, if not triple, the fun of this game!

So no placing industries, creating or deleting villages, nothing. Adjusting the settings un such a manner as to make it as flat as possible still results in a map with significant hills, so I can forget playing on a map that even remotely resembles my native country, never mind create an exact replica of an existing area, no matter how small, as the maps are also still pretty small even at the largest settings. Other options don't work very well, as you quickly end up having to destroy entire buildings, at great expense. In the end, you still end up with gridlock, with no clear way of getting people to get out of their cars, to take public transport. I have a sneaking suspicion that the AI that governs where people want to go is very, very basic and very, very flawed. That makes a game like this pretty much pointless, as instead of a realistic and challenging transport network, you end up having to play along with some obscure rules.When I played earlier, there were several serious issues, that should not have been allowed to exist in a released game. At one point, I ended up with several corrupted savegames, at another I was completely unable to remove sections of road as they were deemed to be an essential connection, despite them not leading anywhere. I haven't played the current release of the game long enough to be sure, but I haven't encountered them again and am willing to give them the benefit of the doubt and assume both are fixed now. However, it says something about the state the game was in when I bought it and the level of Quality Control that these flaws were in a released game in the first place. 												Graphically the game is awesome to look at. If only the UI and gameplay were anything close to Transport Tycoon this would have been a success.Instead, the UI is a mess. Just an example: You can build a railway on top of a road, but you cannot build a road on top of a railway?? You have to delete kilometers of railways to place the road and then re-place the railway (which costs a lot) on top to create a crossing??? What?! Why?!Regarding gameplay, industries seem to work randomly. You place a station nearby an industry building, create the line, let vehicles at the station, and sometimes you start getting goods, sometimes your vehicles are stuck waiting for years, with the industry refusing to collaborate for no apparent reason.Could have been much better. We desperetely lack a successor to Transport Tycoon, but this is absolutely not it.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												This game is a diamond in the rough. It's not perfect, but very enjoyable.Pros:+A surprising amount of data is available to you regarding your transit lines. +Generally nice graphics.+Cities grow naturally as you expand infrastructure, a la Cities in Motion.+Two separate campaigns (second one free)Cons:-UI is wonky. Windows pop up everywhere, very inconsistently. -UI needs more scalability.-Music is awful for the setting, at least in regards to the USA map. Doesn't in any way resemble what I would expect for the old west. Iffy:*Campaigns are really just large sandbox maps. Some will love this, some will hate it. Not much in the way of structure.*Can't speak to how accurate train models are. I've played enough train games to know it's in the ballpark. It's not something that's overly important to me, so beyond that I can't say much.*It'd be nice if there were more interaction with the cities, a la Railroad Tycoon 3. A little more interaction with industry.-Tutorial is... less than great. If you don't have a basic grasp of these sort of games, you'll probably be lost.I know I nitpicked, but I really do enjoy this game. It's Railroad Tycoon meets Cities in Motion. If that sounds like your bag, definitely check it out!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												Okay I am a bit of an expert in the Transportation Managment Simulation genre and I have to say this game is one of the best (at least until Transport Fever is release later this year) that I've played so far.  Coming from games like Chirs Sawyer's Transport Tycoon (1993) and Railroad Tycoon 3 (2003?) this one is a little more challenging right out of the gate.  The economy is very well implemented.  The longer your company has been around the easier it is to expand, and the easier it is to make money.  Sure there are still a few problems with upgrading things and sure cronstrution is a little wonky, but those are small beans compared to how much fun the game is.  There hours of replayability with this game and it is well worth the $30.  Plus the USA DLC is free.  There is no reason not to buy this game.

content:
Posted: April 14
												It's a bit frustrating in places but I think I probably got my money's worth. It's got the core of a decent transport tycoon type game, and certainly looks nice.My issues are the fairly well documented ones everyone has: It ends up running a bit slow later on - there's a lot to calculate and I don't think it does it very efficiently. The train pathfinding is a bit of a nightmare - they only go via one route and don't use extra platforms and multiple tracks efficiently - so it's very easy to end up with unjustified congestion. The industrial model (nothing is produced unless there's a complete supply/demand chain in place, and only that exact amount is produced) is a unintuitive and a little rigid. Once you understand it it's completely possible to work with it, but it still seems like a pain. It does seem like there should be some flexibility with prices dropping as demand is fulfilled.So I did enjoy playing it (once I'd got the hang of it's unneccessarily fiddly bits) but I ended up with no great desire to investigate the sequel.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												TLDR: while it looks great and has a wide variety of trains to choose from, especially thanks to mods, it is just not a great game and the DEV's are moving on to another game. I mostly played this game earlier, before the US update, but I reinstalled it some time afterwards and gave it another shot. Not that much appears to have changed, which is disappointing, as there are still quite a few things that could be improved. They promise they will keep supporting this one at least for a while, but major updates probably won't be forthcoming. I'm expecting only some bugfixes, not added content or changed mechanics. Such a shame. It is, in many ways, a decent game. There are also various mods which improve the game even further. But it is certainly not a great game. It really showed a lot of promise and might have ended up as a much better game than even Railroad Tycoon or any of its successors, never mind Transport Tycoon. Now my hope for that is fading fast. So not recommended, unless you're a hardcore train fanatic, eager to play anything to do with trains.Long version: there are many good things about this game. It looks pretty great. It allows you to play with trains and road transport alike. It allows you to build a transport network across a map, connecting various cities and industries, which evolve and grow as you play. New trains and vehicles are unlocked with time. You can play with European or US buildings. It can be a lot of fun to lay out a track and watch your trains, even high speed TGVs, race across them. Unfortunately, the flaws of the game are very distracting.Track laying is often anything but intuitive. There are a few guides on how to create overpasses and the like, but that kind of thing should be easy to do and it isn't. It often feels as if you're wrestling the game, to try and trick it and get it to do what you want it to do. I've had episodes where the game kept telling me something couldn't be done, or where tunnels ended up coming out just wrong so I had to relay track that then didn't match up, costing me literally millions or whatever coin is used in game, bankrupting my company so I had to restart from a save game. Sometimes I was just trying to lay track alongside of existing track, or turn a single track bridge into a two track bridge and the game just wouldn't cooperate. Why is there no option to lay out track, check if it is the right way, THEN confirm to actually lay the track? How about an undo option? Sometimes you try to lay track and the game things it is easier to carve down a hill, costing you millions, instead of just building a tunnel. Although there is something to be said for the feeling of being victorious when I managed to do something that the game had absolutely refused to cooperate with, even told me repeatedly that it couldn't be done, I highly doubt that any game should be made that way and that people would want to play a game that worked like that.I also ran into trouble trying to get my trains to pass each other at a crossing. They ended up stopped, again costing me millions before I was able to fix it or forcing me to go back to an earlier save. Just when you think you've laid it out properly, a train stops, for no apparent reason and just turns back, headed the wrong way, all the way to the other side of the map, only losing money in the process. This game really should be able to use signals in a proper and realistic way. But even trying to create proper switches or points (intersections) is next to impossible. When I think I've managed to do exactly what I wanted, they end up confusing my trains so much they just stop altogether or start running on the wrong track. This is a game that tries to appeal to train enthusiasts, the trams and road vehicles seem to be thrown in as an extra, but it doesn't even get the train thing right. All in all, it feels unfinished.Some things are really still pretty basic. You can't create a map from scratch or adjust the random map in any way. So no placing industries, creating or deleting villages, nothing. Adjusting the settings un such a manner as to make it as flat as possible still results in a map with significant hills, so I can forget playing on a map that even remotely resembles my native country, never mind create an exact replica of an existing area, no matter how small, as the maps are also still pretty small even at the largest settings. The game inclused road vehicles in addition to rail vehicles, but don't include either water or air transport at all. This makes no sense and further limits the opportunities in the game.Improving or deleting streets is also quite difficult. Some options, like highways, don't even exist. Other options don't work very well, as you quickly end up having to destroy entire buildings, at great expense. In the end, you still end up with gridlock, with no clear way of getting people to get out of their cars, to take public transport. I have a sneaking suspicion that the AI that governs where people want to go is very, very basic and very, very flawed. That makes a game like this pretty much pointless, as instead of a realistic and challenging transport network, you end up having to play along with some obscure rules.When I played earlier, there were several serious issues, that should not have been allowed to exist in a released game. At one point, I ended up with several corrupted savegames, at another I was completely unable to remove sections of road as they were deemed to be an essential connection, despite them not leading anywhere. I haven't played the current release of the game long enough to be sure, but I haven't encountered them again and am willing to give them the benefit of the doubt and assume both are fixed now. However, it says something about the state the game was in when I bought it and the level of Quality Control that these flaws were in a released game in the first place. So what hope do I have that their next game will be released in a better state? Why would I preorder that one, or buy it at full price, or even at all, based on this experience?This game comes pretty close to being great however, which makes it all the more sad. With the Developers moving onto another game, there won't be as much support as there was, so all hope of this game being improved to be all that it could ever be, seems lost. It is not terrible, but it is certainly not great. It has something for enthusiasts, but mostly because of how little competition there has been in this field in the past few years. It leaves me feeling disappointed and sad, eager for more. And yet it could have been so much more and seemingly without too much effort. I've seen some interesting suggestions on the community hub and if the publisher changed its mind and came out with a solid update, that would fix the remaining flaws of the game and expand on its possibilities, I might even be persuaded to buy it. Something that I would do with reluctance, as it is still rewarding a company for releasing an unfinished game, but if it was good enough, I'd be willing to set that aside. They have people to feed too and moreover, I really want a game like this, only better. Just a bit better. I get the impression the developers were disappointed too, that they were too ambitious and now want to wash their hands of this game and move onto the real thing. But that would be wrong. Not only because they risk losing the trust of their customers forever, but also because they pass up the opportunity of making something really impressive out of this. They should invest in this game and really build it into a flagship product, show us what they really can do. Then keep releasing expansions. Then move onto the next engine and improve the game even further. They could milk us for years. How is that for a marketing strategy?

number of helpful: 17 of 36 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												Sometimes a product is launched as a "sequel" that only serves to remind you how brilliant the original was. Train Fever is obviously inspired by Transport Tycoon (Deluxe) and/or its opensource version, OpenTTD.Both games use a simple grid system with sprites and to put it midly, the graphics look dated. Train Fever obviously ups the stakes in the graphics department and when it runs, it looks pretty decent. But nobody played openTTD for years for the graphics, it was/is the gameplay, refined through years of development, that kept people coming back.Does Train Fever compare well to an ancient game, the most common player version available for free? No.First off, this game is closer to TT then OpenTTD, it is a common problem for a new game that is based on an existing game, it tends to lack the refinement, content and bug squashing its pre-decessor went through. When Locomotion came out, the official sequel, people liked the improved graphics but were less enthused by essentially taking a step back in time with regards to features.To put it in a nutshell, Train Fever feels like a lightweight TT when I have gotten used to the heavyweight OpenTTD. But why does this game remind me how brilliant Chris Sawyer is. Error messages. You will see a lot of them in Train Fever and they will drive you up the wall. Some are to due with the terain and it shows how brilliant Sawyers decission was to go for a simple grid. Sure it looks ugly but you always know what you are doing and building tunnels and bridges is a breeze. Not so in train fever.Another is bridge building, Sawyer simply saw pillars are graphical niceties, who cares if they are to far apart, it is gameplay that matters. Train fever insists every bridge pillar is in the right place and therefor building a bridge over anything at all is extremely error prone. Realistic I hear you say? Not really, if in the real world a rail bridge has to cross another track at an angle, engineers simply place two pillars on each side of the track, put a crossbeam on top and the bridge on top of that. Job done. The Dutch rail network has plenty of examples of these fly-overs (way to cross a track without blocking the other track).That is Train Fevers biggest failure, the desinger thinks error messages beat gameplay. No you can't cross this road at a right angle, BECAUSE! No, we can't space the pillars differently, BECAUSE! In OpenTTD if you run into trouble with lost trains, you can build track in front of the train to lead them back. In train fever, you can't build track close to a train, can't change or delete signals close to a train, the stop/reverse buttons are on a seperate tab from the route assign and find depot depot, Once ytou do manage to place a depot close to a train, it can't find it.I have had to cancel several games by now because of trains completely stuck and overlapping each other. Routes you define get changed randomly, the slightest hickup sees trains going off in all directions, try to manage it with signals and trains get stuck. You can't force a train to move or ignore a red light, nor do signals show a red light. Trains do occasionally drive through each other.Missing features that really should be in the game and bug that shouldn't: Industry is far to simplistic with just 2 chains (ore/cole -> goods) (wood->goods) goods can be deliverd to a city. Industry seeder is to random, one map with one forest, four sawmills.Industry often produces no raw material, only way to build a semi reliable network is to watch the flow of existing cargo and move goods faster. Simply building a route yourself will not startup production.Stations, even if grouped do not share cargo, so your truck dock is overflowing but your train runs empty.It takes two click to select track layer, if you are destroying track,it is just an extra hassle that doesn't need to exist.Building road bridges is near impossible, you can't simply build a road, force it to go up and create a bridge, it creates a hell of a mess, if you even manage to get the "collision" type error messages to go away. Building shortt tunnels to dive under a track is a similar mess.Despite claims of wanting to fix the economy, which in TT is broken in that passenger traffic pays of most of all, this game again makes passenger traffic the most rewarding. The better you connect the cities, the more pasengers, the same does not go for cargo. You can have full trains with a simple route, cargo trains take decades in game years to build up to few wagons.Signals are very basic.No visual indication for signals as to their state, signals are to small to see and their icon does not show what direction they are pointing in. Despite the game using routes (the game shows a ribbon for your train routes over the track, they SHOULD only follow thar route, you can't easily change it, there is for instance no way to force a train to a certain platform or to take a certain route) trains easily get lost and end in all the wrong places, often staring each other down nose to nose each refusing to move. Route finding is extremely iffy and trains can't pick their own individual routes, no mixing fast and slow trains and having them overtake each other. Or another train arriving on one platform as another on the same route is leaving.In OpenTTD, I scoff at players that only create simple routes, a train station at each end, each route on their own seperate track. I love making big complex networks getting enjoyment out of creating stations with half a dozen trains entering and leaving at once.Forget about that in Train Fever. The game as it is now is an interesting project but the developer needs to hire someone who is less anal retentive about perceived reality and introduces some much need "game" into the engine.Maybe if the game gets picked up by the openttd developers or this developer plays that game and learns something, it will improve but right now, only buy this game if you got a very high frustration tolerance.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												I want to like this game, I really do, but it just won't let me.For the most part, this is a great train game. The graphics are nice, laying track is well done, i like the map generator. And you can build some reasonably complex rail networks.However, this game badly needs some code optimization. Once you build up your rail network a little bit.. enough that you're covering 4 or 5 cities, the performance takes a serious nose-dive and the game becomes unplayable. Every in-game month the game has to calculate & apply the expenses for all your vehicles. Once youve got more than 30 or 40 vehicles, this process locks the game up for a good minute or more, if you grind through that enough to get up to 60 or 70 vehicles, the game will lock up for over 2 minutes while it calculates your monthly expenses. Couple this with the fact that it does this every game month, which is about 5 minutes IRL, you'll spend approx 30 to 40% of your playtime looking at a frozen mouse pointer. Ugh..And thats not necessarily a huge rail network. Maps have about a dozen cities in them, but you wont get to more than 1/3rd of them before the game becomes unplayable.And from the looks of it, there are no plans to develop this game further. So it's likely to stay broken.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Now I'm a fan of the Railroad Tycoon franchise and OpenTTD and I was really looking forward to enjoying this game. The first experience was horrible. The text was all fuzzy and barely readable on a Win10 4k resolution. That problem went away after I restarted the game, however the mouse pointer was restricted to 3/4 of the screen. Lowering the resolution at that point didn't fix it, playing in a window did.The game lacks a tutorial. It lacks a campain. You're just thrown in the game on your own. It's unbelievable how unpolished the UI is in this game. It really feels like splatted buttons and text by a novice. Laying rail track is a pain. Raising a road to create a bridge over rail tracks is easy, but that is a whole different ball game for rail bridges over roads. Go figure.I kept going though, looking at guides and reading forums. But I immediately stopped playing and asked for a refund when I realized that every time the game was computing the finances and displaying the maintenance cost for 3 !!! running vehicles froze the game for a fraction of a second on a 6 core I7 and a 980TI. I'm a software developer and I immediately understood that the simulation is running on a single thread. If this was happening in the first hour of playing the game, imagine what it would be like later on in the game.UPDATE: Digging into the forums, this is indeed one of the top complaints: http://www.train-fever.com/forums/topic/req-multithreading-performance-issu-large-map/ It becomes unplayable later on in the game or on a large map.Don't believe the excuse that synchronizing resource access in a multi-threaded app is killing its performance. If the code is done right, and the synchronization primitives are being used correctly, you'll get a cool working game with nicely balanced work loads on all the available CPU cores and even on the GPU compute cores. If things get too hectic and the load reaches a high threshold value, the code can simply lower the simulation speed or coarse grain the steps in order to compensate, but still run tasks in parallel. Nowadays, there is no excuse for not fully taming the power we've got in our computers. Multi-core CPUs weren't invented yesterday!The graphics are nice, that's the only positive about the game. The developers simply stopped short of finishing the game and moved on to DLCs and future titles. Or I could give them the benefit of the doubt and say that they lacked the skill. Simulations are not easy to get right.
