content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Train Fever is a sandbox transport company management game with as many good ideas as flaws, making the experience rather jarring and not entirely recommendable, and certainly not at full price.The main flaws concern the mechanics and the ergonomics of the game. While people often say that such and such game don’t hold your hand, I never felt it truer than in Train Fever. Although prepared, even before purchase, I still had to look up quite a lot of information elsewhere, but this is fun to me, understanding the inner workings and mechanics at play. Sadly, even now it seems to me that some mechanics are still not understood, or at least not fully, making it rather difficult to reach an optimal play style.But the flaws become even more apparent on a higher difficulty level. While the game is perhaps too easy on lower settings, on hard mode the lower profit margins and the limitations of the construction tool require a near perfect play style. It is just plain unfair: cargo is profitable, but not passenger transport. You would think that a vehicle full of people would make a profit, no matter what, and I’m not talking just about trains here, where you could argue that you need more wagons to transport more people and thus improve the profit margins (which doesn’t work by the way: there is a limit to how much a locomotive can pull, and that’s even disregarding the artificial transportation time limit of twenty minutes the game forces upon you). It might have something to do with the travel distance, which gives a bonus to the income of each line, but since it is rather difficult to measure distances (only travel time), it’s hard to judge what line will or will not turn up a profit without testing first, which is not an option with the limited resources of a higher difficulty level. And even then, it doesn’t explain why cargo is always profitable, regardless of travel time or distance.Still, you need both cargo and passenger to improve your cities (and even about that I’m not sure since nothing is explained and there doesn’t seem to be a consensus on the forums about it. Some say its cargo, other passengers, others still argue it is both. I’ve heard it say that’s it’s actually the line usage percentage that is used in city growth but from my experience that wasn’t the case, with cities with lower index actually growing while interconnected ones didn’t budge at all, even over longer periods of time). It would thus seem that people and goods are a must to make a profit later on: as you progress in the game, the running costs of vehicles rise, which means that more passengers or goods are required to make a profit. It is thus my belief that you can screw yourself completely over in this game if you take too slow a start, and don’t develop the cities rapidly.It feels completely unbalanced, with the effect of the player feeling rather limited or the sensation that it comes down to luck. It’s hard to get involved when your impact on the game world feels so loose sometimes.What actually makes the whole ordeal truly worse is the interface. Replacing vehicle is horribly unintuitive and slow, with the game opening dozens of tabs at a time, grinding the game (already in need of performance optimisation) to a halt, regardless of the characteristics of your computer. The construction tool isn’t much better. The way double lanes work isn’t intuitive at all, but it is manageable. Problems arise when trying to get double tracks crossed by other double tracks and so forth, although the difficulty might come from the fidgetiness of the construction tools. It’s not completely broken, and that’s what makes it so aggravating to me. If it was completely broken, I would just stop playing, but since there is always a way to do what I wanted, with a lot of work and patience, I tried.On a final side note, it should be said that the music is fantastic, I did truly enjoy it. Weirdly enough, it somehow felt like it made perfect sense in this game. Still, the value of the game is to hold ones attention for long hours without pause. There is always something to do, always something to improve, to update, new routes to plan, etc. That, to me, is fun, and truly addicting. It’s one of those management games where time just flies by, something that I haven’t experience since my time with the Anno series. It’s just a shame it had to come with so many faults. I grew tired of having to put up with them and just stopped playing after that, feeling disappointed.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												I was hoping this game was going to satisfy my desire to replace Simcity 2013 and Railroad Tycoon II...yes, I said RRT2.  The graphics are mediocre, at best.  Sure, you can zoom in and see people walking around, but you can't do anything productive with a view like that.  The train's AI is completely below standard.  For instance: Picking up oil with one train and dropping it off at a refinery makes "goods" which is the generic demand for towns.  If you use a different locomotive to pick up goods to drop off at a town, then they jam up at the refinery and sit there waiting for eachother to get out of the way.  Signals are useless as they only allow trains to travel in one direction, not wait for a train to move out of the way.  Wood is the only way to make a decent amount of cash and that's only because "wood" and "goods" can utilize the same cars.  There isn't a way to change the consist of any other trains so you need 3 oil cars and 3 goods cars on the same locomotive and 1/2 the train is empty during it's route.In short, the mechanics are garbage compared to an OLD game like RRT2 or even Railroads! which was fun, but wasn't as indepth as RRT2.  As far as the "business" part of the game, it's not even close to Simcity 2013.  The "town" doesn't develop if you pump "goods" to it.  A few buildings pop up, but then they stop after a short while.  I'm assuming it's because the goods aren't getting to the "low value" areas of the town but none of my "cargo" (non-rail) stations are productive as far as money goes.  Yes, they work, but they don't make money because the distance is too far.  In order to rectify this, you can lay rails, but then you're back to square-one with the "not using the same train to transport goods of different types" nonsense.I don't care about graphics when it comes to business simulations (to a point).  I want complexity yet it needs to be intuitive.  This game has neither.  If you can't change consists at a station, then it's impossible to use the same locomotive transport different types of commodities.  If you must have multiple trains on a single rail, then the programmers need to figure out how to make one train wait for another BEFORE they're 2 feet away from eachother.  In real life, companies have yards and spurs....not enough room in this game to do this so "reality" is NOT an excuse for this.This is the first game that I would like a refund for.

Posted: April 29, 2015
												19 minutes in, already gave up.- The interface is terrible. No zoom to cursor. Can't scroll on the screen edges that have menus. This includes all corners, so you can't scoll diagonally.- The cargo system is unrealistic. For example, you have to build truck depots near industries. One of the main advantages of trucks in real life is that they don't require depots or yards - trucks just go from industry dock to industry dock. - There is no good way to visualize the cargo economy. In railroad tycoon, you could switch to a cargo view, which would show you where a good was produced and demanded. In this game, you just have to hunt around until you happen upon two industries that will create a supply chain.- Optimization is abysmal or non-existent. This game is incredibly sluggish, and I have a fairly powerful rig.Looks like it's back to Railroad Tycoon 3 for me.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Not as good as I expected. I've played several versions of Railroad Tycoon, along with SimCity and other transportation and urban simulations, and while this one is pretty and has some enticing features, the overall game play is frustrating.Some positives: It is nice being able to manage transportation within cities and between them. The ability to use buses and trams and not just trains is fun. Detailed reports of how each line and vehicle is doing are nice. The visuals are good. Some negatives: Overall game play is just plain frustrating. In a game like this, the main experience is in setting up routes and connecting things. This game basically ruins this experience. It's not so bad when setting up bus lines, since you are using existing roads, but it totally fails when you start laying railroads. It is almost impossible to get a railroad to cross a road. This appears to be related to grade differences, because typically the tracks are running in a cut or embankment that is above or below the road grade. Why can't the AI just automatically regrade the road so that the two can cross, and add to the railroad cost accordingly. The last thing I want to do is have to fiddle with individually grading road crossings, especially since it is expensive and time consuming and may fail, since even after I'm done, I won't be able to know if the tracks can go there anyway. Industries are a major pain. You are supposed to build a depot next to the industry, and it may or may not begin to fill with some of the goods that otherwise magically travel down the road by other means. After building expensive depots at two industries that should feed into each other and the tracks to connect them, it typcially happens that you watch the goods totally ignore your nice transportation system and continue marching down the road without your assistance. Maybe there is a reason for this--some parameter that needs to be set, some limit on the placement of the depot. But if there is, it is a complete mystery, since there is no documentation that would help you figure it out. Speaking of documentation, this game really lacks it. There is a very basic tutorial at the start, but nothing for the more advanced things you typically would like to try.The game largely feels unfinished and untested, and not worth the rather high price that would be more appropriate for a game that totally works. I love transportation sims, and I laid down a fairly large chunk of cash to buy this. But I'm not playing it. Life is frustrating enough without having a game make it worse.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Update 17.12.2014:After 4 month since release, performance has not been getting better, until today I spent roughly 10 hours of driver management, installs, uninstalls, configuration etc and nothing changed. This company has released a beta status (if not even alpha) as a gold status. Since then, some patches came out but none of the announced performance issues are fixed until today. First game I ever bought by Urban Games / Gamitous and last game I ever will. Same level of dishonest behavior as shown by some of the "big players" but at least they keep their♥♥♥♥♥♥working and concentrate on more subtile ways to mess with thir customers. Initial review: Well, at the moment, this game is way off near to call it release version. Lots of people are experiencing big performance issues and while for issues based on nVidia cards some workarounds already exists, AMD owners are mostly on their own. I tried to get it running in a playable way with the help of 3 forums by now but the only outcome is a frame skipping stutter orgy. This may not a problem if you only want to look on some nice landscape from a distance but as soon as it gets to building something, it's becoming a real pain.Graphics are nice and the features yet given are good (as far as I could see them) but based on the huge performance issue I won't recommend buying it yet. In 2 or 3 month the devs have given the code some serious work it may turn out to be a good game, until then: Buy if you like but don't expect anything else then some "will it run?"-gamble - for some it will work without any issues, others won't even get it started. Also, - may run, may not run, how up to date your rig is does not influence this as it is the code of the game that makes it unstable - even if the graphic is shiny, the landscape looks a bit dead and empty- trainstation not upgradable- no real tutorial, only 2 texts regarding line creation, lots of things not mentioned (signals, passanger capacity, concept of how long passangers are willing to wait for a train etc) - no option to but 2 lane tracks (you have to put 2 1 lane tracks next to each other)+ shiny graphics All in all, unstable alpha build with serious performance issues - but the graphic is shiny! Going to play some RTD2 now ...

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												This game unfortunately feels unfinished and unpolished. It has several issues besides the known problems that with some system configurations  the game often crashes or is completely unplayable. Following the issues I came across and that I feel need to be adressed soon.First off the track laying. One of the most important parts of a game like this is the track laying. However it often is just not working properly. For example on a pefectly flat peace of land the game desides that the track after you crossed a street has to go up and starts building a ramp for no reason. This happens often and leads to the player fiddling around to correct the issue.Another issue is the performance. I do have a good middle class PC where games like X-Rebirth, Guild Wars 2 and Sim City 5 can be perfectly played on almost maximum settings. But with this game even on a small map with medium settings the game often starts to stutter and the mouse lags like hell. This might not sound like a big deal but in fact it is because everyone who does not have an absolute high end gaming rig will not be able to enjoy maps bigger than ones who can accomodate at maximum 4 to 6 bigger towns!Just not to my taste is that you have to start out at a time where horse carriages are the only street cars available. I want to be able to set the start date from the beginning on by myself and as I please. As of now you have to achieve certain goals to open up the options to start at another date.If they fix these issues the game might become enjoyable.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												Played 30 minutes, managed to finish the tutorial but couldn't figure out much else. The last 15 minutes were spent trying to figure out how to delete a train, and how to make it go back to de depot apparently after I added a second train everything ground to a halt and I had no idea how to fix it. Tutorial is extremely short and leaves crucial stuff out.The UI is barely better than classic Transport Tycoon which is 20 yo by now: windows pop under or over others, stuff you need is spread confusingly between multiple tabs. Appears designed for 640x480 screens. Music sounds like elevator music. Can't zoom the map out all the way. Graphics look dated, RRT3 looked way better and it's a 10 year old game.All that stuff is forgivable but it looks like micromanagement hell and that breaks it for me. Was expecting it to be Railroad Tycoon 3 but better, it isn't, it's TTD with a prettier UI and I hated TTD because of all the micro. Probably won't launch the game again. Pretty sad tbh.

content:

												Sadly this game is let down by a clunky user experience without refinement. Please can you make it easier to replace a 16 year old wagon ( or other item) on the same line.  Why can this not be done with a single click from the old wagons information page?  Instead you have to remember which wagon is old and on what line.. scrap it then buy a new one.... the put it back onto the original line..... not really user friendly.Saving a game is equally as bad....  it does not show up game history or previous files ....  Whilst on this subject the auto save pauses the game.... a real irritation when already frustratedCome on  - I know the game starts in the 1800's but the user interface should not be that antiquated.  Get some user testing and feedback done please and streamline the whole experience.This should be a great game, alongside any of the major Sims.... but it needs a lot of tweaking and streamlining before I play it again, Sorry.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												I have tried it a bit further today, and after the advice given, it is a bit clearer now. I have an idea how to make money now and I can get my emperium off the ground.However, understanding the basic concept now shows that the game is rather dull and empty. After a few bus lines and a single train line(which makes some good money, by the way) I have found that it is mostly waiting to get enough dough to continue on. Outside of buying a few vehicles and laying out the lines, there is nothing to do in between.Oh, and removing a depot renders your vehicles to that depot useless, you can't send them back anymore or send them back to your depot because it can't find one, even though I already had build one on almost the exact same place, on the exact same road.The UI is vague, the mouse moves like crap for some reason and the FPS isn't too good either. The music is absolutely abysmal and made me want to quit this game before it's even started. Oh, and when you save manually you cannot overwrite your current one(apparently)I should have known, because every single one of these games end up the same, but the screenshots looked so great.While my view on it is better than it was earlier, I still do not think it is worth the 25euros/dollars/regional equivalent you pay for it. I really do hope the developers continue to develop it, because it really needs it.--Updated the review after some advice from McLOVIN

number of helpful: 2 of 16 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												I have really, really tried to like this game but it is so annoying. No manual so just other players input. There are so many things you can't do, like put crossover tracks on a bridge, signals on a bridge, can't supply industry from more than one resource.....the list is endless. And you only discover this by trial and error and bulldozing or repeated reloading.IMHO procedures and routines have been botched to make things try and work. When building a railway and you have everything ready to go, click set line.....and the train has "no path" even though the coloured "path" is lit. The problem is that you have the game paused. This is such lazy programming that is unexcusable. A simple "Paused" would be more appropriate, but you end up checking the line for faults for 15-20mins anyway.Depending how many vehicles you have on a line will determine your frequency. You may have a frequency of 3mins, but according to the timeline, they take 5 months to get there!  Also, two trains on the same track with the same number of passengers and yet they get different income! With one train carrying upto 64 passengers why do so many disappear? Poor programming again!The game is only half finished judging by all the updates that are being implemented and due.My i5 4570 is o/c to 4.2Ghz and my HD 7850 is o/c 20% and on a large map with large cities and everything turned low, I get 8fps. Lots of artifacts as well.Would I recommend you buy this game? Yes, but in a year's time when it works properly (and should be cheaper).Unfortunately Steam will only let me post this review with a Yes/No choice instead of Yes/No/Not yet, so I'll say No for now.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Oh my...This is what happens when you offer wannabe-developers an unchecked realm to dump their trash upon the public. I don't even understand how Total Biscuit was able to take more than 10 minutes of it. (In fact he even excused the lacking options-screen, so he probably has a stake in this title, I guess.)Basicaly what we have here is a transport-tycoon offering that misses the mark on everything it touches.-Management is obtuse, confusing and totally left to the player to figure out.-It's called trainfever, but trains will bankrupt you.-Randomly generated map that actually blocks you from doing what you want.-Incredibly slow. So damn slow... So slooow... (Kill me now.)-Trucks and buses are where it's at. Ignore trams and trains or go bankrupt.-Most poorly optimized game of this decade. It must be a new standard for developers, I think.-Simulation depth is threadbare, uninteresting and not at all offering an incentive to play.-Industry can be ignored.-Trams and train can be ignored.-Developing cities can be ignored.-Upgrading roads can be ignored.-Modernizing your fleet is agonizing punishment.-Music is worse than elevator muzak.I wish this developer saved himself and us the trouble. I think that this developer hates gamers and especially those gamers that like transport-tycoon style games. I have no other handle on Train Fever to explain it's sorry existence. There can be no other explanation. This developer actively hates you and tries to have you commit suicide while you slowly come to realise, as you play Train Fever, that you're a pathetic slug who shouldn't be alive.Prove him wrong! Don't buy this contender for Ultimate Trash Cash Grab 2014.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												After many hours I now get the strategy. Get passengers into towns using trains. Accumulate cash, then start delivering products and raw materials to the producers. The challenge comes with keeping routes profitable and building lines that can cope with the geography and topology. I bought the game at discount so I think it was value for money. Graphics and game speed are fine with the right kit. What is good about the game? Graphics, definitely - excellent detail. Addiction level is fairly high. Dealing with the terrain is absorbing. What could be better? Scenarios and game goals needed. Vehicles need drivers - it looks weird seeing driverless wagons and buses! Overall, a good mix of strategy and addiction. Worth it at discount so put on your wish list.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												Pros:  Great transportation network game.  The scale of the models and terrain are pleasantly realistic.  Easy to learn and play.  Camera controls intuitive and easy to use.  Depth and replayability make this a long-term enjoyable experience.Cons:  The economic model is straightforward and a little boring.  I'm nostalgic for Rail Road Tycoon 3 which this game comes close to in a lot of ways, but doesn't match the economic complexities found in RRT3.  There are only a few commodities to transport with no high-tier goods to move around to meet certain demands. Rail laying can get a little tedious when you want to cross roads--the angle has to be just right with sometimes annoying "why won't this work!" moments.Overall this has been a great experience.  I hope to see further content come out in the future.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Great game! The train lines are a challenge and even after I think I've got them down pat, they sometimes still do things I'm not so sure are right, or at least, don't make sense to me. But that's part of what makes this game one you can play for a really long time. Even after you acheive certain goals and make millions, you can still work the game with several different objectives. I thought I might get tired of it after reaching the year 2000 but I have gone back and started new maps and tried to succeed different ways. It's been tough and I like that!The graphics are enjoyable and that's something I'm kind of picky about in games. The best thing about this game that I like is that you're not just building train lines, you're creating the towns with transport lines as well. I haven't even gotten into some of the mods yet, which I'm looking forward to. I'm still satisfied playing the base game for now, more like savoring it. But I think I saw a mod with plopable buildings which really excites me!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Very steep learning curve. Watch a few videos on YouTube if you get frustrated. Fun game though, especially if you get it on sale. Not worth $20, but anything under that it's a good buy.Some things I've learned: You don't need to add a bus line or tram line to a city before you connect passenger rail. Passenger rail is the most lucrative thing you can do (That I've found) - start early with one good line on flat land and you'll do well.Be very catutious before investing a lot of money in cargo lines, so far they've been money pits in 9/10 situations. Even when the cargo is really flowing I haven't had a lot of luck generating a lot of profit from it.Signals are unecessairly complicated but once you get it it makes sense.Have fun!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												The game has some issues (like track laying difficulties, level crossing issues), but is overall one of the better and most beautiful transport simulators around. The fully simulated citizens, gorgeous trains and amazing transport systems you can build are all worth buying it.Also, this is one of the few transport tycoon style games in which you have to build geometrically realistic rail lines and roads. No insane slopes or tight curvs here. Realism means that it takes skill to build the shortest, straightest route between two points.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												This is a fun game, with pros and cons. Adequate management in various forms of transport, from over the road to railroad. Trains do some pretty stupid things once in a while, like sit face-to-face at a signal for no apparent reason. There is no warning for when trains have stopped, or are becoming excessively late for their routes. The game has no intermittent signals like in real life. This allows trains to follow closer than switches as long as they are Goin the same direction. Need excessive amounts of double iron to handle some train traffic in the case to track overload. A few updates, and addition of a few features that are used on railroads in real life would make game a lot more enjoyable. Still very fun, definitely recommend.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												i didnt have the patience to earn my way to really mastering this game, instead i grabbed a couple of mods that make my education ramp up so much easier.   the No Cost mod make the nuances of this game more understandable, so go out and get the mods for this.  i know the new version of transport fever is coming out, discounting this version like 75% off. i am very happy with the 30-60 hours i will put into it and consider me as to having gotten my money worth and will chase the next version.  it can be an Ant Farm experience just sitting and waiting for more money without those mods imho.  note mods kill achievements which means you cant get the three Eon save points (1859, 1900, 1950) as boot date options.  so the mods will affect things but open a lot more...  also the uSA DLC i had to kind put a little work into for it to show, so watch that...  if this game is $5, get it, get a couple of mods, and enjoy 20+ hours before you kinda figure the whole thing out and before Ant Farm stage.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												As a train enthusiast since i was a baby, and a tycoon gamer, this is a MUST PLAY game, a great, fun, and oddly satisfying way to kill time, especially after a stressful day at work or school. During those boring days of sitting in class doing nothing, i just have those thoughts in my head saying "all i wanna do is go home, fire up my computer and play Train Fever." It's kinda like a stress reliever in my opinion, as if you're playing with a model trainset in a digital format.The game itself is kinda like a highly advanced style of Chris Swayer's Locomotion, only instead of 6 different types of ways to transport people/goods, it's heavily train-focused, so it definitely lives up to it's name "Train Fever" Anyway, I highly reccomend this game and i'm definitely looking forward to Transport Fever.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												Quite addictive. Some stumbling blocks at the start to figure out how the mechanics works, but once sorted it is enjoyable. For example took me awhile before I realised you have to specify the cargo on the trucks for them to pick it up, and cargo lines have to be quicker than 15 minutes to be used. Should perhaps be called Truck Fever as I make money mostly on buses and trucks, whilst slowly experienting with the often loss making trains. Not perfect, some UI is clunky but I enjoyed it. Looking forward to Transport Fever.Ps could so with some NPC characters in the USA DLC at the start. E.g. NPC horses  with riders and some wagons for more realistic view.  And some views as passenger/driver would be nice, but probably difficult and a lot of assets to create.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												I started on Easy Mode, on a small map, and worked my way up to a large map, and now I'm doing the Medium Mode on a Medium map...and making money hand over fist. It seems a lot easier than Transport Tycoon, or the Open Source TT version which I constantly failed at. I'm yet to attempt Hard Mode..but my advice is simple...before you get busy building Tram and Bus and passenger train routes, go for Cargo routes...if you do it right, the money just rolls in. It's an enjoyable game, with lots of challenges, particularly if you choose the hillier terrain modes. It would be good if we could have waterways too, so we could set up ferries and cargo ship routes. So yes, it's simple in concept, compared to more complicated sims, but it's still a lot of fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Very interesting game and good concept of path finding I have never seen before (there is no "station radius", only overall travel time (foot, bus, train, whatever) is important for passager to pick a route). Also it is great (but it becomes standart nowadays) non-rectangular completly free building of roads. Also good idea is dynamic city growth based on stations and lines availibilty (number of places where can passager get from his place within 20 minutes interval). Acceleration and decceleration model of trains is good and realistic (no stopping on 5 meters).But game overall is like beta-version or testing of technical concept. Most lacking parts:- More balanced graphics (colors), its less colorful and playful if you compare it for example with classic Tycoons.- Fixed path finding for trains. NO dynamic picking of available platform or path like you know from TTDX/OTTD. Every line has fixed path you define manually. This is main limiting factor of train building. Signals works only as start-stop (segmentation).- Industry model is joke.- There should be bigger maps. Cities placement on map can be more random (they have almost fixed distance between each other).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 19, 2016
												Graphics are tops and as eye candy it succeeds. City grow and building change from year to year.The rivers are well done and look wet.Cars and people change appearance as game years pass.As a railroad simulator is is limited to track planning with several unanticipated reasons why you cant build where you want.   Cities grow and may block future track plans. Industries are a challenge to predict future product levels.  Freight trains are  harder to manage and require a good guess as to the level of future traffic revenue .  Making route adjustments late in the game can result in rapid decline in revenue.  Game control is made awkward  by the use of  multiple windows for tasks that block scenery and rapidly fill the screen with text. Single window information and control would be an asset to game enjoyment.    Changing the consist of a line will  void all  built up development of traffic on that line,  so plan for this when adding stations or reemoving stations.  Growing a railroad is best done by adding a new line rather than extending existing lines.   This program was run on a gaming computer (Aspire V 17 Nitro. Ttrying to resume the game after a save and exit often  displays a  greyed out selections on start up screen which prevents further play. Small and medium screens are least likely to cause lag and crash problem on this Aapire laptop.|In spite of game mechanics and lag problems experienced, there is sufficient enjoyment to overcome frustrations and give this game a yes.

Posted: December 28, 2015
												Very interesting game and good concept of path finding I have never seen before (there is no "station radius", only overall travel time (foot, bus, train, whatever) is important for passager to pick a route). Also it is great (but it becomes standart nowadays) non-rectangular completly free building of roads. Also good idea is dynamic city growth based on stations and lines availibilty (number of places where can passager get from his place within 20 minutes interval). Acceleration and decceleration model of trains is good and realistic (no stopping on 5 meters).But game overall is like beta-version or testing of technical concept. Most lacking parts:- More balanced graphics (colors), its less colorful and playful if you compare it for example with classic Tycoons.- Fixed path finding for trains. NO dynamic picking of available platform or path like you know from TTDX/OTTD. Every line has fixed path you define manually. This is main limiting factor of train building. Signals works only as start-stop (segmentation).- Industry model is joke.- There should be bigger maps. Cities placement on map can be more random (they have almost fixed distance between each other).

content:
Posted: April 23
												DO NOT CONTRIBUTE TO THE DEGRADATION OF QUALITY GAMES!!How a company can charge for a pre-release, promise many updates on a paid incomplete game, and overall ignore community input JUST TO DROP THE GAME AND SELL A NEW ONE!!! Transport fever has been "pre-released" and is being given the same jump-off as train fever was given. How long until they give up on this and release another unfinished title!?This behavior from a game company is irresponsible and should be highlighted so weary gamers can tread lightly. Beyond that the game is fun IF you're willing to forego achievements or progress and download a gang of mods to make it enjoyable. Overall lack of industry. Poor economic balance and soothing yet repetative bgm.

												Train Fever was a good game, with a lot of flaws. I could write a long review about how the hardest thing in this game is to build rails - appreciate the irony for a train sim...Fortunately, the devs have released a sequel - Transport Fever - which does everything better and fixes almost every major issue there was with Train Fever.So there is no need to buy or play this game anymore - it was good while it was the only train sim out there - now you can jump straight to the sequel:
